GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 93.01 ADOPTION OF NATIONAL CODES BY REFERENCE.
   (A)   The following national regulations are hereby adopted and incorporated
by reference as if fully set forth herein:
      (1)   International Fire Code adopted. The 2006 International Fire Code
of the International Code Council is hereby adopted as the basic Fire
Prevention Code of the village; and each of all of the regulations, penalties,
conditions, and terms of the 2006 International Fire Code are hereby referred
to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter.
      (2)   The National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) No. 101 Life Safety
Code 2015 Edition and the most current publication of the remaining NFPA
standards as deemed necessary by the Fire Department.
   (B)   These regulations, as adopted herein, shall be known as the Winthrop
Harbor Fire Prevention Code.
   (C)   The purpose and the intent of the Winthrop Harbor Fire Prevention Code
is to prescribe minimum requirements and controls to safeguard life, property,
or public welfare from the hazards of fire and explosion arising from the
storage, handling, or use of substances, materials, or devices and from
conditions hazardous to life, property, or public welfare in the use or
occupancy of buildings, structures, sheds, tents, lots, or premises.
Accordingly, this Code shall be interpreted broadly to the maximum extent
permissible under applicable state and federal law.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.02 DUTIES OF THE BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the officers assigned to the Bureau of Fire
Prevention to enforce all laws and ordinances of the village covering the
following:
      (1)   The prevention of fires.
      (2)   The storage and use of explosives and flammables.
      (3)   The installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm
systems and fire extinguishing equipment.
      (4)   The means and adequacy of exit, in case of fire, from factories,
schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters,
amphitheaters and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or
congregate, from time to time, for any purpose.
      (5)   The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes.
      (6)   The investigation of the causes, origins and circumstances of
fires.
      (7)   An annual fire inspection shall be required for all properties
within the village except residential occupancies consisting of three units or
less. Scheduled inspections that result in a No Call/No Show to allow access
for the scheduled inspection shall result in a fee of $25 for each missed
inspection after two or more.
      (8)   The Fire Chief shall have the sole power and discretion to waive
the fee for No Call/No Show set forth hereinabove for good cause shown.
   (B)   Bureau members shall also have such other powers and perform such
other duties as are set forth in this subchapter and as may be conferred and
imposed from time to time by law. The Fire Chief may delegate any of his or her
powers or duties under this subchapter to a duly designated Fire Marshal.
Residential occupancy inspections will be coordinated with the village’s rental
inspection program if one is then in existence.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.03 FEE AND PERMIT SCHEDULE.
   The Fire Chief shall maintain a fee and permit schedule in the main office
of the Fire Department. The Fire Chief shall propose fees for the matters under
the jurisdiction of the Department to the Village Board on at least a biennial
basis. The Village Board shall consider the same and adopt such proposed fees
that they deem appropriate and necessary in their sole discretion by way of
resolution. The Fire Chief shall make such schedule available to all persons
upon request.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
EXPLOSIVES AND FIREWORKS
§ 93.10 EXPLOSIVES.
   Explosive regulations are governed by the provisions of the standard codes
adopted by reference in § 93.01(A) and the rules set forth therein shall be
strictly enforced in all instances.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.11 FIREWORKS.
   (A)   Adoption. Pursuant to the authority and in accordance with the
provisions of ILCS Ch. 425, Act 35, § 2 and all other applicable police powers
and authority, the village hereby adopts in its entirety the Illinois
Pyrotechnic Use Act, ILCS Ch. 425, Act 35, §§ 0.01 et seq., as it currently
exists, and as it may hereafter be amended, together with any and all
regulations duly adopted by the Office of the State Fire Marshall pursuant to
the authority so vested in that Office by ILCS Ch. 425, Act 35, § 4.1 and the
same are adopted as ordinance provisions of the village. Any ticket or
complaint charging a violation of the provisions of the Pyrotechnic Use Act
incorporated herein may note that the offense is being charged as a violation
of municipal law but may also describe the specific offense using the statutory
section number from the Pyrotechnic Use Act.
   (B)   No public exhibition of fireworks or pyrotechnics shall be given
unless a permit therefor is first secured from the Fire Chief with the express
approval of the Board of Trustees. All such public displays shall be under the
supervision of one or more persons duly licensed pursuant to ILCS Ch. 425, Act
35, § 2.1 and the site shall be supervised by the Fire Chief or some member of
the Fire Department assigned to the duty.
   (C)   Penalty. Any violation of the provisions of the Pyrotechnic Use Act
shall hereafter be considered a violation of this chapter and each such
violation shall subject the violator thereof to the penalty provisions provided
in the Illinois Pyrotechnic Use Act, up to and including a class A misdemeanor.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
FIRE PREVENTION SYSTEMS
§ 93.20 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALARM HOLDER. The owner, lessee or other person responsible for the presence
or maintenance of an alarm system within or on a premises.
   ALARM SYSTEM. An assembly of equipment devices designed to signal the
presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police and/or fire
personnel are expected to respond. Such an alarm system may include BURGLAR,
HOLDUP or FIRE ALARMS and any system designed to monitor water flow, smoke,
temperature, humidity or other like conditions. Included are internal premises
systems with an audible sound and/or flashing lights or beacons designed to
signal persons outside the premises.
   AUTHORIZED CENTRAL RECEIVING STATION. An office or place duly authorized by
the village as a receiver of alarm transmissions to which alarms are connected
and where operators supervise or monitor such alarms and immediately and
automatically send a data transmission of said alarm to the village’s dispatch
center.
   AUTOMATIC DIALER. An alarm system which automatically transmits over regular
telephone lines (as distinguished from dedicated telephone lines) a pre-
recorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of an emergency
situation.
   BURGLAR ALARM. An alarm system activated automatically signaling an entry or
attempted entry into a building or vehicle protected by the alarm system.
   DEDICATED TELEPHONE LINE. A telephone line which has its sole use the
transmission of an alarm signal.
   FALSE ALARM. An alarm signal which indicates the existence of an emergency
situation when in fact, no such emergency exists.
   FEES. The monies paid by an alarm holder to connect his alarm system to the
central answering point at village facilities.
   FIRE ALARM. Any automatic or manual system installed in any commercial or
industrial structure and any residential structure with greater than two
dwelling units within the village, installed to detect the presence of fire or
its by-products and alert the buildings occupants by visual and audible means
of the presence of a fire.
   FIRE ALARM USER. The person, firm, partnership, association, corporation,
company or organization of any kind in control of the property protected by a
fire alarm.
   LOCAL ALARM. An alarm system which when activated causes an audible and/or
visual signal in or on the premises which the system is designed to protect.
Such type of alarm may or may not be a part of a system to notify an answering
point.
   SERVICE CHARGE. An assessment by the village against an alarm holder for
false alarms emitted from this alarm system as provided §§ 91.02 through 91.99.
   TROUBLE INDICATION. A transmitted signal different from the alarm signal
which indicates a mechanical/electrical problem in the system.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.21 FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (A)   Enforcement. The Fire Chief or his or her designee shall have the
responsibility for enforcement of this chapter.
   (B)   Fire alarm connections.
      (1)   Required connections. It shall be unlawful to install, modify, or
upgrade any fire alarm system or component thereof as described in this
subchapter, without first obtaining approval of the Fire Marshal. This approval
is separate from any other permit required by the village for any new
construction, remodel, repair or alteration of any building. All fire alarm
systems in any commercial or industrial structure and any residential structure
with greater than two dwelling units, that automatically transmit the presence
of an alarm to any central receiving station, shall be tied to an approved
central answering station chosen by the alarm holder and approved by the Fire
Department’s Fire Marshal in accordance with the requirements of the adopted
edition of National Fire Protection Association, Standard 72 (National Fire
Alarm Code), International Fire Code, National Fire Protection Standard 70
(National Electrical Code) and the village’s municipal code.
         (a)   New buildings shall comply with the requirements of this chapter
before the building is occupied or used for any other purpose other than its
construction.
         (b)   Any existing structure other than residential buildings with
less than four dwelling units shall add a fire alarm system for the entire
structure regardless of building separation, fire-rated assemblies and type of
construction, at any time that any addition, major renovation (50% or more), or
expansion of the structure increases the gross square footage of the structure
as it existed on January 1, 2003 by 2,500 square feet or more.
         (c)   The status of all fire alarm systems required by this section
shall be monitored continuously through a method approved by the Fire
Department’s Fire Marshal. Phone lines shall not be an approved method of
transmitting fire alarm systems. Wireless technology is preferred.
         (d)   Automated secure alarm protocol (ASAP) technology may be
utilized dependent on the Village of Winthrop Harbor’s Dispatch Center’s CAD
vendor and capabilities.
      (2)   Permit. No person shall be authorized to install, connect, or
maintain an alarm system under this code whether within the corporate limits of
the village, the Fire District or from an adjoining municipality, municipality
or county which has entered into a communications services agreement with the
village without first obtaining approval and a permit from the Fire Marshal. An
applicant for a license or a permit shall furnish satisfactory proof to the
Fire Marshal that he or she is familiar with the materials used in the activity
for which the license or permit is required, that he or she is competent to do
and perform all acts necessary or incidental to such activity as may be
required by this chapter; and that he or she is familiar with and knows the
application of the requirements of the provisions of the fire prevention codes
of the village. If the Fire Marshal determines that the applicant for any such
license or permit conforms in all particulars with these requirements, the Fire
Marshal shall give his or her approval to the issuance of such license or
permit.
         (a)   The permit application shall be on a fire alarm user
registration form prescribed by the Fire Department. In addition, all
applicants shall agree as follows:
            1.   To enter into a subscription agreement with a central
receiving station approved by the Fire Marshal.
            2.   That the village shall not be held liable for any claimed
failure of service or any damages that may result from the installation,
maintenance or operation of the alarm system which is and shall remain entirely
the alarm holder’s responsibility.
            3.   To indemnify, defend and save harmless the village from all
claims, demands, judgments, liability, costs and expenses that may arise, in
anyway as a result of the alarm connection.
            4.   That the alarm subscriber, not the village, is liable for any
and all costs or expenses of installation, lease, maintenance, service or any
other charges or fees for any alarm equipment leased or owned by the applicant.
            5.   Submit a fee as identified in the Fee and Permit Schedule
maintained by the Fire Chief prior to a permit being issued by the Fire
Marshal.
            6.   Upon final acceptance of the fire alarm system, a certificate
of acceptance will be issued to the alarm holder. The certificate of acceptance
sticker shall be affixed on the fire alarm panel by the Fire Marshal at time of
testing and approval.
         (b)   All applicants must certify that they have alarm system
maintenance provided on a 24-hour basis.
         (c)   All alarm systems connecting under this code shall be subject to
inspection for compatibility by the Fire Marshal and/or the Fire Department at
any time they deem necessary or advisable. All fire alarm users shall allow the
Fire Marshal and/or the Fire Department access to the premises upon which the
fire alarm systems are installed, for the purpose of inspection, during regular
business hours.
         (d)   The central receiving station must be able to transmit
identifying remarks related to the source signal and required response as
defined by the Fire Marshal. An example would be identifying the alarm location
as a “target hazard.”
         (e)   A redundant means of confirming alarm transmission to the
Dispatch Center shall be maintained by the authorized central answering
station.
      (3)   Equipment. In addition to any other requirement under the code, all
alarms connected herein shall bear Factory Mutual, Underwriters’ Laboratories,
Inc., or equivalent labels.
      (4)   Connection and maintenance fees. All connection and maintenance
fees shall be in accordance with the Fee and Permit Schedule maintained by the
Fire Chief.
      (5)   Issuance. Upon compliance with all the requirements of this
division (B), the Fire Marshal shall issue a permit.
      (6)   Testing of equipment. All fire alarm subscribers shall submit proof
of a successful test of their system by a licensed alarm contractor annually.
Each fire alarm user is solely responsible for the installation, maintenance,
repair, upkeep and operation of his or her own fire alarm system. All fire
alarm systems covered under this subchapter shall be tested and system
components cleaned annually by a licensed alarm contractor. Documentation of
the fire alarm system testing and maintenance shall be submitted to the Fire
Marshal within 14 days of such testing/cleaning. No person shall conduct any
test or demonstration of any permitted fire alarm system without first having
notified the Fire Department and the monitoring location, and if unable to
contact, then the 911 dispatch center shall be notified of the test or
demonstration. When a fire alarm system is out of service for any reason, the
Fire Marshal, or his or her designee, may, at their sole discretion, require
the fire alarm user to implement a fire watch at the user’s expense until such
time as the fire alarm system is back in service.
      (7)   Disconnection and reconnection.
         (a)   Causes for disconnection from an authorized central receiving
station.
            1.   Failure to pay any fees, maintenance charges, or service
charges required by this subchapter shall be cause for the Fire Marshal to
request disconnection of an alarm system after 60 days’ notice.
            2.   Twelve false alarms from any one alarm system within any 12-
month period shall be cause for the Fire Marshal to request disconnection of an
alarm system after 60 days’ notice.
            3.   Six or more trouble indications within any 12-month period
shall be cause for the Fire Marshal to request disconnection of an alarm system
after 60 days’ notice.
            4.   The alarm holder shall be responsible for any cost or charge
arising from the disconnection.
            5.   If a given fire alarm system is found to be unsatisfactory or
in improper working order, the Fire Marshal may require that the system be
disconnected until such time as corrections are made. The Fire Marshal or
designee may require a fire watch should a disconnection be required. Any fire
alarm placed out-of-service pursuant to this section must be repaired and
placed back in service within a time period specified by the Fire Marshal,
provided however, that the fire alarm user may, in accordance with all
applicable state, local and federal laws, determine not to reinstall or repair
said system. Should the fire alarm user determine not to repair the system, all
components of the fire alarm system shall be removed from the premises, and a
written notice shall be given to the Fire Marshal advising of this change
within 14 days thereof.
            6.   Should a fire alarm user terminate its contract with a central
receiving station a written notice shall be given to the Fire Marshal advising
of this change within 14 days thereof.
         (b)   Reconnection.
            1.   If an alarm system has been disconnected because of nonpayment
of any fees or charges, upon payment in full of all outstanding fees and
charges, the alarm system may be reconnected.
            2.   If an alarm has been disconnected for trouble indications, the
alarm holder must submit a written statement indicating that repairs have been
made to correct the mechanical/electrical problem in the system. After
verification that the system is properly functioning, the alarm system may be
reconnected.
            3.   If the alarm system has been disconnected because of false
alarms, the alarm holder must submit a written statement indicating the reasons
for the false alarms and stating what measures have been taken to prevent or
minimize future false alarms. Upon review of the statement, the alarm system
may be reconnected at the discretion of the village.
            4.   The alarm holder shall be responsible for any cost or charge
arising from the reconnection.
   (C)   Another central answering point. In addition to making the required
fire alarm system connections pursuant to this code, nothing shall prohibit the
connection of any alarm system to a secondary central answering point.
   (D)   Misuses of fire alarm systems and false alarms.
      1.   Misuse of alarms. It is unlawful for any person to activate an alarm
system for any purpose other than that which the alarm system was originally
designed to detect.
      2.   False alarms. Alarms resulting from any of the following causes
shall not be considered to be a false alarm as that term is defined in this
subchapter provided that such event is verified by the Fire Marshal.
         (a)   A fire causing structural damage to the protected premises.
         (b)   An earthquake affecting the village.
         (c)   A tornado or hurricane affecting the village.
         (d)   Flooding of the protected premises.
         (e)   Lightning causing physical damage to the protected premises.
         (f)   Telephone line malfunction verified to the Fire Marshal by an
authorized telephone company supervisor within seven days of the occurrence.
         (g)   Electrical service interruption verified to the Fire Marshal by
an authorized electric company supervisor within seven days of the occurrence.
         (h)   Plumbing or electrical malfunctions unrelated to the alarm
system at the protected premises.
      (3)   Grace period. Fire alarm users shall be granted a 30-day grace
period from the date of final acceptance testing before alarms emanating from
the protected premises shall be deemed to be false alarms.
      (4)   Out-of-service alarms. A fire alarm which gives three or more false
alarms within a 12-hour period may be considered by the Fire Marshal to be in
improper working order and removed from service until repaired. Twelve false
alarms from any one alarm system within any 12-month period shall be cause for
the Fire Marshal to request disconnection of an alarm system after 60 days’
notice.
   (E)   Penalty. Penalties for misuse of alarms or false alarms shall be
punishable by a fine not to exceed $750 per violation to be imposed as follows:
      (1)   For the first three false alarms in any 12-month period, no fine
may be assessed, unless the Fire Marshal shows willful and wanton misconduct on
the part of the fire alarm user, his or her employees or agents.
      (2)   For a fourth and fifth false alarm in any 12-month period, a fine
of $85 shall be assessed for each Fire Department response thereto.
      (3)   For a sixth and seventh false alarm in any 12-month period, a fine
of $110 shall be assessed for each Fire Department response thereto.
      (4)   For an eighth and ninth false alarm in any 12-month period, a fine
of $220 shall be assessed for each Fire Department response thereto.
      (5)   For a tenth false alarm and for each and every succeeding false
alarm in any 12-month period, a fine of $330 shall be assessed for each Fire
Department response thereto.
      (6)   For any false alarm emanating from a fire alarm user who has not
received a permit or certificate of acceptance from the Fire Marshal for the
operation of a fire alarm system in the village, a fine of $550 shall be
assessed for each and every false alarm until the system has been authorized
and a permit issued.
      (7)   The village may file a lien against the protected premises for any
outstanding fine which is reduced to judgment.
      (8)   Any person issued a citation under this section shall have the
right to seek a hearing in front of the village’s duly appointed adjudication
hearing officer. In such a hearing, the person seeking the hearing shall have
the burden of proof.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.22 SPRINKLER SYSTEMS REQUIRED.
   (A)   Sprinkler systems shall be installed in all use groups as required by
§ 903 of the 2006 International Fire Code and as required by the NFPA 2006 Life
Safety Code. Any residential structure with two or more dwelling units shall
have an automatic fire sprinkler system installed prior to occupancy.
   (B)   Remodeling. Any existing structure other than residential buildings
with less than four dwelling units shall add an automatic fire sprinkler system
for the entire structure regardless of building separation, fire-rated
assemblies and type of construction, at any time that any addition, expansion,
or commercial major renovation (50% or more) of the structure increases the
gross square footage of the structure as it existed on January 1, 2003 by 2,500
square feet or more.
   (C)   Strobe lights required. A white strobe light shall be installed on all
residences protected by an automatic sprinkler system. The strobe shall be
placed directly over the Fire Department connection in addition to the required
ten-inch bell. The strobe light shall be clearly visible from the Fire
Department’s normal access route. A horn/strobe light combination device may be
installed in place of the ten-inch bell at the discretion of the Fire
Department.
   (D)   Connection required. All automatic sprinkler systems shall be
connected to the Winthrop Harbor Police/Fire Dispatch Center by direct
connection. In the event of the activation of any such system, an alarm shall
sound on the premises and an alarm shall be transmitted to the Dispatch Center
in order to alert the Fire Department.
   (E)   Compliant systems. At all times, the Fire Department shall maintain a
list of commercially available and approved automatic sprinkler systems, and
shall freely distribute such list to all building owners and occupants upon
request. The Fire Department shall not recommend any particular system or be
required to provide any engineering or design services, but shall review all
submitted plans prior to installation as part of the building permit approval
process to ensure compliance with this section.
   (F)   Maintenance. All automatic sprinkler systems must remain operational
and in good working order at all times.
   (G)   Liability. All owners of structures regulated under this section shall
have a non-delegable duty to ensure that all such sprinklers remain operational
and in good working order at all times. All building tenants and occupants,
other than residential apartment dwellers, have a joint and several duty with
the building owner to ensure that all such sprinklers remain operational and in
good working order at all times.
   (H)   Controlled areas. All buildings required to have sprinklers under this
section shall have sprinklers installed in all living areas and all common
areas of the structure, including, but not limited to, hallways, vestibules,
storage rooms, entryways, laundry rooms and attached garages.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.23 AUTOMATIC DIALER SYSTEMS.
   Upon the effective date of this chapter the connection of any automatic
dialer alarm system to any village facility is prohibited except by permit
through the designated digital alarm receiving equipment for police and fire
alarms at the remote receiving facility in the appropriate department of the
village. The issuance of any such permit shall be at the sole discretion of the
remote receiving facility, which may set all terms and conditions for such
permit.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.24 LOCAL ALARMS.
   (A)   Local alarms shall not transmit an audible sound which is similar to
or imitates emergency vehicles or the village’s severe weather alerting system.
   (B)   Local alarms emitting audible sound shall have an automatic shut off
which will deactivate the signal after one-half hour. The Police and/or Fire
Departments may enter the premises to deactivate a signal which is not shut off
within one-half hour activation. Such action shall be taken only after
reasonable efforts to contact the alarm holder have been made. Neither the
village nor its employees shall be liable for any damages resulting from such
action.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS
§ 93.30 BUILDING PLANS.
   The owners or developers of all new buildings, other than single-family
detached residences, shall provide three sets of blueprints to be submitted for
final review. No construction permit or occupancy permit shall be granted for
any building regulated hereunder until such plans are provided and accepted.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.31 STANDPIPES REQUIRED.
   All newly constructed buildings other than detached single-family homes
having floors used for human occupancy located two or more stories above grade
shall be equipped with standpipes prior to occupancy. Hoses shall not be
required. The standpipes shall have connections at grade level approved by the
Fire Department or its designee. All standpipe systems shall be hydrostatically
tested at five-year intervals or any shorter term designated by the NFPA.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.32 RAPID KEY ENTRY SYSTEM REQUIRED.
   (A)   All structures which are currently equipped with, or which are
required under this code to be equipped with, a fire alarm system, sprinkler
system or fire extinguishing system, or wherein materials are stored that the
Fire Chief deems to pose such a threat to human health and safety and risk of
property damage as to require entry to such structure prior to the arrival of
the owner or other key holder, shall be equipped with a Knox brand rapid entry
key box, which box shall be installed after consultation with the Fire Chief or
the Chief’s designee regarding the size and location of such box.
   (B)   In addition to those structures described in division (A) of this
section, all apartment buildings with four or more units and that have common
entrances or exits shall be equipped with Knox boxes as described above.
   (C)   All existing structures which are required to have rapid entry boxes
under this section shall have them fully installed not later than June 30,
2024.
   (D)   No building or structure erected to remodeled hereafter which shall be
required to have a rapid entry box shall receive a certificate of occupancy
from the village unless and until the rapid entry box is fully installed.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.33 SMOKE DETECTORS.
   The village strictly enforces all statutes and regulations regarding smoke
detectors, including, but not limited to the Illinois Smoke Detector Act, ILCS
Ch. 425, Act 60, §§ 1 et seq., and the Facilities Requiring Smoke Detectors
Act, ILCS Ch. 425, Act 10, §§ 0.01 et seq., together with all regulations
adopted thereunder, and together with all related regulations in the standard
codes adopted by reference in §
93.01 of this code.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.34 CARBON MONOXIDE DETECTORS.
   The village strictly enforces all statutes and regulations regarding carbon
monoxide detectors, including, but not limited to the Illinois Carbon Monoxide
Alarm Detector Act, ILCS Ch. 430, Act 135, § 1 et seq., together with all
regulations adopted thereunder, and together with all related regulations in
the standard codes adopted by reference in §
93.01 of this code.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
§ 93.36 TAMPERING WITH DETECTORS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for an owner, manager, occupant or any other person to
vandalize or tamper with the smoke detectors, or in any way render smoke
detectors or carbon monoxide detectors inoperative or to cause them to be
impaired in their ability to detect and give early warning of smoke or fire.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see § 93.99
MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS
§ 93.45 MARINA REFUELING OPERATIONS.
   (A)   All refueling operations or service stations at any marina or harbor
shall be of the attended type only. Self-service for the pumping of any fuels
shall be prohibited. It is also prohibited for any boater, marina operator,
employee or any other person to use or allow the use of any holdopen clip or
device of any type, to be used to hold open the nozzle of any fuel pump.
   (B)   Any person violating the provisions of division (A) above shall be
liable for any and all direct and indirect costs incurred by the village in
cleaning any spilled petrochemical into any body of water within the
territorial boundary of the village, in addition to any fines and penalties
imposed by law.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24) Penalty, see §
93.99
§ 93.99 PENALTY.
   Any person that is adjudged guilty of violating any of the provisions of
this chapter for which no other penalty has been provided shall be guilty of an
offense against the village, punishable by a fine of not less than $100 and not
more than $750.
(Ord. 2024-O-5, passed 3-19-24)
CHAPTER 94: ABANDONED AND JUNK VEHICLES
Section
   
94.01   Definitions
   
94.02   Abandonment unlawful
   
94.03   Notification of Police Department
   
94.04   Towing authorized
   
94.05   Record of vehicle towed
   
94.06   Search of state motor vehicle records for identity of owner
   
94.07   Reclaiming possession
   
94.08   Disposition of unclaimed vehicles
   
94.09   Records to be kept for one year
   
94.10   Proceeds from disposition of unclaimed vehicles
   
94.11   Storage of inoperable vehicles required
   
94.12   Waiver of liability
 
   
94.99   Penalty
§ 94.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED VEHICLE. All motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of
disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition; or
any motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven
consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted.
   ANTIQUE VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle or other vehicle 25 years of age or
older.
   HIGHWAY. Any street, alley, or public way within the village.
   JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLE or DISABLED MOTOR VEHICLE. Any vehicle which is without
current valid license plates and/or in either wrecked, discarded, dismantled,
inoperative or abandoned condition.
   JUNKED VEHICLE or DISABLED VEHICLE. Any travel trailer, any camper, any
motor home, any tent or camping trailer, any motor home or camper box, any
boat, car, or other type of trailer, or any boat, hover craft, or license
plates and/or in either wrecked, discarded, dismantled, inoperative or
abandoned condition.
   VEHICLE. Any automobile, truck, bus, or similar vehicle designed for
operation on public highways.
   VEHICLES, INOPERABLE. Any vehicle in its present state which is incapable of
being operated on a public highway and has remained in such state for a period
of 30 days.
('79 Code, § 1808(1)) (Ord. 1983-O-20, passed 9-6-83)
§ 94.02 ABANDONMENT UNLAWFUL.
   The abandonment of a motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part thereof on
any highway in this village is unlawful except on property of the owner or
bailee of such abandoned vehicle. A motor vehicle or other vehicle or any part
thereof so abandoned on private property may be authorized for removal by or
upon the order of the Chief of Police after a waiting period of seven days or
more has expired. The Police Department shall place a notice sticker/sign on
said vehicle giving notice that it will be towed after said seven-day waiting
period has so expired.
('79 Code, § 1808(2)) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.03 NOTIFICATION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   When an abandoned, lost, stolen, or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle
comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this state, not
the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the Police
Department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the village. Upon
receipt of such notification, the Chief of the Police Department shall
authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the abandoned,
lost, stolen, or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service
will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents, maintain a record of the
tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person legally
entitled to possession thereof, or until it is disposed of as provided in this
chapter.
('79 Code, § 1808(3)) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.04 TOWING AUTHORIZED.
   (A)   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is abandoned on a highway in
this village ten hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be
authorized by order of the Chief of the Police Department.
   (B)   When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned, or partially
dismantled motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because
of its position in relation to the highway, or its physical appearance is
causing the impeding of traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a
towing service may be authorized by order of the Chief of the Police
Department.
   (C)   When the removal of a vehicle from either public or private property
is authorized by order of the Chief of the Police Department, the owner of the
vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs.
('79 Code, § 1808(4))
   (D)   The storing, placing, or allowing to remain in the open on private
property within the village of motor vehicle bodies, parts, equipment, motors,
and materials for a period of more than 48 hours in any one calendar month is
hereby prohibited, unless necessary for the operation of a business enterprise
lawfully conducted thereon.
   (E)   The parking or storing of junked or disabled motor vehicles and junked
or disabled vehicles and the storing or allowing to remain in the open of motor
vehicle bodies, parts, equipment, motors, and materials or junked or disabled
vehicle bodies, parts, equipment, motors and materials in violation of division
(D) above is declared to constitute a public nuisance. The Police Department
will be empowered to declare such a public nuisance to exist.
   (F)   The village shall notify the person in control of any private property
to relocate any junked or disabled motor vehicle or junked or disabled vehicles
parked or stored in violation of division (D) above and/or any motor vehicle,
bodies, parts, equipment, etc., stored and allowed to remain in the open in
violation of division (D) above to a completely closed location on the property
or otherwise to remove the same from the premises. Such notice shall be given
by certified or registered mail addressed to the residence or usual place of
business of such person.
   (G)   When a vehicle has been defined and declared a nuisance, the owner
shall have seven days from the receipt of the notice provided for in division
(F) above to request a hearing with the Village Board, such request shall be
filed with the Village Clerk.
   (H)   If, after the expiration of seven days from the receipt of the notice
provided for in division (F) above, the person so notified has failed to
request a hearing pursuant to division (G) above, or has failed, neglected, or
refused to comply with the direction of such notice, the village shall pay for
the removal and disposal of such motor vehicles, motor vehicle bodies, motors,
equipment, etc., or order the removal and disposal by the village.
   (I)   In the event the village is required to remove and dispose of the
motor vehicle, motor vehicle bodies, motors, equipment, etc., the person in
control of the premises shall be liable to the village for the expense occurred
by the village. A statement shall be rendered to the person liable for the cost
thereof, and if not paid, suit shall be instituted.
(Ord. 1990-O-7, passed 5-15-90)
§ 94.05 RECORD OF VEHICLE TOWED.
   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the
Police Department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed,
listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name,
manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and
license plate year, and the number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall
also include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed to,
reason for towing, and the name of the officer authorizing the tow.
('79 Code, § 1808(5))
§ 94.06 SEARCH OF STATE MOTOR VEHICLE RECORDS FOR IDENTITY OF OWNER.
   (A)   When the Police Department does not know the identity of the
registered owner or other legally entitled person, it will cause the motor
vehicle registration records of the state to be searched by a directed
communication to the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining the
required ownership information.
   (B)   The Police Department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the
State Police to be searched by a directed communication to the State Police for
stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the State Police files are
searched with negative results, the information contained in the National Crime
Information Center (NCIC) files will be searched by the State Police. The
information determined from these record searches will be used by the Police
Department in sending a notification by certified mail to the owner or legally
entitled person advising where the vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be
made, and setting forth public sale information.
('79 Code, § 1808(6))
   (C)   When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the
possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the
registration files of this state or from the registration files of a foreign
state, if applicable, the Police Department shall notify the State Police for
the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person legally entitled
to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the State Police
will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement agency having custody of
the vehicle for notification of owner. ('79 Code, § 1808(7))
§ 94.07 RECLAIMING POSSESSION.
   Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or
disposed of as provided herein, the owner or other person legally entitled to
its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the Police Department
proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No
vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person under this section until
all towing and storage charges have been paid.
('79 Code, § 1808(8))
§ 94.08 DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES.
   (A)   Whenever an abandoned, lost, stolen, or unclaimed motor vehicle or
other vehicle, seven years of age or newer, remains unclaimed by the registered
owner or other person legally entitled to its possession for a period of 30
days after notice has been given as provided herein, the Police Department
having possession of the vehicle shall cause it to be sold at public sale to
the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in
a conspicuous place for at least ten days prior to the sale on the premises
where the vehicle has been impounded.
      (1)    At least ten days prior to the sale, the Police Department shall
cause a notice of the time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail
to the registered owner or other person known by the Police Department or
towing service to be legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. Such
notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what
steps must be taken by any legally entitled person to reclaim the vehicle.
      (2)   In those instances where the certified notification specified
herein has been returned by the postal authorities to the Police Department due
to the addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from
the registration records of this state, the sending of a second certified
notice will not be required.
('79 Code, § 1808(9))
   (B)   When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally
entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost, or unclaimed vehicle of seven
years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided for in this
chapter, the vehicle may be sold as provided herein or disposed of in the
manner authorized by this chapter without notice to the registered owner or
other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle.
   (C)   When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven years of age is impounded
as specified by this chapter, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of ten
days for the purpose of determining ownership, the contacting of the registered
owner by the U.S. Mail, public service, or in person for a determination of
disposition; and an examination of the State Police stolen motor vehicle files
for
theft and wanted information. At the expiration of the ten-day period, without
the benefit of disposition information being received from the registered
owner, the Chief of Police will authorize the disposal of the vehicle as junk
only.
   (D)   A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is
excluded from this chapter.
('79 Code, § 1808(10))
§ 94.09 RECORDS TO BE KEPT FOR ONE YEAR.
   When a motor vehicle or other vehicle in the custody of the Police
Department is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled
person, or when the vehicle is sold at public sale or otherwise disposed of as
provided in this chapter, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the
Police Department for a period of one year from the date of the sale or
disposal.
('79 Code, § 1808(11))
§ 94.10 PROCEEDS FROM DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES.
   When a vehicle located within the corporate limits of the village is
authorized to be towed away by the Chief of Police and disposed of as set forth
in this chapter, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition after the
deduction of towing, storage, and processing charges shall be deposited in the
municipal treasury.
('79 Code, § 1808(12))
§ 94.11 STORAGE OF INOPERABLE VEHICLES REQUIRED.
   The storage outside of an enclosed building of one or more abandoned or
inoperable vehicles or parts thereof, or of any junk or debris, machinery, or
equipment not in operable condition, except on property in a zone in which a
junkyard is permitted under the zoning ordinance, is declared a public
nuisance.
('79 Code, § 1808(14)) (Ord. 1983-O-20, passed 9-6-83) Penalty, see §
94.99
§ 94.12 WAIVER OF LIABILITY.
   Any police officer, towing service owner, operator, or employee shall not be
held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner, or the owner's legal representative, or any
other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other
vehicle when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by
this chapter.
('79 Code, § 1808(13))
§ 94.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   The owner of any vehicle or junk declared to be a nuisance hereunder,
or any person owning, leasing, occupying, or having control of property on
which a nuisance exists shall be issued a notice to correct the violation by an
authorized officer of the village and shall be given a reasonable time, but no
less than 48 hours, to correct said violation. If the owner, lessee, occupant,
or person having control of the property fails to correct the violation within
the time stated on the notice, that person shall be fined the sum of $25 for
the first offense, $50 for the second offense, $100 for the third offense and
$200 for the fourth and any subsequent offense. Each day during which a
violation exists following expiration of the time allowed in the notice shall
be deemed a separate offense. Additionally, if the owner, lessee, occupant, or
person having control of the property fails to correct the violation within the
time stated on the notice, the village, through its duly designated officers,
shall have the right to secure an order of court to enter upon the property and
correct such violation, and shall have a lien against such property for the
reasonable cost of correction, together with the reasonable costs, expenses and
attorney's fees incurred in seeking such court order.
   (B)   All other violations of any provision of this chapter shall be deemed
a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, the person in violation shall be
fined an amount not more than $500. Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable hereunder as such.
('79 Code, § 1808(15))
   (C)   Whoever violates the following series of code sections shall be fined
pursuant to the chart set forth hereinbelow:
 
Offense Section Number 1st Offense 2nd Offense 3rd Offense
§                     $25         $50         $100
94.11
 
(Ord. 1983-O-20, passed 9-6-83; Am. Ord. 1999-O-17, passed 6-15-99; Am. Ord.
2006-O-17, passed 9-5-06)

CONTAGIOUS DISEASES
§ 95.01 REPORTS REQUIRED.
   Every physician called in to handle a case of a contagious or epidemic
disease in the village shall make a report of the same within 24 hours after
being called in to the Health Officer. In case no physician is in attendance,
it shall be the duty of the person in charge or in care of any person with such
disease to make a report within 24 hours from the time the disease is
recognized.
('79 Code, § 1201(1))
§ 95.02 QUARANTINE.
   The Board of Health and the Health Officer shall have charge of the
establishment and enforcement of reasonable quarantine rules. They shall have
the power and authority to place any premises within which a contagious or
infectious disease occurs under quarantine, and shall determine the time when
the quarantine shall end.
('79 Code, § 1201(2))
§ 95.03 FUMIGATION.
   Premises which have been quarantined in accordance with the terms of §
95.02, or in which a contagious disease has occurred, shall be thoroughly
fumigated or otherwise freed from all risk of infection under the supervision
of the Health Officer, before the quarantine shall be lifted.
('79 Code, § 1201(3))
§ 95.04 SPREADING CONTAGION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or carelessly aid or cause
the spread of any contagious disease.
('79 Code, § 1201(4)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.05 DELIVERIES TO QUARANTINED PREMISES.
   No person engaged in the delivery of food or drink intended for human
consumption shall enter into any premises which are quarantined because of the
existence of a contagious disease. No containers or bottles shall be removed
from such premises until the termination of the quarantine; and no such
containers which have been left at the premises during the quarantine period
shall be placed in use for the carrying of food or drink until they have been
thoroughly sterilized.
('79 Code, § 1201(5)) Penalty, see §
95.99
GARBAGE DISPOSAL FOR MULTI-FAMILY, COMMERCIAL, AND INDUSTRIAL BUILDINGS
§ 95.10 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ASHES. The residue from the combustion of fuel used for heating.
   GARBAGE. All organic household kitchen wastes, such as rejected or unused
food and food residue, and paper necessarily used for wrapping the same.
   HOUSEHOLD RUBBISH. Inorganic, incombustible household waste such as tin
cans, metal ware, bottles, broken glass, crockery, stoneware, and similar
refuse resulting from the regular operation of a household.
   LITTER. Any discarded, used, or unconsumed substance or waste. The term may
include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish,
grass clippings or other lawn or garden waste, newspapers, magazines, glass,
metal, plastic or paper containers or other packaging construction material,
abandoned vehicles, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, carcasses of dead
animals, nauseous or offensive matter of any kind, objects likely to injure any
person or create a traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly or
unsanitary nature which has been discarded, abandoned, or otherwise disposed of
improperly. (Ord. 1988-O-3, passed 2-2-88)
   MANURE. The excrement of domestic animals and fowl, and stable bedding.
   MISCELLANEOUS RUBBISH. Combustible rubbish or waste resulting from the
operation of a residence, including grass cuttings, but excluding any highly
inflammable material or explosives.
   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company,
corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, or any other
legal entity or their legal representative, agent, or assigns. (Ord. 1988-O-3,
passed 2-2-88)
   SPECIAL RUBBISH. All rubbish not above defined.
('79 Code, § 1202(1))
§ 95.11 REFUSE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to deposit
anywhere in the village any uncovered pile of refuse, garbage, offal, or
carcasses of dead animals. Such refuse must be buried at least two feet below
the surface of the ground, buried in properly constructed incinerators, or
otherwise properly disposed of. Any uncovered pile of refuse is hereby declared
to be a nuisance.
('79 Code, § 1205(5)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.12 REMOVAL REQUIRED.
   The owner, occupant, or lessee of any premises in the village shall remove
from the premises or otherwise dispose of all garbage, ashes, rubbish, and
animal fecal material, and shall keep the premises at all times free and clear
of any accumulation of refuse.
('79 Code, § 1202(2)) (Am. Ord. 1999-O-17, passed 6-15-99) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.13 CONTAINERS TO BE PROVIDED.
   The owner, occupant, or lessee of any premises in the village upon which any
garbage, ashes, household rubbish, miscellaneous rubbish, or special rubbish
accumulate shall provide and maintain, clean and in good repair, adequate
separate receptacles of the following material, construction, and capacity:
   (A)   A receptacle for garbage and miscellaneous rubbish shall be a suitable
container with a close- fitting cover. It shall be watertight and provided with
suitable handles for carrying. Each receptacle shall have a capacity of not
less than ten gallons and not more than one yard, and shall be provided by any
owner, occupant, or lessee of any premises.
   (B)   A receptacle for ashes and household rubbish shall be a suitable
container and have a capacity of not less than ten gallons and not more than
one yard, and shall be provided with suitable handles for carrying.
   (C)   A receptacle for special rubbish shall be of adequate strength, shall
have a capacity of not more than three bushels, and shall be provided with
suitable handles for carrying.
   (D)   Receptacles (commonly referred to as "dumpsters") for apartment
buildings, condominiums, and other multiple dwelling units shall meet the
following size requirements:
      Number of Units   Size (Yards)
         (For each additional 5 units, receptacle capacity shall be increased
by 2 yards.)
   (E)   An owner, occupant, or lessee of premises consisting of a single-
family dwelling, duplex, or multiple-dwelling unit having fewer units than the
number specified in division (D) shall be permitted to utilize receptacles
commonly referred to as "dumpsters."
('79 Code, § 1202(3)) (Ord. 1980-O-2, passed 3-4-80) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.14 USE OF CONTAINERS.
   (A)   The occupant or lessee of any premises in the village shall cause all
garbage and nothing except garbage to be deposited in the receptacle or
receptacles provided for garbage; and ashes or household rubbish and nothing
except ashes and household rubbish to be deposited in the receptacle or
receptacles provided for same.
   (B)   The owner, occupant, or lessee of any premises in the village may
dispose of any garbage, ashes, or household rubbish produced on his own
premises when such disposal is accomplished in a manner which does not create a
nuisance or cause annoyance or discomfort to inhabitants of the village.
   (C)   All receptacles shall be placed outside the residence or other
building in an accessible place, at ground level, and at the rear of the
residence or building except that said receptacles may be placed near the
street line within eight hours prior to the day of collection and must be
removed within eight hours after the day of collection.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any garbage, ashes,
or household rubbish in any garbage receptacle belonging to the village.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit garbage, ashes, or
household rubbish in any rubbish container or receptacle commonly referred to
as a "dumpster" not owned, rented, or furnished for his use.
   (F)   Receptacles commonly referred to as "dumpsters" and rubbish containers
used in the village parks shall be used for the deposit of trash from the use
of village parks. No one shall transport any junk or garbage into any village
park for the purpose of using said receptacles for the disposal of their
personal junk or garbage.
('79 Code, § 1202(4)) (Ord. 1983-O-24, passed 10-18-83) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.15 REGULATION OF COLLECTORS.
   The business of collecting and disposing of garbage and rubbish for hire,
and of transporting such over the streets of the village without a permit is
declared to be a nuisance. Such business shall not be carried on by any person
except under the conditions prescribed by the village.
('79 Code, § 1202(5)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.16 DUMPING OF LITTER PROHIBITED.
   (A)   No person shall dump, deposit, drop, throw, discard, leave, cause, or
permit the dumping, depositing, dropping, throwing, discarding, or leaving of
litter upon any public or private property in this village, or upon or into any
river, lake, pond, or other stream or body of water in this village, unless:
      (1)   The property has been designated by the village or any of its
agencies, for the disposal of litter;
      (2)   The litter is placed into a receptacle or other container intended
by the owner or tenant in lawful possession of that property for the deposit of
litter;
      (3)   The person is acting under the direction of proper public officials
during special cleanup days; or
      (4)   The person is lawfully acting in or reacting to an emergency
situation where health and safety is threatened, and removes and properly
disposes of such litter when the emergency situation no longer exists.
   (B)   No person shall allow litter to accumulate upon real property of which
the person charged is the owner or tenant in control, in such a manner as to
constitute a public nuisance or in such a manner that the litter may be blown
or otherwise carried by the natural elements onto the real property of another
person.
('79 Code, § 1202(6)) (Ord. 1988-O-3, passed 2-2-88) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.17 CONSTRUCTION REFUSE.
   Refuse resulting from construction operations including earth, plaster,
metal, tile, brick, concrete, terra cotta, slate, shingles, roofing, tin, iron,
and construction litter in general, shall be removed and disposed of by and at
the expense of the person responsible for its production and in a safe manner.
('79 Code, § 1202(7)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.18 SCREENING REQUIRED.
   All properties subject to the regulations set forth in §§
95.10 through
95.16 shall be required to have opaque screening six feet in height, completely
surrounding the garbage containers, dumpsters, grease bins or other outdoor
waste containers, which screening shall be made of wood, cement block or brick
and include a latching gate with a self-closing device such as spring hinges.
The gate may be constructed of wood or chain-link fencing material equipped
with privacy slats. A wooden privacy fence of the appropriate height shall be
considered to be a sufficient screen. Upon a petition duly presented by the
property owner or business owner, the Village Board shall have the express
ability to grant a variance upon such terms and conditions as may be just and
equitable in the premises.
(Ord. 2007-O-28, passed 10-2-07; Am. Ord. 2008-O-15, passed 7-1-08
Penalty, see § 95.99
GARBAGE DISPOSAL FOR SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCES,
DUPLEXES, AND APARTMENT BUILDINGS
§ 95.20 APPLICABILITY.
   Effective October 1, 2004, all single-family residences, duplexes and
apartment buildings containing four or less units shall be governed by the
provisions set forth in this subchapter. After that date, §§
95.10 through
95.17, inclusive, shall apply only to larger mufti-family buildings, commercial
and industrial buildings and, only to the extent that they do not conflict with
any provision of this subchapter, to all other persons and properties in the
village.
(Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04)
§ 95.21 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CURBSIDE. The approved point of collection which shall be within five feet
of the edge of the paved street.
   GARBAGE. All household and kitchen wastes, such as discarded food or food
residues and paper necessarily used for wrapping same, books, boxes and
cartons, providing all such materials are placed in suitable containers and not
left in piles on the ground, and small amounts of sod, earth and rocks,
provided the last three items listed are put in suitable containers of
reasonable, movable weight. It shall also include do-it-yourself home
remodeling and repair construction materials, and not commercial remodeling and
construction materials, provided the items are put in suitable containers or
bundles of reasonably movable weight.
   RECYCLABLE MATERIAL/MATERIALS. Aluminum cans, tin and/or steel cans, plastic
milk jugs (HDPE), newspaper, glass bottles/containers or other materials
specified by the village, the hauler or the contract.
   RECYCLING CONTAINERS. The container provided by the contract hauler to
residents for the specific purpose of storing recyclable materials on site and
for placing those materials curbside for collection. Exact size, shape and
color of the container may vary from time to time, however, recycling
containers will be clearly marked for use as a recycling container only.
(Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04)
§ 95.22 EXCLUSIVE CONTRACT REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the enterprise of collecting, transporting,
processing, storing or disposing of garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse,
recyclables, landscape waste or solid waste of any kind from any residence,
dwelling, or multi-family residential development of four units or less within
the corporate limits of the village, as the limits exist from time to time,
without first having secured an exclusive contract with the village for such
purposes, consistent with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.23 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   All residents within the village shall comply with all applicable
provisions of the current contract between the village and the village’s
designated single waste hauler, and any extensions or amendments thereto.
   (B)   The contract, as well as any extensions and amendments thereto, is on
file with the Village Clerk and is hereby made part of this subchapter by
reference.
   (C)   Notwithstanding the foregoing, two residences composed entirely of
senior citizens (being persons having reached the age of 65 years) may jointly
combine their garbage from their individual residences and share the expense
thereof, and in such an event, the single waste hauler shall only bill and
receive compensation for one residential service.
   (D)   A further exception is made for residents who leave their homes on
extended vacations. In the event any residence is vacated by its residents for
a period of more than 30 days in a row, that owner or occupant of that
residence may so notify the single waste hauler in advance and in writing and
this shall cause the hauler to suspend service to that residence. No charges
shall be billed to the residence for any period of suspension pursuant to this
division.
(Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.24 RECYCLING PROGRAM ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is hereby established a voluntary village-wide residential
recycling program to be operated by the village's exclusive single waste hauler
to provide for the separation of certain designated recyclable materials from
normal household refuse for placement in specially designated containers
provided by the single waste hauler. The respective approved containers for
recyclables and landscape waste shall be used only for the purpose of storing
the materials on site and for the placement of those materials curbside.
   (B)   Recycling containers shall be stored on the residential premises in
conformance with the provisions of this chapter and may be placed at the
designated location for collection only during the times specified in this
chapter.
   (C)   Once recyclable materials have been placed in or alongside the
container and set at the curb or other designated collection location, the
materials become the property of the village and the contract hauler, and it
shall be unlawful for any other person to move, remove or tamper with
recyclables or landscape waste and each act of moving, removing and/or
tampering in violation hereof from one or more locations shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense punishable as provided in this chapter.
   (D)   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter:
      (1)   Any person may donate recyclables and landscape waste to any other
person whether operating for profit or not for profit; and
      (2)   Any person may maintain his own compost pile or site so long as
such site or pile neither constitutes a nuisance to surrounding property owners
nor endangers the public health or safety.
(Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.25 COLLECTION.
   No garbage, recyclables, landscape waste or any refuse whether or not in the
proper container, shall be placed on any portion of any public or private road,
street or alley, or within 25 feet thereof, earlier than 24 hours prior to the
scheduled time and date for the pickup of such garbage, recyclables or
landscape waste for the premises; and any garbage, recyclables or landscape
waste placed earlier than as aforesaid is hereby declared to be a public
nuisance. The nuisance may be abated at the direction of the Mayor and the
removal of the nuisance shall be at the expense of the owner and resident of
the premises in question who shall be jointly liable.
(Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04) Penalty, see
95.99
OTHER HEALTH AND SANITATION REGULATIONS
§ 95.30 CEMETERIES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to establish a
cemetery or to bury any person within the village limits or within one mile
thereof without a permit therefor from the Board of Trustees.
('79 Code, § 1205(6)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.31 FOOD SANITATION REGULATIONS.
   (A)   All premises used for the sale or storage of food or drink intended
for human consumption shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall
be unlawful to permit any person who is afflicted with a contagious disease to
handle any food or drink intended for sale. Such premises shall be kept free
from flies and vermin at all times. ('79 Code, § 1205(2))
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, any unwholesome or
polluted food or drink of any kind intended or polluted food or drink of any
kind intended for human consumption, in the village. ('79 Code, § 1205(1))
Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.32 STAGNANT POOLS.
   Any stagnant pool of water in the village is hereby declared to be a
nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to permit
any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under its control.
('79 Code, § 1205(4)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.33 PRIVATE PROPERTY OR BUILDING AS HEALTH NUISANCE.
   It shall be unlawful to permit any building, structure, or place to remain
in such a condition as to be dangerous to the public health in any way. Any
such structure, building, or place is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
('79 Code, § 1205(7)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.34 OBSTRUCTION OR POLLUTION OF WATERCOURSES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation to
obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the village.
('79 Code, § 1205(3)) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.35 ENDANGERING PUBLIC HEALTH IN ANY MANNER PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to commit or do any act which endangers the
public health or results in annoyance or discomfort to the public. ('79 Code, §
1205(8))
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to permit or maintain the existence of any
nuisance on any premises controlled or occupied by any person, firm, or
corporation in the village. The Board of Health, Health Officer, and any member
of the Police Department are hereby authorized to abate any nuisance existing
in the village, whether such nuisance is one specifically recognized as such by
this chapter or other ordinance or not. A nuisance shall include, but shall not
be limited to the allowing or suffering of any ditch, drain, excavation, or
hole in, across, or under any public street, alley, sidewalk, or other place or
lot not to be refilled with all reasonable dispatch so that such street, alley,
sidewalk, or place or lot remains a hazard to children and all persons who may
pass by or may be attracted to said ditch, drain, excavation, or hole.
('79 Code, § 1205(9)) Penalty, see §
95.99
ABATEMENT PROCEDURE
§ 95.45 NOTICE TO ABATE.
   In addition to the penalty provided for in §
95.99, if any nuisance is not abated within five days after notice in writing
by the Board of Health, Health Officer, or any member of the Police Department
duly served on the owner, tenant, agent, or person having control of the
premises, the said Board of Health, Health Officer, or member of the Police
Department may cause said nuisance to be abated. Service of the notice may be
effected by handing the same to the owner, tenant, or agent in person wherever
they may be, or to any member of their household of the age of 15 years or
upwards found on the premises, or by mailing the same by United States mail,
postage fully prepaid, addressed to the owner if known, or if not known, to the
last taxpayer of record as it appears on the records of the County Treasurer.
('79 Code, § 1205(10))
§ 95.46 ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE; LIEN.
   (A)   The Board of Health, Health Officer, or member of the Police
Department shall keep an accurate record of expenses incurred in abating the
nuisance on each parcel of real estate and this expense shall become a lien
upon the real estate effected. The lien shall be superior to all other liens
and encumbrances except tax liens. Within 60 days after incurring the expense
of abating the nuisance, the Board of Health, Health Officer, or member of the
Police Department shall file a notice of lien in the office of the County
Recorder of Deeds. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out:
      (1)   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification
thereof;
      (2)   The amount of money representing the cost or expense incurred and
payable for the services; and
      (3)   The day and date when the expense was incurred by the village.
   (B)   After notice of lien is filed with the County Recorder of Deeds, the
expense shall be a lien upon the real estate described therein from and after
its recording until it is released as provided by law.
('79 Code, § 1205(10))
COMPREHENSIVE FIRE AND BURNING REGULATIONS
§ 95.50 PURPOSE.
   The village recognizes the traditional burning of leaves and other clean
material, and also the health rights of those affected by inhalation of smoke
and ash as well as the danger from uncontrolled fire and burning of certain
noxious materials, in accordance with the Lake County Department of Health, the
Illinois Environmental Protection Act, Illinois Administrative Code and the
BOCA National Fire Prevention Code.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02)
§ 95.51 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply,
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AGRICULTURAL WASTE. Any refuse, except garbage and dead animals, generated
on a farm or ranch by crop and livestock production practices including such
items as bags, cartons, dry bedding, structural materials and trade residues
but excluding landscape waste.
   CLEAN WOOD. The wooden remains of a building, trees, branches, stumps and
split firewood.
   DOMICILE WASTE. Any refuse generated on single-family domiciliary property
as a result of domiciliary activities. The term excludes landscape waste,
garbage and trade waste.
   GARBAGE. Refuse resulting from the handling, processing, preparation,
cooking and consumption of or food preparation.
   GRASS FIRE. A fire which covers a broad area, including fields, scrub areas
or woodlands which is not centralized on a particular pile of combustible
materials.
   LANDSCAPE WASTE. Any vegetable or plant refuse, except garbage and
agricultural waste. The term includes weeds, leaves, grass, shrubbery and yard
trimmings.
   TRADE WASTE. Any refuse resulting from the prosecution of any trade,
business, industry, commercial venture, utility or service activity and any
government or institutional activity, whether or not for profit. The term
includes landscape waste but excludes agricultural waste.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02)
§ 95.52 GENERAL PROHIBITION.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to light or maintain any fire in the village
except in accordance with the provisions in this subchapter. The term fire as
used herein shall not be construed to mean or include a fire in a furnace,
stove or fireplace or other container designed for the burning of approved
materials.
   (B)   Notwithstanding any provision herein, it shall be unlawful to light or
maintain any fire in the village so close to any building or structure, or any
flammable material other than that to be burned so as to cause a fire hazard or
the emission of thick, black smoke or release into the air particles of ash.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.53 GRASS FIRE REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No person shall set any grass fire in the village without first
obtaining a permit from the Fire Chief.
   (B)   Permits:
      (1)   The Fire Chief may, in his sole discretion, issue a permit for a
grass fire upon an application from a village resident or landowner, and in
determining whether or not to issue the permit, the Fire Chief may, but is not
required to, consider the scope of the planned burn, the availability of fire
hydrants, ponds or other sources of water, the weather conditions, the number
of persons the resident or landowner may have available to tend the fire, the
reason why the resident or landowner wishes to set the fire and available
alternatives thereto, the available manpower in the Fire Department at the time
proposed for the fire, any other permits issued for the same time as proposed
and any other factors which could lead to an unmanageable fire being set.
      (2)   In issuing such a permit, the Fire Chief may set the specific time
and date upon which the fire may be maintained and any other conditions he may
deem necessary or desirable to prevent the spread of such a fire and to ensure
the public safety.
      (3)   Where a permit has been issued, the Fire Chief shall have the sole
discretion to cancel such a permit without prior notice to the permitee if
weather conditions, manpower or the like shall indicate the existence of
altered conditions that may make the spread of the fire likely.
   (C)   Any person setting a grass fire with or without first having obtained
a permit from the Fire Chief shall be liable for all costs incurred by the Fire
Department in extinguishing any fire which becomes unmanageable or grows out of
control.
   (D)   Any person setting a grass fire with or without first having obtained
a permit from the Fire Chief shall be liable in a civil action to the owner of
any property destroyed or damaged by such a fire.
   (E)   Nothing herein shall make the Fire Chief or the village liable to any
person for a grass fire, whether set pursuant to a permit or not.
   (F)   Any person setting a grass fire without first obtaining a permit from
the Fire Chief shall be punished as provided for in §
95.99.
   (G)   In the absence of the Fire Chief, the next ranking officer of the Fire
Department or the specifically designated Acting Chief shall have all the
powers of the Fire Chief described in this section.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.54 PROHIBITED BURNING.
   The following activities are specifically prohibited:
   (A)   The burning of landscape waste, trash, rubbish or construction debris
(other than clean wood) is prohibited. Materials such as, but not limited to,
hazardous materials, asphalt, animal carcasses, manure, rubber, asbestos and
asbestos materials, roofing, treated wood and lumber, tires, skids, plastic
materials, batteries, paint and other solvent containers, plastic containers,
other materials producing noxious odors and/or black smoke, shall not be burned
at any time.
   (B)   No burning shall occur on a public street, sidewalk or within a right-
of-way.
   (C)   Cardboard and other paper products may not be burned in any
residentially zoned area, provided, however that the products may be burned by
commercial establishments in business or industrial districts, but only under
the following conditions:
      (1)   The burning shall be within an approved incinerator stove, furnace
or fireplace or metal drum designed and constructed as set forth below so as to
prevent the escape of ignited particles or burning material therefrom.
      (2)   As it is preferred that commercial establishments recycle paper and
cardboard rather than burning, therefore, only when recycling is not available
and the establishment's storage bins are full may a commercial establishment
burn cardboard and paper products.
      (3)   The area in which the incinerator to be used is located shall have
a surface of gravel, cinders, cement or similar non-combustible material and
this area shall extend at least five feet from each side of the approved
burning container.
      (4)   The burning shall be done in an incinerator no larger than five
feet in width and not more than five feet in height. It shall be constructed of
steel or firebrick. The top of the incinerator shall be equipped with a spark
arrestor or screen having openings of not more than ¾-inch.
   (D)   Site and weather restrictions:
      (1)   No burning of any kind shall be allowed on a day or evening when
the wind is predicted to be in excess of 10 miles per hour, by the National
Weather Service or within 48 hours after a rain totaling ¼ inch or more, as
reported by the National Weather Service.
      (2)   All burning permitted herein shall be extinguished and put out
before the attendant leaves the burn area or when the wind, smoke or ash make
such fire dangerous or likely to emit noxious fumes and smoke.
      (3)   A hose or other sufficient extinguisher device shall always be
readily available.
      (4)   No burning shall create a visibility hazard on streets and
roadways.
      (5)   No fire shall be lit within 30 feet of any building or structure or
within 10 feet of a fence or property line.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02; Am. Ord. 2004-O-15, passed 9-7-04) Penalty, see
§
95.99
§ 95.55 BONFIRES AND CAMPFIRES.
   This chapter is not intended to prohibit a controlled burn under adult
supervision, and after notice to the Police Department, of clean wood and
materials, other than those prohibited above, for an occasional gathering of
neighbors, block party, school groups, scout and other legally recognized
organizations, or for a special event such as a charitable fund raising
activity. Such a burn may be after sunset but must be extinguished by 11:00
p.m. The pile of materials to be burned may not exceed 5 feet x 5 feet x 5
feet, the fire must not be closer than 30 feet to any building or structure,
and the area surrounding the fire must be non-combustible.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02; Am. Ord. 12-O-11, passed 6-5-12) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.56 CITIZEN COMPLAINTS.
   Upon the complaint of any village resident that a burning in progress may be
a violation of this chapter, the Village Police Department will investigate as
soon as possible and if it appears that such burning is a violation of the
chapter, will order the fire to be extinguished immediately and, if necessary,
call the Fire Department to do so.
(Ord. 2002-O-8, passed 3-5-02)
