CHAPTER 96: NOISE
Section
   
96.01   Excessive noise prohibited
   
96.02   Exceptions
 
   
96.99   Penalty
Cross-reference:
   Noisy animals, see §
90.03
§ 96.01 EXCESSIVE NOISE PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Vehicles.  No person shall play, use, operate or permit to be played,
used or operated, any radio, tape recorder, cassette player, compact disc
player, MP3 player IPOD or other device for receiving broadcast sound or
reproducing recorded sound if the device is located on the public way or in any
motor vehicle on the public way if the sound generated by the device is audible
at a distance of 75 feet or more from the device.
   (B)   On public property.  No person, for purposes of entertainment or
communication may generate any sound by any means that it is audible at a
distance 100 feet or greater from the point of generation.
   (C)   On private property.  No person, for purposes of entertainment or
communication may generate any sound by any means that it is audible at a
distance 100 feet or greater from the property line of the private property
where the sound is generated.
(Ord. 2015-O-22, passed 10-6-15) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.02 EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to any of the following:
   (A)   Sound generated in conjuncture with a village-sponsored event;
   (B)   A person participating in a parade, public assembly or athletic event
for which, a special event permit has been obtained from the village;
   (C)   An emergency warning device or alarm sounded for emergency purposes;
   (D)   Sound generated between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. in
construction, demolition or repair work;
   (E)   Sound generated in construction, demolition or repair work of an
emergency nature or in work on public improvements authorized by a governmental
body or agency;
   (F)   Sound generated by church bells.
(Ord. 2015-O-22, passed 10-6-15)
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   Refer to the chart of fines set forth in §
39.07 of this code.
(Ord. 2015-O-22, passed 10-6-15)
CHAPTER 97: OUTDOOR EVENTS AND ASSEMBLIES
Section
   
97.01   Permit required; exceptions
   
97.02   Application; fee; insurance
   
97.03   Police investigation; report
   
97.04   Issuance of permit; conditions
   
97.05   Appeal procedure
   
97.06   Revocation; refund; notice
   
97.07   Periodic permits
 
   
97.99   Penalty
§ 97.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   No person, partnership, corporation, organization, or group shall
promote, advertise, operate, conduct, or participate in any public or quasi-
public exhibition, demonstration, show, festival, parade, similar planned
event, or other outdoor assembly of persons, which is directly or indirectly
advertised or touted in the public press, radio, or television, or to which
large numbers of people are directly or indirectly invited to attend, unless
the person, partnership, corporation, organization, or group promoting,
advertising, operating, or conducting the same shall first have obtained a
permit from the Village Clerk.
   (B)   This chapter shall not apply to the following:
      (1)   Funeral processions proceeding by vehicle under the most reasonable
route from the funeral home, church, or residence of the deceased to the place
of interment.
      (2)   A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions.
('79 Code, § 1918(1)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87) Penalty, see §
97.99
§ 97.02 APPLICATION; FEE; INSURANCE.
   (A)   Written application for such a permit shall be made to the Village
Clerk not less than 20 days nor more than 60 days prior to the event for which
the permit is requested. Together with the application the applicant shall, in
typewritten form, submit the following information:
      (1)   The proposed location and the portion of the premises available for
such event.
      (2)   The reasonable projected number of persons who will attend such
outdoor event and the basis of such projection.
      (3)   A specific description of the nature of the assembly and the number
and, where
available, the names of the exhibitors, demonstrators, or other persons invited
by or under contract with the applicant in connection with the proposed event.
      (4)   Annexed to such application shall be the written permission of the
record owner or owners of the premises intended to be used or, if the same is
owned by this state, Lake County, or any other governmental unit or school
board, then the written permission of the officer or agent having authority to
permit the use of such premises as they are intended to be used.
   (B)   The applicant shall pay to the Village Clerk a permit fee of $25 per
application.
   (C)   The applicant shall submit to the Village Clerk with the application:
      (1)   A written commitment from a responsible insurance company, licensed
to do business in Illinois, to insure the applicant and the village as a co-
insured during such event, on a single limit policy, in the amount of $500,000;
or
      (2)   Where it shall appear that the nature or size of the event or the
existence of other applicable insurance will not reasonably require the limits
hereinabove related, the President may fix such lesser limits or accept such
evidence of other insurance or financial responsibility as will reasonably
afford protection to the participants and the public; or
      (3)   Where it shall appear that no insurance can be reasonably obtained
by the applicant, the President shall require that all persons who desire to
participate in a proposed event duly execute and submit to the Village Clerk no
later than 72 hours prior to the event, a release and hold-harmless agreement,
which shall read as follows:
   "Hold-Harmless Indemnification Agreement"
   I,       (name)        of     (address)     , City of       , County of
               , State of               plan to participate in  (name of event,
parade, demonstration, etc.   , scheduled to take place on   (date)     ,
within the municipal limits of the Village of Winthrop Harbor, Illinois.
   I hereby assume the risk for any personal injuries or property damages that
I may sustain in the pursuit of my activities while participating in the above-
specified event and do hereby hold harmless, remise, release, and forever
discharge, the Village of Winthrop Harbor, its agents and employees, from any
and all actions, suits, damages, claims or judgments that may result from any
personal injuries or property damages I may sustain while participating in
(name of event)                 on    (date)      .
   Further, I shall be liable and shall indemnify the Village of Winthrop
Harbor and/or its agents for any injury or loss sustained by a third party,
which results from my conduct or participation in the above-specified event.
   IN WITNESS WHEREOF I have executed this Release/Hold-Harmless Agreement at
  (designate place of execution)   on               , 19  .
                                                                     
                           (Signature of Participant)
   Subscribed and sworn to before me
   this            day of      , 19  .
                                                     
   Notary Public
('79 Code, § 1918(2)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87) Penalty, see §
97.99
§ 97.03 POLICE INVESTIGATION; REPORT.
   (A)   The Village Clerk shall, upon receipt of the application, refer the
same immediately to the Police Department in order that it might complete and
submit to the Village Clerk and President an investigative report and
recommendations.
   (B)   The Police Department shall cause to be investigated and shall report
upon the following:
      (1)   The background of the applicant and the factual accuracy of the
application.
      (2)   The extent to which the proposed outdoor assembly may adversely
affect the health, safety, or welfare of the persons attending the same or the
health, safety, or welfare of the persons in the community.
      (3)   Such other matters as may reasonably be required by the nature and
size of the proposed event or as may be directed by the Village Clerk.
   (C)   The report of the Police Department shall contain written
recommendations and the reasons therefor. Said report shall be filed with the
Village Clerk and the President within ten days after receipt of the
application for a permit and shall be available for inspection by the applicant
or his attorney.
('79 Code, § 1918(3)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87)
§ 97.04 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; CONDITIONS.
   The President shall, upon consideration of the application and the report
submitted pursuant to §
97.03, together with any additional information, grant the permit for which
application is made, subject, however, to the following:
   (A)   Each permit shall contain such written conditions as are reasonable
and appropriate to the nature and size of the proposed event so as to insure
the public health, morals, safety, and welfare.
   (B)   No permit shall be issued unless a certified copy of the applicant's
liability insurance policy, or other required evidence of financial
responsibility, shall have been filed with the Village Clerk or President.
   (C)   No permit shall be issued unless the full permit fee required by §
97.02, shall have been paid to the Clerk.
   (D)   The President may require of the applicant, prior to the issuance of a
permit, a cash deposit in an amount sufficient to insure prompt repair of
physical damage and collection of refuse when the event is to take place in a
public street, park, playground, or other public facility. Such a cash deposit
shall, as well, be sufficient to pay for such special police officers and like
personnel as may reasonably be required by the event and for which the Village
Clerk shall bill the applicant- permittee.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful to participate in any manner in any parade,
procession, march, or demonstration between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00
a.m.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person participating in any event
described in §
97.01, to wear a mask, hood, or any other article of clothing which conceals
the identity of the participant.
('79 Code, § 1918(4)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87) Penalty, see §
97.99
§ 97.05 APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   Upon a denial by the President of an application made pursuant to §
97.02, the applicant may appeal from the determination of the President within
five days thereafter to the Village Board of Trustees by filing a written
notice of appeal for hearing by the Board at its next meeting. Upon such
appeal, the Board of Trustees may reverse, affirm, or modify in any regard the
determination made by the President by majority vote.
('79 Code, § 1918(5)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87)
§ 97.06 REVOCATION; REFUND; NOTICE.
   (A)   A permit may be revoked by the President upon 24 hours' notice to the
applicant-permittee where it appears that:
      (1)   The application is materially false or purposely misleading and
such fact was not earlier discovered despite due diligence prior to such time.
      (2)   New or substantially changed conditions have arisen so as to
imperil or materially endanger the public health, morals, safety, or welfare.
If a permit is revoked for the reason denominated in this division (2), the
applicant's permit fee shall be returned to him.
   (B)   A permit may be revoked at any time after 24 hours prior to the event
and at any time during such event where it appears that the public health,
morals, safety, or welfare are being endangered, where it appears that numerous
acts of criminality, disorderly conduct, or juvenile delinquency are occurring,
or where nuisances substantially impairing the comfort or welfare of the
community are occurring. Where such circumstances appear, a permit shall be
revoked upon request of the Police Department by the President, or in the
absence of the foregoing, by the Police Department. In the event of revocation
under this division, the permit fee and the cash deposit, to the extent the
latter is billed, used, or required, shall not be returned to the applicant-
permittee.
   (C)   In the event that a permit is revoked pursuant to division (A) of this
section, oral notice by the President to the applicant-permittee shall be
determined sufficient notice to the applicant-permittee and his agents,
servants, employees, and contractees that the permit has been revoked. In the
event that a permit is revoked pursuant to division (B) of this section, oral
notice, audible to any individual and oral notice reasonably audible to any
person within normal hearing range of any electronic device, given by an
authorized official or police officer, shall be deemed sufficient notice that
the permit has been revoked.
('79 Code, § 1918(6)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87) Penalty, see §
97.99  
§ 97.07 PERIODIC PERMITS.
   (A)   Any applicant who shall have obtained a permit for an event which is
commonly held at annual or other periodic intervals shall, once having obtained
such permit, be entitled to renew the same, without fee, upon the same
conditions as are contained in the original permit by notifying the Village
Clerk, in writing, not less than 20 days nor more than 60 days prior to the
event for which the permit is requested, and submitting with such notification,
evidence of financial responsibility and the fulfillment of such other
conditions as may theretofore have been required.
   (B)   The application for renewal shall be granted by the President unless a
bona fide complaint concerning the past operation of such event by the
applicant or new or changed circumstances or a different mode of operation by
the applicant have been brought to the attention of the President. Where such
matters are brought to the attention of the President, he shall hold a hearing
upon notice to the applicant and may thereafter grant the application for
renewal, impose new or different conditions upon the applicant, or deny the
application, as the evidence adduced at the hearing shall warrant.
('79 Code, § 1918(7)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87)
§ 97.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, partnership, corporation, organization, or group who shall
promote, advertise, operate, conduct, or participate in any event described in
§
97.01 for which no permit has been duly issued, or where required has failed to
file an executed "Hold-Harmless Indemnification Agreement" as described in §
97.02 shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $500. Each
day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall
constitute a separate offense.
   (B)   Any person, partnership, corporation, organization, or group who has
been notified of the revocation of a permit pursuant to the provisions of §
97.06 and thereafter promotes, advertises, operates, conducts, or participates
in any event described in §
97.01 shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $500. Each
day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall
constitute a separate offense.
   (C)   Any person who has been notified of the revocation of a permit
pursuant to the provisions of §
97.06 and who has been requested by a police officer to quit the premises or
who obstructs, hinders, or delays the quitting of himself or others shall, upon
conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $500.
   (D)   Any person, partnership, corporation, organization, or group who
violates any other provision of this chapter, including the submission of a
false or materially misleading application, shall, upon conviction, be punished
by a fine of not more than $500. Each day any violation of any provision of
this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
('79 Code, § 1918(8)) (Ord. 1987-O-6, passed 1-20-87)

§ 98.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known as the "Parks Chapter of Winthrop Harbor" and
may be so cited and referred to.
§ 98.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUTHORIZED VILLAGE OFFICIAL. The Village Clerk or the Chief of Police of the
village.
   PARK. The following park areas in the village: North Prairie Park, Novotny
Park, Fossland Park, Broadway Field, Paxton Park, Village Park, the Garrett-
Langvad Community Center and its adjacent grounds, and the recreational grounds
to the north of the Winthrop Harbor Fire Station.
('79 Code, § 2001) (Ord. 1979-O-26, passed 6-19-79)
   PARK REGULATIONS
§ 98.10 ADVERTISING; POSTING NOTICES.
   (A)   No person shall display any placard or advertisement of any kind in
any park; nor shall any person distribute, cast, throw, or place any handbill,
pamphlet, circular, advertisement, or notice of any kind; nor post, stencil, or
otherwise affix any notice or bills, advertisements, or other papers upon any
structure or thing in or about any park except as herein provided.
('79 Code, § 2002)
   (B)   No person shall post or otherwise affix any bills, notices, or other
paper upon any trees or shrubs within any park, street, or public grounds
within the village.
('79 Code, § 1002(9)) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.11 BIRDS AND ANIMALS.
   No person shall trap, catch, wound, kill, or treat cruelly, or attempt to
trap, catch, wound, or kill any bird or animal or molest or rob any nest of any
bird or animal in any park.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.12 DOGS AND CATS.
   No person shall bring a dog or cat within the park system unless on leash.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.13 RIDING ANIMALS.
   No person shall lead or allow to be loose upon park property any horse,
pony, or other riding animal except in areas designated for riding and by
written permission of an authorized village official. Any animal found within
the park system in violation of this section may be apprehended; removed to an
animal shelter, public pound, or any other place provided for that purpose; and
impounded, all at the expense of the owner.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.14 BEGGING.
   No person shall beg or solicit money or contributions of any kind for any
purpose within the park system except such organizations as have received
written permission from an authorized village official.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.15 CAMPING.
   No person shall place, erect, or use any hammock, swing, tent, or shelter or
otherwise camp or sleep in the park system except such organizations as have
received written permission from an authorized village official.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.16 CLOSING HOURS.
   The parks shall be closed from 10:00 p.m. prevailing time in the evening
until daybreak the following morning except at parks having lighted athletic
facilities where the closing hour is 11:00 p.m., and in neighborhood or
community recreation centers as specified herein. No person or property of any
kind shall remain in the parks after closing hours unless permission has been
granted by an authorized village official.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.17 CLOTHING.
   No person shall enter or remain in the park system unless properly and
decently clothed. This shall include suitable covering of the upper portion of
the body except as permitted at beaches.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.18 DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
   No person shall make, aid, countenance, or assist in making any loud,
unusual, or improper noise, threat, fight, disturbance, nuisance, breach of the
peace, or disturbance of the peace and quiet in the park system, or be guilty
of any disorderly conduct therein, or collect with other persons, in bodies or
in crowds, for unlawful purposes, or for any purpose to the annoyance,
obstruction, or disturbance of other persons or lawful assemblage.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.19 EXCAVATION.
   No person shall excavate or take soil, plants, flowers, shrubs, or other
property of any kind from the park system under the jurisdiction of the
village, except by written permission from an authorized village official.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.20 FIRES.
   (A)   No person shall light or make use of any fire in the park system
except at such places as may be established for such purpose and then only
under such rules as may be prescribed therefor. Every fire shall be
continuously under the care and direction of a competent person from the time
it is kindled until it is completely extinguished. ('79 Code, § 2002)
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to start a fire of any kind in the Village Park
without a permit for the same. ('79 Code, § 1002(10))
Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.21 GAMES AND SPORTS.
   (A)   No person shall engage in any sport, game, or amusement in the park
system except at such places and times as may be designated by the park and
then only under such rules as are prescribed. Further, no person shall walk,
remain, or conduct himself upon such portion of the park system designated for
any particular game, sport, or amusement in such a way as to interfere with the
use of such portion by persons who are using the same for the particular sport,
game, or amusement for which it has been designated.
   (B)   No person shall engage in any activity in a rough or reckless manner
so as to endanger, injure, or damage persons or property in any way.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.22 IMPROPER BEHAVIOR.
   No person shall use any abusive, threatening, profane, indecent, or obscene
language, or language calculated to occasion a breach of the peace; induce,
commit, or perform any indecent or obscene act or behavior; or exhibit,
possess, or transfer indecent or obscene pictures, writings, or articles of any
kind within the park system.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.23 COMMUNITY CENTER RESTRICTIONS.
   No alcoholic beverages shall be served or consumed in the park buildings or
park grounds unless specifically authorized, after application, by the Liquor
Commissioner of the village, and in conformance with the general regulations
for issuing licenses and permits as set forth in Chapter 110.13(J).
('79 Code, § 2002) (Ord. 1982-O-28, passed 12-7-82; Am. Ord. 1996-O-8, passed
6-17-96) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.24 DRUGS.
   No person under the influence of narcotic drugs shall enter, be, or remain
in the park system, nor shall any person being within possess, sell, or
transfer any narcotic drug in any part of the park system in the village.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.25 MINORS; PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   No parent, guardian, or custodian of a minor shall permit or allow such
minor to do any act in the park system in violation of any law, ordinance, or
rule of the parks, and they shall use their best efforts to prevent any such
violation.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
Cross-reference:
   General license/permit requirements, see
Chapter 120
§ 98.26 PICNICS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for persons to assemble in or upon the Village
Park or the Community Center building except according to the rules established
by the Village Board and the Recreational Director. No person shall scatter,
throw, or deposit any paper, food, or waste material upon the grounds of the
park or in the Community Center.
('79 Code, § 1002(6))
   (B)   Picnics requiring fires may only be held in those areas where
fireplaces, stoves, or pits have been provided for that purpose, and upon
issuance of a permit by the park.
   (C)   Picnic permits required under division (B) shall be issued to groups
or organizations who conduct the business of their organization within the
village. Permits shall be issued to individuals or family groups who are
predominantly village residents up to 50 in number. In the case of the latter
group exceeding 50 in number, approval must be given by an authorized village
official. All permits are subject to divisions (B) and (D).
   (D)   Individuals or organizations holding permits and dispensing food, soft
drinks, dairy products and confections, or any products may do so only in the
area designated by an authorized village official. In the event the dispensing
of the aforementioned products is by sale, they may only be sold to the members
of the organization attending the function and not to the general public except
by written permit from an authorized village official.
   (E)   Village residents under 15 in number may picnic without a permit at
parks or grounds provided they are not violating division (B) and (D).
   (F)   Events sponsored by the parks in conjunction with their supervised
recreation program shall be exempt from the aforementioned restrictions.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
Cross-reference:
   General license/permit requirements, see
Chapter 120
§ 98.27 DAY CAMPS AND SIMILAR GROUPS.
   No person or organization shall bring or cause to be brought into the park
system any play class, day camp, or other organized group of any kind,
organized for profit except with the written permission of the village. Not-
for-profit agency day camps, play classes, or organized groups may use
facilities of the park with the written permission of an authorized village
official.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.28 PROTECTION OF PROPERTY; REWARD.
   (A)   No person shall mark, injure, damage, destroy, or take in any way park
plants or property of any kind, or any property of others in the park system,
or otherwise interfere with the use of the park system by the public. No person
shall bring any plant or portion of a plant onto the park system. No person
shall remove, pour, or otherwise discharge any injurious or vile substance upon
waters, grounds, or property of any kind in the park system. No person shall
climb upon any plants, fence, structure, or property of any kind in the park
system, except such recreational equipment as may be installed by the village
for such purpose.
   (B)   The village may give rewards to the person or persons (other than
police officers or employees of the park) who furnish information to the
village directly resulting in the arrest and conviction of anyone who
unlawfully takes, damages, or destroys park property. All claims for said
reward must be made to the village within 30 days after conviction, and the
village shall be the sole judge of any dispute arising over the reward and the
person or persons, if any, entitled to share therein. The decision of the
village on any matter connected with the reward shall be final and conclusive.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.29 PUBLIC MEETINGS.
   No person or organization of any kind shall call or hold any public meeting,
exhibition, or entertainment of any kind within the park system unless
permitted by the village. Payment of expenses and indemnification of the park
may be required.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
Cross-reference:
   General license/permit requirements, see
Chapter 120
§ 98.30 REFUSE AND GARBAGE.
   No person shall deposit or leave any garbage, refuse, or other material of
any kind on the park system grounds or waters. Paper, glass, cans, garbage, and
other refuse of any kind resulting from picnics or other proper use of the park
system shall be deposited only in receptacles provided for that purpose, and no
person shall litter, suffer, or cause the park system to be littered in any
way.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.31 SKATING AND SLEDDING.
   No person shall skate, sled, toboggan, ski, slide, or carry on other similar
activity in the park system except at such places and times as the park may
designated for the purpose. No person, while engaged in such an activity, shall
conduct himself in such a manner as to annoy others or to endanger, injure, or
damage persons or property in any way.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.32 WEAPONS AND MISSILES.
   (A)   No person shall bring, carry, or use in any way, knives, firearms, or
other weapons of any kind, or any fireworks or other explosive substances of
any kind in the park system. No person shall throw, cast, or shoot stones,
arrows, or other missiles of any kind within the park system, except at such
places and times as the park may designate for such purposes. No person shall
carry or transport any weapon or missile in any vehicle in the park.
   (B)   This section shall not apply to police officers or members of the
armed services while performing official business in the park.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.33 BASEBALL AND SOFTBALL PLAYING.
   (A)   No person shall engage in games of softball and baseball except in
those parks which have established diamonds and backstops constructed for that
purpose.
   (B)   In those parks having established diamonds, participation in softball
or baseball in areas other than the established diamonds is limited in
accordance with signs or notices posted.
   (C)   In those parks having established softball or baseball diamonds, the
type of participation on said diamonds may be regulated in accordance with
posted signs or notices.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.34 HAWKING, PEDDLING, OR SOLICITING.
   No person shall offer or exchange for sale any article or thing; do any
hawking, peddling, or soliciting; buy or offer to buy an article or thing; or
do any soliciting, taking up any collections, or receiving contributions of
money or anything of value in the park system except as herein permitted or
when authorized to do so by permit from a contract with the Board of Trustees.
('79 Code, § 2002) Penalty, see §
98.99
Cross-reference:
   General license/permit requirements, see
Chapter 120
§ 98.35 REMOVAL OF SAND, GRAVEL, AND SIMILAR MATERIALS PROHIBITED.
   The removal or taking away of any sand, gravel, clay, earth, soil, stone, or
other material of any kind or nature whatsoever, from any part of the beach
adjoining and abutting on the park, by any person, either as principal or
agent, for any purpose whatsoever other than for village purposes, on order of
the Board of Trustees, is forbidden.
('79 Code, § 1002(8)) Penalty, see §
98.99
TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
§ 98.40 DRIVING OTHER THAN ON ROADWAY PROHIBITED.
   No person shall drive any automobile, truck, motorcycle, or motorized
vehicle within any of the parks of the village except on roadways intended for
such traffic. Park employees in the performance of their duties are exempt from
this section.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.41 DRIVING WHILE INTOXICATED.
   (A)   No person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or
narcotic drugs shall drive any vehicle within the park system.
   (B)   Upon any trial for such offense, in addition to other evidence,
evidence of the amount of alcohol in the person at the time of the act alleged,
as shown by a chemical analysis of his breath, blood, urine, saliva, or other
bodily substances is admissible, and the result of any such analysis shall give
rise to the presumptions set forth in § 47 of the Uniform Act Regulating
Traffic on Highways, approved July 9, 1935 as amended.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.42 RECKLESS DRIVING.
   No person shall drive any vehicle with a willful or wanton disregard for the
safety of persons or property.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.43 NEGLIGENT DRIVING.
   No person shall operate any vehicle upon a parking lot or roadway in the
park system negligently, heedlessly, and without due caution or in a manner so
as to endanger, or be likely to endanger any person or property. All vehicles
shall be driven on the right side of the roadway except on one-way roadways
open to travel whenever possible, or except when carefully passing another
vehicle.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.44 STARTING VEHICLE.
   No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing, or parked unless
and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.45 BACKING.
   The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can be
made without interfering with other traffic and with reasonable safety.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.46 EQUIPMENT.
   No person shall drive, move, or cause or knowingly permit to be driven or
moved, in the park system, any motor vehicle which is in such unsafe condition
as to endanger persons or property, or which does not contain two headlights,
tail lights, brake lights, brakes adequate to control the movement of and to
stop and hold the vehicle, a horn, a muffler to prevent excessive or unusual
noise and annoying smoke, a rear view mirror, windshield wipers, and such other
equipment necessary for the safe operation of the vehicle, all in good working
order and constant operation (except motor bicycles or motor scooters and only
if they meet the other safe driving conditions specified) unless approved by
the President and Board of Trustees.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.47 PEDESTRIANS.
   Every driver of a motor vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian
at any marked crosswalk or within any unmarked crosswalk at any intersection;
and any pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked
crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at any intersection, shall yield the
right-of-way to vehicles upon the roadway. However, every driver of a vehicle
shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrians upon any
roadway, shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary, and shall
execute proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or
incapacitated person upon a roadway.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.48 PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall park or place any vehicle or other property of any
kind within the park system so as to obstruct or interfere with traffic or
travel or endanger the public safety.
   (B)   No person shall park any vehicle in any of the following places,
except where otherwise designated:
      (1)   On lawn areas and grounds;
      (2)   In front of public or private driveways;
      (3)   In any position to block another car legally parked;
      (4)   At any place where official signs prohibiting parking or
prohibiting parking for more than a specified period having been posted by the
park; or
      (5)   Basketball courts, volleyball courts, tennis courts, baseball
fields, or specified play areas (except that parking shall be permitted on the
basketball court located immediately adjacent to the Community Center between
the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on Wednesdays of each and every
week).
('79 Code, § 2003) (Ord. 1980-O-3, passed 4-1-80; Am. Ord. 1989-O-13, passed 5-
16-89 ; Am. Ord. 1992-O-18, passed 8-4-92) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.49 IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES.
   Any vehicle parked or standing within the park system in violation of any
law, ordinance, or rule is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Such
vehicle may be removed and impounded and the owner or person entitled to
possession of the vehicle shall pay all charges and expenses arising out of any
action taken hereunder.
('79 Code, § 2003)
§ 98.50 UNATTENDED MOTOR VEHICLES.
   No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand
unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, and
removing the keys, and when standing upon any perceptible grade, without
effectively setting the brake thereon and turning the front wheels to the curb
or side of the roadway.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.51 PARTIES TO AN OFFENSE.
   (A)   Every person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit, or
aids or abets in the commission of any act declared herewith to be unlawful,
whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons, or as
principal, agent, or accessory, shall be guilty of such offense.
   (B)   It is unlawful for the owner, or any other person employing or
otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle, to request or knowingly permit
operation of such vehicle upon a roadway in the park system in any manner
contrary to this chapter or other applicable law.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.52 PARKING LOTS.
   No person shall park any vehicle in parking lots of the parks beyond the
normal closing hour of the park system of 10:00 p.m. except where an individual
is attending a function where permission has been granted for a later closing
hour by the village and specified herein. In no event shall any car, except
park vehicles, be parked in any parking lot beyond 11:30 p.m.
('79 Code, § 2003) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.53 STATE TRAFFIC DEFINITIONS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE.
   All terms in this subchapter shall have the same meaning as that set forth
in ILCS Ch. 625 (Motor Vehicles).
§ 98.54 SPEED RESTRICTIONS.
   Maximum speed for motor vehicles operating within the village park shall be
the following: Speed limit on Thomas E. Rottmann Memorial Drive shall be 10
miles per hour.
(Ord. 1992-O-18, passed 8-4-92)
§ 98.55 STOP INTERSECTIONS.
   The following area shall be designated as stop intersection: From parking
lots to Thomas E. Rottman Memorial Drive in village park.
(Ord. 1992-O-18, passed 8-4-92)
CONSERVANCY AREAS
§ 98.60 TRESPASS OR ENTRY PROHIBITED.
   No person shall trespass or enter any area or land owned by the village
which is subject to a conservation easement unless such person has obtained the
prior permission of an authorized village official as defined in §
98.01 for the purpose of removing trash or any other unnatural bodies or any
natural bodies as required by sound conservation practices. Any person who
violates any provision of this section shall be fined in accordance with the
provisions of §
98.99.
('79 Code, § 2006) Penalty, see §
98.99
RESERVED USE OF PARK FACILITIES
§ 98.70 RESERVED USE OF PARK FACILITIES.
   Residents of the village shall have the right to apply for a reservation of
certain park facilities owned, operated and maintained by the village. The
following specific regulations of such reservations shall apply in all
instances:
   (A)   Reservations shall be made in writing, upon forms supplied for that
purpose, with the Recreational Director;
   (B)   Reservations shall not be accepted by the Recreational Director when
it appears to the Director that there would be a conflict with any community
activity planned which would require use of the facility;
   (C)   No reservations shall be accepted from any non-resident of this
village, and the Recreational Director shall have the right to refuse any
reservation request which is presented by any person who cannot or will not
provide proper proof of residency;
   (D)   Reservations shall be done on a first-come, first-serve basis, and the
determination of the order of the reservations shall be entirely within the
sole discretion of the Recreational Director;
   (E)   No reservation shall be made for any organization known to the
Recreational Director to discriminate on the basis of race, creed, sex, skin
color, national origin, provided, however, that this provision shall not
prevent a reservation on behalf of a church league or other religious
organization;
   (F)   No organization or individual shall be refused a reservation because
of any religious beliefs, race, creed, sex, skin color or national origin of
that individual or the constituent members of the organization;
   (G)   No organization or group of individuals shall be entitled to priority
in the use of any facility, except for those bona fide community activities
provided for above in division (B);
   (H)   The reservation application shall be accompanied by payment in full of
the appropriate rental fee, as described in the fee schedule on file with the
Village Clerk and the Recreational Director, and which may be amended from time
to time, together with payment in full of the non-refundable service charge;
   (I)   In the event the person or organization desires to withdraw its
reservation, that person or organization shall be entitled to a refund of the
fee paid on the following basis:
      (1)   Thirty days or more prior to the scheduled event: the entire fee
shall be refunded;
      (2)   Less than 30 days prior to the scheduled event: no part of the fee
shall be refunded;
      (3)   In no event shall any part of the non-refundable service charge be
refunded.
   (J)   In the event the person or organization desires to serve alcohol or
intoxicating liquors in connection with his, her or its use of the leased park
facility, that person or organization shall first apply for and obtain a
special event liquor license from the Village Liquor Commissioner, and shall in
all respects abide by the terms of that license.
(Ord. 1997-O-21, passed 10-21-98)
POND FISHING REGULATIONS
§ 98.80 HOURS.
   (A)   In the pond located within Village Park, the hours for fishing shall
be the same as the open hours of the park itself, established by § 98.16
hereinabove.
   (B)   In all other ponds located on property owned or controlled by the
village, hours for fishing shall be from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. year round.
(Ord. 2012-O-15, passed 6-19-12)
§ 98.81 GAME LAWS.
   All rules and regulations of general application throughout the State of
Illinois shall apply to pond fishing, including specifically all licensing
requirements.
(Ord. 2012-O-15, passed 6-19-12)
§ 98.82 CATCH AND RELEASE ONLY.
   Notwithstanding the provisions of §
98.81, it shall be unlawful for any person to remove any person to remove any
fish from any pond located in a public park or on property owned or controlled
by the village.
(Ord. 2012-O-12, passed 6-19-12)

according to the chart of fines set forth at §
39.07 of this code.
