GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 111.01 APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter, except as to licenses and fees, shall apply
to all public shows, theatricals, circuses, and other amusements in the
village, whether licensed specifically in another section of this chapter or
not.
('79 Code, § 1401(1))
§ 111.02 LICENSES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open
to the public and for admission to which a fee is charged without having first
secured a license therefor; provided that the provisions of this section shall
not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by
other sections of this chapter or by other ordinances.
   (B)   Applications for such licenses shall be made to the Village Clerk and
shall comply with the general provisions of the code sections relating to such
applications. Except as otherwise provided, the fee for such licenses shall be:
 
Menageries                       $10 per day
Carnivals                        $50 per day
Concerts                         $10 per day
Exhibitions of inanimate objects $10 per day
Other public shows or amusements $10 per day
 
('79 Code, § 1401(2)) Penalty, §
111.99
§ 111.03 ATHLETIC EXHIBITIONS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to conduct, operate, or exhibit any race between
persons, animals, or vehicles, or any baseball games, boxing or wrestling
match, or any other athletic contest or exhibition for admission to which a fee
is charged without having secured a license therefor. The fee for each license
shall be $10 per day.
   (B)   Sufficient members of the Police Department shall be admitted, free of
charge, to all such exhibitions for the purpose of preserving and maintaining
order.
('79 Code, § 1401(3)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.04 AUDIENCE BEHAVIOR.
   (A)   The audience of any amusement, show, or theatrical shall be orderly
and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful to create or permit a
disturbance at such performance.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other
risks.
('79 Code, § 1401(4)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.05 BUILDING PREMISES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to conduct or hold any public show or theatrical
show in any building or premises which does not comply with the requirements of
the code of this village relating to the construction of buildings.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to conduct or hold any such performance or
exhibition in any place not equipped with adequate exits; and all exits and
such building or place shall be kept free for access and unobstructed with
proper exit signs.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigarette, cigar, or
pipe on or beneath a stage or in a dressing room of any building used as an
assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than 100 people or in which
theatrical shows, amusements, lectures, or other entertainment are offered,
presented, operated, or exhibited, including the Village Council chambers.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of the owner of such premises or of the occupant
in charge to provide and place printed signs on which the words "No Smoking"
shall appear in letters. Two signs shall be on the stage or in the wings
thereof and one in each dressing room.
('79 Code, § 1401(5)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.06 INDECENT SHOWS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to present,
exhibit, or conduct any indecent show, theatrical, motion picture, exhibition,
or other form of public amusement or show.
('79 Code, § 1401(6)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.07 PUBLIC DISTURBANCE.
   It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of any kind
which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or public
disturbance.
('79 Code, § 1401(7)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.08 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Police Department and the Chief of
the Fire Department to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter, and one member of each department shall be admitted free to each
public show, exhibit, or amusement for the purpose of seeing to the enforcement
thereof.
('79 Code, § 1401(9))
GAMING DEVICES AND VENDING MACHINES
§ 111.10 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Every vending machine and gaming device in the village shall be required to
be individually licensed, and each person, firm or corporation that owns any
such device shall be required to obtain a separate distributor’s license prior
to installing or maintaining any such device. All licenses required hereunder
shall be applied for and issued pursuant to
Chapter 120 of this code.
(Ord. 2002-O-45, passed 11-19-02; Am. Ord. 12-O-22, passed 10-16-12)
§ 111.11 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter (consisting of §§
111.10 through
111.14), the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly
indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GAMING DEVICE. For the purposes of this section, a gaming device shall be
considered to be any mechanical, electronic or electrical apparatus or
contrivance which accepts money and provides any intangible service to the
depositor of the money. By way of general description, but not limitation,
gaming  devices include juke boxes, pinball games, bowling games, video poker
games and other similar contrivances. However, nothing herein shall be
construed to define licensed Illinois Lottery machines as regulated gaming
devices hereunder, nor shall any video gaming terminal duly licensed by the
Village Clerk pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 125 of this chapter and the State Gaming Board pursuant to ILCS Ch.
230, Act 40, §§ 1 et seq. be construed to be regulated hereunder, nor shall any
device designed to allow only human to human interactive games, including, by
way of illustration and not limitation, pool tables, billiard tables, snooker
tables, foosball tables and dart boards, be considered to be regulated gaming
devices hereunder.
   VENDING MACHINE. For the purposes of this section, a vending machine shall
be considered to be any mechanical, electronic or electrical apparatus or
contrivance which is not located completely inside of a building which
dispenses any product or tangible thing upon payment of money without other
human intervention, provided however, that no automated gasoline pump shall be
considered to be a vending machine.
(Ord. 2002-O-45, passed 11-19-02; Am. Ord. 12-O-22, passed 10-16-12)
§ 111.12 ILLEGAL DEVICES, MACHINES AND ACTS.
   (A)   Notwithstanding any provision of this section, nothing herein shall be
deemed to legitimize or legalize any device, nor to legitimize or legalize any
use of any device, which is prohibited under any other provision of federal,
state or local law, and the payment of any fee or the granting of any license
upon the application of the device owner shall not estop or bar the village or
any law enforcement authority from exercising its jurisdiction under the law to
remove, disable, confiscate or otherwise assume control over any illegal device
or any device used in an unlawful fashion.
   (B)   Notwithstanding any provision of this section, nothing herein shall be
deemed to authorize the use of vending machines for the sale of prohibited
products, and in particular, no vending machine may be used for the sale of
products containing alcohol, tobacco or other products that may be subject to
age restrictions or other regulatory prohibitions on distribution.
   (C)   Notwithstanding any provision of this section, nothing herein shall be
deemed to authorize the use of vending machines for the sale of products which
require a separate license without that license. By way of example, but not
limitation, such products as prepared food or sandwiches may require county or
state Health Department licenses.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful to use any vending machine or gaming device in a
manner which violates this section or which violates any other provision of
local, state or federal law.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation in actual or
constructive custody or control of any vending machine or gaming device to
permit the use of the machine or device in a manner which violates any
provision of this section or which violates any other provision of local, state
or federal law.
(Ord. 2002-O-45, passed 11-19-02; Am. Ord. 12-O-22, passed 10-16-12) Penalty,
see §
111.99
§ 111.13 FEE SCHEDULE.
   The annual fees for vending machines, gaming devices and for distributor’s
licenses shall be as follows:
      Vending machines:       $10 per machine;
      Gaming devices:       $25 per machine;
      Distributor’s licenses:    $200.
(Ord. 2002-O-45, passed 11-19-02; Am. Ord. 12-O-22, passed 10-16-12)
§ 111.14 VIOLATION.
   Any person, firm or corporation found to be in violation of §§
111.10 through
111.13, inclusive, shall be subject to the penalties provided for in §
111.99(G).
(Ord. 2002-O-45, passed 11-19-02; Am. Ord. 12-O-22, passed 10-16-12)
BOWLING ALLEYS
§ 111.15 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall operate, maintain, or conduct for
profit within the village any bowling alley, pin, or ball alley without having
first obtained a license therefor, as herein provided.
('79 Code, § 1402(1)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.16 FEE.
   The annual license fee for any such license shall be $10 for the first
alley, and $5 for each additional alley.
('79 Code, § 1402(2))
§ 111.17 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No person shall keep open, operate, or play upon any bowling alley, ball, or
pin alley licensed hereunder during the night time between the hours of 2:00
a.m. and 6:00 a.m.
('79 Code, § 1402(3)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.18 NOISE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation keeping or
conducting a bowling alley, pin, or ball alley to permit the patrons of the
same to make loud and boisterous noises so as to disturb the peace in the
vicinity. It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause any such noise
in a bowling alley, ball, or pin alley, or to congregate on the sidewalk or
street in front of any such premises in such manner or in such numbers as to
obstruct foot or vehicle traffic along the street or sidewalk.
('79 Code, § 1402(4)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.19 GAMBLING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble, to bet, or to tolerate any
form of gambling or betting in any premises used for a bowling alley, pin, or
ball alley.
('79 Code, § 1402(5)) Penalty, see §
111.99
BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS
§ 111.25 PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall operate, maintain, or conduct a
billiard, pool, bagatelle, pigeon- hole, or any other table or implement kept
for a similar purpose in any place of public resort within the village.
('79 Code, § 1403(1)) Penalty, see §
111.99
CIRCUSES
§ 111.50 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall conduct or operate a circus in the
village without having obtained a license as provided in this chapter.
('79 Code, § 1405(1)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.51 APPLICATION; FEE.
   The applications for such licenses shall be made to the Village Clerk, and
shall specify the place in or on which the circus is to be conducted. The fee
for circus licenses shall be $50 for each day during which the circuses are
conducted or open to the public, and no license shall issue without the payment
of the fee.
('79 Code, § 1405(2))
§ 111.52 SIDESHOWS AND CONCESSIONS.
   The license fee for sideshows and concessions operated in connection with a
circus shall be $50 per day; but only one sideshow license shall be required
for any circus regardless of the number of sideshows and concessions operated.
('79 Code, § 1405(3))
§ 111.53 PARADES.
   (A)   No circus parade shall be held in the village without a permit
therefor being first secured; the fee for such a permit shall be $50.
   (B)   Applications for such permits shall be made to the Village Clerk, and
the route to be followed shall be specified in the permit and shall be approved
by the Chief of Police.
   (C)   Each application shall be accompanied by a bond in the sum of §10,000
with sureties to be approved by the Village Clerk, conditioned to indemnify the
village for any loss or damage to the city property by the vehicles or
participants in such parade.
('79 Code, § 1405(4)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.54 INSPECTIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police and the Chief of the Fire
Department to see that inspections as provided for in §
111.08 shall be made of all circus performances and of the premises used.
('79 Code, § 1405(6))
§ 111.55 CHEATING.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to cheat, shortchange, or otherwise
defraud any person attending or about to attend a circus performance within the
village.
('79 Code, § 1405(7)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.56 OBEDIENCE TO REGULATIONS REQUIRED.
   It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this subchapter to obey
the provisions of this subchapter, and all other ordinance provisions relating
to circuses or the premises occupied.
('79 Code, § 1405(5)) Penalty, see §
111.99
MOTION PICTURES
§ 111.60 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to give, present, or conduct any motion picture to
which a fee for admission is charged, excepting performances given solely for
the benefits of and under the auspices of a local school or village religious
or charitable organization, without having first secured a license therefor as
is herein provided.
('79 Code, § 1406(1)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.61 APPLICATION; FEE.
   (A)   Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the
general provisions relating to such applications, and shall state in addition
to the other information required the place of the intended performance and the
seating capacity thereof. ('79 Code, § 1406(2))
   (B)   Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures naming a
specific place or building in which the performances are to be presented may
present therein any number of performances, including theatricals, during the
year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional
fee. The annual license fee for such licenses shall be $50. ('79 Code, § 1406
(3))
§ 111.62 NON-LICENSED PREMISES.
   For motion pictures which are to be presented in premises which are not
covered by such an annual license, the fee to be paid shall be $10 per day;
provided that no such motion picture shall be presented in or on any premises
or building which does not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances
for the construction of buildings with sufficient fire exits adequately marked.
('79 Code, § 1406(4)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.63 PROHIBITED PICTURES.
   It shall be unlawful to offer or present any motion picture which has a
tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance; or any immoral, indecent, or
blasphemous pictures or performances.
('79 Code, § 1406(5)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.64 CROWDING.
   It shall be unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers, to remain
standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is presented during the
time of such performance; and it shall be unlawful to admit to any such hall
more persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements for such
premises.
('79 Code, § 1406(6)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.65 FIRE PREVENTION.
   It shall be unlawful to use any scenery in any theater other than non-
flammable scenery or such as may have been rendered non-flammable by
application of fire preventive coatings.
('79 Code, § 1406(7)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.66 BUILDING REQUIREMENTS.
   It shall be unlawful to present any public motion picture in any building or
structure which does not contain the number of exits required for buildings or
places intended for motion picture performances by the building ordinances or
code of the village; or in any premises in which the electric wiring does not
fully comply with the ordinances. All places used for the exhibition of
theatricals must be kept adequately ventilated during the performance and for
so long a time as the audience may remain therein.
('79 Code, § 1406(8)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.67 EXITS.
   It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any aisles,
corridors, or exits leading from any room or enclosure in which a motion
picture performance is being given.
('79 Code, § 1406(9)) Penalty, see §
111.99
THEATRICALS
§ 111.75 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any theatrical performance, with
the exception of motion pictures or other performances specifically licensed by
this code to which a charge is made for admission and which is not conducted
solely for the profit of and under the auspices of a local public school or a
local village religious or charitable organization, without having first
obtained a license therefor, as is herein provided.
('79 Code, § 1407(1)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.76 FEE.
   Any person securing an annual license for theatricals naming a specific
place or building in which the performances are to be presented may present
therein any number of performances or theatricals, including motion pictures,
during the year for which the license is secured without any additional fee.
The annual fee for such licenses shall be $50.
('79 Code, § 1407(2))
§ 111.77 NON-LICENSED PREMISES.
   For theatricals which are to be presented in premises which are not covered
by such an annual license, the fee to be paid shall be $10 per day; provided
that no such theatrical shall be presented in or on any premises or building
which does not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances relating to
buildings to be used for theatricals.
('79 Code, § 1407(3)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.78 PROHIBITED THEATRICALS.
   It shall be unlawful to offer or present any theatrical which has a tendency
to cause a riot or disturbance of the peace; or any immoral, indecent, or
blasphemous plays or performances.
('79 Code, § 1407(4)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.79 CROWDING; DISTURBANCE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to permit any person, other than an usher or
other employee, to remain standing in a hall in which a theatrical performance
is presented during the time of such performance; and it shall be unlawful to
admit into any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating
arrangements for such premises.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any disturbance at any
theatrical performance.
('79 Code, § 1407(5)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.80 FIRE PREVENTION.
   It shall be unlawful to use any scenery in any theater other than non-
flammable scenery or such as may have been rendered non-flammable by
application of a fire preventive coating.
('79 Code, § 1407(6)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.81 BUILDING REQUIREMENTS.
   It shall be unlawful to present any public theatrical in any building or
structure which does not contain the number of exits required for buildings or
places intended for theatrical performances by the building ordinances or code
of the village; or any premises in which the electric wiring does not comply
with the ordinances. All places used for the exhibition of theatricals must be
kept adequately ventilated during the performance and for so long a time as the
audience may remain therein.
('79 Code, § 1407(7)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.82 EXITS.
   It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any aisles,
corridors, or exits leading from any enclosure or room in which a theatrical
performance is being given.
('79 Code, § 1407(8)) Penalty, see §
111.99
§ 111.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
111.01 through
111.08 shall be fined not less than $20 nor more than $200 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues.
('79 Code, § 1401(8))
   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of §§
111.15 through
111.19 shall be fined not less than $20 nor more than $200 for each offense.
The said license may be revoked for any violation of §§
111.15 through
111.19 by the licensee or his employees.
('79 Code, § 1402(6))
   (C)   If a person violates any provision of §
111.25, he shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $200 for each
offense.
('79 Code, § 1403(8))
   (D)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of §§
111.50 through
111.56 shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than $200 for each offense.
Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be considered a
separate and distinct offense.
('79 Code, § 1405(8))
   (E)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
111.60 through
111.67 shall be fined not less than $20 nor more than $200 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues.
('79 Code, § 1406(10))
2003 S-12 Repl.
   (F)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
111.75 through
111.82 shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than $200 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues.
('79 Code, § 1407(9))
   (G)   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of §§
111.10 through
111.13, inclusive, shall be fined $250 for a first offense, and shall be fined
$500 for a second or subsequent offense. The imposition of any fine hereunder
shall not prevent, estop or bar the village or any other law enforcement agency
with proper jurisdiction from applying for or exercising any other prohibitory
or remedial powers granted to them under federal, state or local laws,
regulations or ordinances.
(Am. Ord. 2002-O-45, passed 11-19-02)
CHAPTER 112: AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
Section
   
112.01   License required
   
112.02   Application
   
112.03   Character of applicant
   
112.04   Employees
   
112.05   Exemptions
   
112.06   Fees
   
112.07   False representations
 
   
112.99   Penalty
§ 112.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to conduct an
auction in the village or to do business as an auctioneer without having first
obtained a license therefor as is herein provided.
('79 Code, § 1501(1)) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.02 APPLICATION.
   Applications for auctioneer's licenses, or for a single auction, shall state
thereon the place of business intended to be occupied, if any, or the place of
such auction; and such applications shall give the names of any employees, not
to exceed two, who are to be authorized to conduct auctions under the authority
of the license.
('79 Code, § 1501(2))
§ 112.03 CHARACTER OF APPLICANT.
   No such license shall be issued to any but a person of good character; the
Chief of Police shall investigate the character of each applicant before the
license shall be issued.
('79 Code, § 1501(3))
§ 112.04 EMPLOYEES.
   Every person licensed as an auctioneer may designate no more than one
employee or co-partner who may be authorized by the licensee to conduct
auctions. The employer shall be liable for any violation of the village
ordinances committed by such employee or co-partner in conducting an auction.
('79 Code, § 1501(4))
§ 112.05 EXEMPTIONS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be held to apply to any public auction or sale
made or conducted by a public officer by virtue of any judicial order or
process or by virtue of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or trust
deed.
('79 Code, § 1501(5))
§ 112.06 FEES.
   The fees for auctioneer's licenses shall be: for a license for one day, or
one auction, $10; for an annual license, $100.
('79 Code, § 1501(6))
§ 112.07 FALSE REPRESENTATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any auctioneer, or employee, to make any
representations concerning any object, article, or commodity sold or offered
for sale by him at auction which he knows to be untrue or false.
('79 Code, § 1501(7)) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
112.01 through
112.07 shall be fined not less than $20 nor more than $200 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues.
('79 Code, § 1501(8))
CHAPTER 113: BATHING AND MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
Section
   
113.01   Definitions
Bathing and Massage Establishments
   
113.10   License
   
113.11   Application; fees
   
113.12   Revocation of license
   
113.13   Personnel
   
113.14   Itinerant operator's permit
   
113.15   Inspection
   
113.16   Sanitation requirements
   
113.17   Restricted behavior; exceptions
   
113.18   Hours of operation
Tanning Salons
   
113.25   License
   
113.26   Application; fees
   
113.27   Compliance with regulations
   
113.28   Revocation of license
 
   
113.99   Penalty
§ 113.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BATHING ESTABLISHMENTS. Any building, room, place, or establishment other
than a regularly established and licensed hospital or dispensary wherein are
given steam baths, steam vapor baths, electric tub baths, sponge baths, shower
baths, sun baths, tub baths, mud baths, mineral baths, Finnish, Russian,
Swedish, or Turkish baths, salt glows, massage, fomentation, electric or
magnetic treatments, alcohol rubs, and rubs or massages with or without any
other ingredients.
   MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS. Any building, room, place, or establishment other
than a regularly licensed and established hospital or dispensary where
nonmedical and nonsurgical manipulative exercises or devices are practiced upon
the human body manually or otherwise by any person other than a licensed
physician, surgeon, dentist, chiropractor, or osteopath with or without the use
of therapeutic, electrical, mechanical, or bathing devices.
('79 Code, § 1513(1))
   TANNING SALON. Any building, room, place, or establishment wherein are given
electric cabinet baths, electric light baths, sun baths, or any other method
used to artificially induce tanning of the skin. ('79 Code, § 1516(1)) (Ord.
1984-O-7, passed 2-7-84)
BATHING AND MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
§ 113.10 LICENSE.
   No person shall carry on the business of a bathing establishment or massage
establishment or render attendant occupational or professional services within
the village without first obtaining a license from the village.
('79 Code, § 1513(2)) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.11 APPLICATION; FEES.
   (A)   The application for a license shall contain the name and address of
the applicant, the type of business proposed to be conducted or maintained, and
the address of the place where it is proposed to conduct such profession,
occupation, or business. ('79 Code, § 1513(3))
   (B)   Upon receipt of application for the license, the health inspector
shall make a complete and thorough examination of the premises wherein the
applicant proposes to operate the business to determine if the premises comply
with the provisions of this section. The health inspector shall determine to
his satisfaction that such person is in sound physical, mental, and moral
health and of normal intelligence, a graduate of an accredited institute or
school, and as being possessed of sufficient knowledge of the human body and
its anatomy to be able to practice thereon without danger of inflicting bodily
injury or other harm through ignorance, inability, or other personal defects.
The Village Clerk shall require from the applicant references showing the
previous places of employment, if any, and upon being satisfied that the
applicant has the requisite qualifications to engage in such business or
profession may grant a license to such applicant. The provisions of this
section shall not apply to owners, lessees, or employees who themselves do not
practice on the human body.
('79 Code, § 1513(4))
   (C)   The annual fee for the license shall be $300 for each establishment,
and in addition $50 for each operator, renewable yearly.
('79 Code, § 1513(5))
§ 113.12 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The health inspector may recommend to the Village President the revocation
of the license whenever it appears that the licensee has not operated his
profession or business in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. When
a license is revoked, the health inspector is directed to call upon the Chief
of Police to close the place of business holding such license until such time
as the licensee has agreed to comply fully with the provisions of this chapter
whereupon the President may reinstate the license.
('79 Code, § 1513(6))
§ 113.13 PERSONNEL.
   It shall be unlawful for anyone under the age of 18 years of age to be
either a patron or employee of a bathing establishment or massage
establishment.
('79 Code, § 1513(7)) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.14 ITINERANT OPERATOR'S PERMIT.
   Itinerant masseurs, masseuses, or other itinerant operators engaging in the
professions or occupations set forth in this chapter shall make application for
and receive a permit to so engage in such professions or occupations in the
manner outlined in this section for each time they enter the village for such
purpose. The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons employed for
such work by regularly licensed establishments.
('79 Code, § 1513(8)) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.15 INSPECTION.
   Each establishment licensed under this chapter shall be open for inspection
by the duly authorized representatives of the village to whom the power of
licensing and supervising such establishment is committed. The health inspector
shall have the general sanitary supervision of all such establishments or
places of business.
('79 Code, § 1513(9))
§ 113.16 SANITATION REQUIREMENTS.
   Licensees under this chapter shall maintain their establishments in a clean
and sanitary condition and take all reasonable precautions to safeguard the
safety and health of the patrons of such establishment. All steam rooms, hot
rooms, shower rooms, and dressing rooms shall be constructed of fireproof
material. All hot rooms and steam rooms shall have ventilating systems for the
expulsion of vitiated air. All boiler and furnace rooms within the building
shall be of fireproof construction and equipped with fireproof doors of an
approved design. The partition walls between all the rooms shall be kept
enclosed from floor to ceiling and wall to wall and the doors and walls of such
rooms shall be so constructed and maintained as to insure the utmost privacy.
('79 Code, § 1513(10) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.17 RESTRICTED BEHAVIOR; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   Body massage or treatment of the character described in §
113.01 shall not be given by male persons to female persons, or by female
persons to male persons, except in regularly established and licensed
hospitals, dispensaries, or institutions and establishments operating under the
direction or guidance of a physician or chiropractor, and except when
specifically directed and prescribed in writing by a duly licensed physician or
chiropractor. Except in hospitals and dispensaries, authority for each
treatment shall be given on a separate written prescription over the signature
of a physician or chiropractor. This section shall not apply to any registered
nurse operating under the direction of a physician, nor shall it apply to
massage of the face practiced by beauty parlors or barber shops duly licensed.
('79 Code, § 1513(11))
2005 S-14
   (B)   The provisions of this chapter do not apply to duly licensed
physicians, surgeons, dentists, osteopaths, chiropractors, massage therapists,
or physical therapists; nor do these provisions apply to athletic directors
assigned to schools when engaged in their regular professions or occupations.
('79 Code, § 1513(12)) (Am. Ord. 2005-O-1, passed 1-4-05) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.18 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No massage parlor shall be open earlier than 8:00 a.m. and not later than 8:
00 p.m. on any day.
('79 Code, § 1513(13)) Penalty, see §
113.99
TANNING SALONS
§ 113.25 LICENSE.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall carry on the business of operating a
tanning salon within the village without having obtained a license from the
village.
('79 Code, § 1516(2)) (Ord. 1984-O-7, passed 2-7-84) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.26 APPLICATION; FEES.
   (A)   The application for a license required by §
113.25 shall contain the names and addresses of all persons having a financial
interest in such an establishment, the type of business proposed, and the
address of the place proposed to conduct the business of operating a tanning
salon.
('79 Code, § 1516(3))
   (B)   The annual fee for the license shall be $25 for each establishment,
and in addition $5 for each attendant of such establishment renewable yearly.
Licenses shall be issued concurrently with the fiscal year of the village.
('79 Code, § 1516(4)) (Ord. 1984-O-7, passed 2-7-84) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.27 COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
   Tanning salons shall be maintained and operated in a clean and sanitary
condition which at all times shall meet the requirements of the state, the
county, and the village. Equipment used in the operation of a tanning salon
facility shall be of a type approved by such appropriate authorities to insure
the complete safety of the users.
('79 Code, § 1516(5)) (Ord. 1984-O-7, passed 2-7-84) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.28 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The health inspector may recommend to the Village President revocation of
the license whenever it appears that the licensee has not operated his business
in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The President may direct a
member of the Police Department to close the place of business until such time
as compliance with this chapter has again been met. The President may then,
upon compliance, reinstate the license.
('79 Code, § 1516(6)) (Ord. 1984-O-7, passed 2-7-84)
§ 113.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person, corporation, or entity convicted of a violation of §§
113.10 through
113.18 shall be fined in a sum of not less than $25 nor more than $500 for one
offense. ('79 Code, § 1513(15))
   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
113.25 through
113.28 shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $500 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues.
('79 Code, § 1516(7)) (Ord. 1984-O-7, passed 2-7-84)

BROKERS
§ 114.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall operate as a broker of any articles,
goods, property, or tickets without being licensed therefor as is herein
provided; provided that this section shall not be construed to require an
additional village license from licensed real estate brokers.
('79 Code, § 1502(1)) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.02 APPLICATIONS; FEE.
   (A)   Applications for brokers licenses shall be made in writing to the
Village Clerk and shall state the article or property intended to be traded in.
No such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good
character, and it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to make or cause to
be made an investigation into the character of such applicant. ('79 Code, §
1502(2))
   (B)   The annual fee for brokers shall be $20 and no license shall be issued
except on the payment of the fee.
('79 Code, § 1502(2))
§ 114.03 FRAUD.
   It shall be unlawful for any person operating as a broker of any article or
goods to practice fraud or deception of any sort or to make false pretenses of
any kind, or to represent both parties to a
transaction without the knowledge of both parties.
('79 Code, § 1502(5)) Penalty, see §
114.99
REAL ESTATE DEALERS
§ 114.10 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, or corporation shall operate or conduct the business of
real estate broker without first being licensed therefor. Applications for
licenses shall be made in writings to the Village Clerk, and no license shall
be issued to any person or firm which has not obtained a certificate of
registration as required by the law of this state.
('79 Code, § 1508(1)) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.11 FEE.
   The annual license fee for such licenses shall be $10, and no license shall
be issued except upon payment of this fee.
('79 Code, § 1508(2))
§ 114.12 FRAUDULENT PRACTICES.
   No such license shall be issued to any person or firm which has been found
guilty of fraudulent practices in violation of the state statute in relation to
real estate brokers. Any real estate brokers licenses may be revoked for such
fraudulent practices.
('79 Code, § 1508(3))
§ 114.99 PENALTY.
   (A)    (1)   Any person, firm, or corporation violation or failing to comply
with any provision of §§
114.01 or
114.02 shall be fined not less than $20 nor more than $200 for each offense,
and a separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each and every
day on which a violation of §§
114.01 or
114.02 occurs or continues. ('79 Code, § 1502(4))
      (2)   Any person licensed under the provisions of §§
114.01 and
114.02 who is guilty of a violation of §
114.03 shall be fined not less than $20 nor more than $200 and any broker
license may be revoked upon two or more violations of §
114.03. ('79 Code, § 1502(6))
   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
114.10 through
114.12 or any state statute in relation to real estate brokers shall be fined
$100 for each offense; and each day upon which a violation occurs or continues
shall be considered a separate and distinct offense.
('79 Code, § 1508(4))

provided.

§§
115.01 and

feet are used for residence purposes without the consent of the owners of two-

   The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to permit the
establishment of any factory or place of business in any location where such
factory or place of business is prohibited by the zoning code.

factory causing noxious odors within the village or within one mile of the
village limits.

soap factory, glue factory, tannery, packing plant, slaughterhouse, or other
similar operations within the village or within one mile and one half of the

('79 Code, § 1503(7)) Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this

and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day a violation occurs
or continues.
('79 Code, § 1503(8))

§ 116.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FOOD FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION. All food and drink intended for human
consumption
including packaged, non-readily perishable food, such as candy, chewing gum,
nut meats, and other such foods. ('79 Code, § 1203(2))
   ITINERANT RESTAURANT. A restaurant operating for a temporary period not to
exceed ten days in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition,
or other similar gathering.
   PREPACKAGED FOOD VENDOR. Any establishment or business which dispenses or
sells prepackaged, non-readily perishable food, such as candy, chewing gum, nut
meats, potato chips, pretzels, popcorn, and bottled soft drink beverages on its
premises.
   RESTAURANT. Includes any place where food or drink (other than alcoholic
liquor) is prepared or served to the public for consumption, including and not
limited to a RESTAURANT, coffee house, ice cream parlor, luncheonette, tavern,
mobile sandwich stand, soda fountain, and mini-mart.
('79 Code, § 1203(3)) (Am. Ord. 1989-O-29, passed 8-1-89)
   TOBACCO AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS. Cigarettes, cigars, or tobacco in any form
intended for human use. All products containing tobacco, including, without
limitation, cigarettes, cigars, loose tobacco, pipe tobacco, chewing tobacco,
snuff and whole leaf tobacco.
('79 Code, § 1204(2)) (Ord. 1998-O-6, passed 2-17-98)
   VENDING MACHINE. Any self-service device offered for public use which
dispenses unit servings of food or beverage either in bulk or package, without
the necessity of replenishing the device between each vending operation,
including, but not limited to coin- or token-operated devices.
('79 Code, § 1203(3))
FOOD DEALERS
§ 116.10 LICENSE.
   It shall be unlawful for any food dealer including restaurant, coffee house,
ice cream parlor, luncheonette, tavern, mobile sandwich stand, soda fountain,
or alike operators to operate such establishment without first having secured a
license therefor. No person shall operate a restaurant or itinerant restaurant
without first obtaining a license as provided herein; except that of a
nonprofit, mutual benefit society is not required to secure a license for an
itinerant restaurant, but is otherwise required to comply. It shall be likewise
unlawful for any person to install, maintain, use, or permit the installation,
maintenance, or use upon his premises of automatic coin-operated machines for
the sale of food for human consumption, without having first procured a license
therefor for each machine; provided, nothing in the foregoing shall be
construed to require the licensing of automatic vending machines containing
milk in carton containers. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the
Village Clerk, and shall recite the name and address, both business and
residence, of the applicant and the nature of the business or activity. The
proper fee shall be paid to the Village Clerk, who shall turn it over to the
Village Treasurer forthwith.
('79 Code, § 1203(1)) (Am. Ord. 1989-O-29, passed 8-1-89) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.11 APPLICATIONS; RENEWALS.
   All applications for licenses, and all renewals of licenses to conduct a
restaurant, coffee house, or ice cream parlor shall be referred to the county
health department and the village health officer who shall make or cause to be
made an investigation of the premises to be used, and report these findings
thereon, recommending or advising against the issuance or renewal of the
license.
('79 Code, § 1203(4))
§ 116.12 FEES; ISSUANCE.
   (A)   The application fees for the licenses required by this section shall
be as follows:
 
Restaurant                  $100 per year
Itinerant restaurant        $100 per year
Prepackaged food vendor     $50 per year
Festival ground food trucks
   (See §               $300 per year
116.30)
 
   (B)   All licenses shall be issued by the Village Clerk for a period from
May 1 and ending April 30 of the following year, except the itinerant
restaurant license which shall be issued for a ten-day period as designated by
the village health officer.
   (C)   No license shall be prorated for a portion of a year, and no
application fee shall be refundable after an application has been submitted to
the Village Clerk.
   (D)   All vending machine licenses shall be affixed to the vending machine
or on a surface area immediately adjacent to said machine, which is visible to
the public.
   (E)   No person, business, or establishment shall be allowed to obtain more
than two itinerant restaurant licenses during any calendar year.
(‘79 Code, § 1203(7)) (Am. Ord. 1989-O-29, passed 8-1-89; Am. Ord. 2014-O-4,
passed 3-18-14; Am. Ord. 2014-O-6, passed 5-6-14; Am. Ord. 2024-O-17, passed
11-19-24)
§ 116.13 FLIES AND VERMIN.
   Premises used for the storage of food intended for human consumption shall
be kept free from flies and vermin of all kinds.
('79 Code, § 1203(6)) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.14 UNWHOLESOME FOOD.
   (A)   No person, firm, or corporation shall offer for sale, or keep for the
purpose of selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for
human consumption which is spoiled or tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for
consumption for any reason.
   (B)   All tainted or unwholesome food intended for human consumption may be
condemned by the Lake County Health Department, and shall thereupon be seized
and destroyed by the health officer or any police officer.
(‘79 Code, § 1203(5)) (Am. Ord. 2024-O-17, passed 11-19-24) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.15 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE.
   Licenses may be revoked or suspended by the Village President for any of the
following causes:
   (A)   Fraud, misrepresentation, or incorrect statement contained in the
application for license.
   (B)   Conducting such licensed activity in such a manner as to constitute a
breach of the peace, or a menace to the health, safety, or welfare of the
public, upon the recommendation of the appropriate village official.
   (C)   Actions unauthorized by or beyond the scope of the license granted.
   (D)   Violations of any village code or ordinance applicable to the business
or activity for which the license was granted, or violations of any regulations
or laws of the state so applicable.
('79 Code, § 1203(8))
§ 116.16 APPEAL OF REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   Any person aggrieved by the suspension or revocation of a license shall have
the right to a hearing before the Village President provided a written request
is filed with the Village Clerk within ten days after the receipt of the notice
of such action.
('79 Code, § 1203(9))
§ 116.17 EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food
intended for sale for human consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to
person and clothing.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier
of any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care or
preparation of any such food; and it shall be unlawful to permit any such
person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored, prepared,
or sold, or to deliver such food.
('79 Code, § 1203(10)) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.18 INSPECTION.
   (A)   At least once every six months the county health department will cause
an inspection to be made of every restaurant, coffee house, and ice cream
parlor located within the village. In case the health department discovers the
violation of any item of sanitation, it shall make a second inspection after
the lapse of such time as it deems necessary for the defect to be remedied. Any
violation of the same requirement of this chapter found on such second
inspection shall authorize immediate revocation of license.
   (B)   One copy of the inspection report shall be posted by the health
department upon an inside wall of the restaurant, coffee house, or ice cream
parlor and said inspection report shall not be defaced or removed by any person
except the health department. One copy of the inspection report shall be filed
with the records of the health department.
   (C)   The person operating the restaurant, coffee house, or ice cream parlor
shall, upon request of the agent of the health department, permit access to all
parts of the establishment and shall permit copying of all records of food
purchases.
('79 Code, § 1203(11)) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.19 TOILET FACILITIES.
   Every restaurant, coffee house, or ice cream parlor shall be provided with
adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees,
conforming with the ordinances of the village. In restaurants, coffee houses,
or ice cream parlors hereafter constructed, toilet rooms shall not open
directly into any room in which food, drink, or utensils are handled or stored.
The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self- closing. Toilet rooms shall be
kept in a clean condition, in good repair, and well lighted and ventilated.
Hand washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees.
('79 Code, § 1203(12)) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.20 WASTE DISPOSAL.
   All wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be
kept in suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to become a nuisance.
('79 Code, § 1203(13)) Penalty, see §
116.99
§ 116.21 FOOD AND DRINK.
   All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage, and so
prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid milk products,
ice cream, and other frozen desserts served shall be from approved sources.
Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original
containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a bulk
container equipped with an approved dispensing device; provided that this
requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be served from the original
carton or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters, clams, and
mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked shall be kept until used
in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant.
('79 Code, § 1203(14)) Penalty, see §
116.99
FOOD TRUCKS
§ 116.30 FESTIVAL GROUND FOOD TRUCKS.
   This section permits the owners and operators of festival grounds to operate
or contract with operators of mobile food trucks to provide wholesome food to
tourists, visitors and the general public throughout the year, subject to the
following specific regulations:
   (A)   FESTIVAL GROUNDS means a contiguous parcel of land of at least eight
acres in size;
   (B)   There shall be no more than five food trucks allowed to operate on
each festival grounds site at any time:
   (C)   The owner or occupant of the land is solely responsible for ensuring
that all food trucks on the festival grounds have proper licensing from the
Lake County Health Department and remit all sales taxes to the State of
Illinois Department of Revenue. as well as comply with all local and state laws
that relate to their operation:
   (D)   Nothing in this section is intended to prevent the licensing of food
trucks in other areas of the village pursuant to special event permits duly
issued upon proper application and qualification.
(Ord. 2024-O-17, passed 11-19-24)
§ 116.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of §§
116.10 through
116.30 shall be fined not less than $100 nor more than $500 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues. The issuance of a fine or other monetary
penalty upon any person, firm, corporation shall not prevent the issuance of an
injunction, restraining order or other form of prohibitory writ by a court of
competent jurisdiction: nor shall it prevent the issuance of a notice of
license suspension or revocation by the Mayor. Health Officer or the Lake
County Health Department under §
116.15 or other applicable law. In any action brought or defended by the
village, the person, firm or corporation found to be in violation of this
chapter shall further be liable for the attorney’s fees and the costs of any
such proceeding and the court shall tax the same as part of its judgment.
(‘79 Code, § 1203(15)) (Am. Ord. 2024-O-17, passed 11-19-24)
CHAPTER 117: SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS, PEDDLERS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND
TRANSIENT VENDORS
Section
   
117.01   Definitions
   
117.02   Rights of owners and occupants
   
117.03   Registration/permit—solicitors, canvassers, peddlers
   
117.04   Solicitor registration (not-for-profit)—procedure
   
117.05   Canvasser, peddler, itinerant merchant, transient vendor permit (for-
profit)—procedure
   
117.06   Revocation
   
117.07   Notices limiting solicitation
   
117.08   Duty of solicitors
