§ 150.004 CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
   (A)   Any owner of property or applicant seeking issuance of a certificate
of occupancy for any erected, constructed, reconstructed, enlarged or
structurally altered building or other structure is required as a prior
condition precedent to issuance of any certificate of occupancy for any such
improvement to first file an unexecuted certificate of occupancy with the
Benton Township Assessor.
   (B)   Any owner of property or applicant seeking issuance of a certificate
of occupancy is required to obtain from the Village Building Inspector a
certificate of occupancy form showing that the unexecuted certificate of
occupancy has been filed, and that the property is subject to increased
assessment from the date of issue of the certificate on a proportionate basis
for the year in which the improvement was completed.
   (C)   The owner of the property or applicant shall contact the Township
Assessor's Office for an appointment for an inspection. Upon completion of
inspection, the owner of the property or applicant shall place on file an
executed certificate of occupancy with the Village of Winthrop Harbor
Department of Building. Upon completion of an inspection of said property by
the Building Official and the issuance of certificate of occupancy, a certified
copy of said document will be filed with the Benton Township Assessor by the
Village of Winthrop Harbor through its Department of Building and Zoning.
(Ord. 1990-O-06, passed 3-6-90)
§ 150.005 TEMPORARY CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY.
   (A)   It is the policy of this village to avoid issuance of temporary
certificates of occupancy (“CO”) because of the problems inherent with them,
mainly involving circumstances where the completion of the work on the building
or grounds is not completed on a timely basis following issuance of the CO.
   (B)   Wintertime temporary CO’s will be issued from November 1 through April
1 provided that landscaping (NOT final grading) is the only remaining part of
the construction awaiting completion. Any wintertime temporary CO shall require
posting of a $5,000 landscaping bond, and all work shall be completed not later
than the next following May 31.
   (C)   Special temporary CO’s will be issued from April 2 through October 31
only when all of the following conditions apply:
      (1)   The only remaining work is landscaping (NOT final grading);
      (2)   A $5,000 landscaping bond is posted;
      (3)   All remaining landscaping work shall be completed within 30 days of
the issuance of the temporary CO; and
      (4)   The delay in completion is a result of inclement weather, not the
fault of the owner or builder of the structure.
   (D)   The determination of whether landscaping is the only remaining
construction shall be made by the Village Engineer, and the applicant shall pay
any fees that the Engineer may charge for the review and determination.
   (E)   The landscaping bond shall be in the form of a check made payable to
the village drawn on good funds. The village will deposit the landscaping bond
check upon receipt. Provided that the landscaping work is completed within the
time permitted, the bond shall be refunded. However, if the work is not
completed on time, the bond is forfeit. The village shall then complete the
landscaping, and if the amount of the bond is insufficient to cover the expense
of the same, it shall have the right to bill the builder, homeowner, or
contractor to recover any such additional expenses it shall incur.
   (F)   The village shall charge an administration fee in the amount of 2% of
the escrowed funds each time an escrow is established, which funds shall be
collected at the time that the escrow is established.
   (G)   Nothing herein shall affect the other requirements for a CO, including
those set forth in §
150.004 of this code.
(Ord. 2005-O-6, passed 4-19-05)
§ 150.006 CONSTRUCTION HOURS.
   (A)   Weekday hours. It is forbidden to perform or permit performance of
construction work prior to the hour of 7:00 a.m. or to permit the performance
of construction work after the hour of 7:00 p.m., on any non-holiday Monday
through Friday.
   (B)   Saturday hours. It is forbidden to perform or permit performance of
construction work prior to the hour of 7:00 a.m. or to permit the performance
of construction work after the hour of 3:00 p.m. on any Saturday.
   (C)   Holiday hours. It is forbidden to perform or permit performance of
construction work prior to the hour of 7:00 a.m. or to permit the performance
of construction work after the hour of 3:00 p.m. on any holiday that falls on
any Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, or Saturday.
   (D)   Sunday. It is forbidden to perform or permit performance of
construction work on any Sunday.
   (E)   Definitions.     For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      CONSTRUCTION WORK. The broadest possible meaning, including but not
limited to all excavating, paving, carpentry, electrical, plumbing, concrete
work, roofing, siding, or other trades work on a building under construction,
repair, or remodeling, other than emergency work on existing structures or
routine maintenance that does not cause a substantial disturbance of the peace
and quiet in any residential neighborhood.
      HOLIDAY. Any holiday recognized by the state or the federal government as
an official holiday.
   (F)   Exemption. Nothing herein is intended to prohibit or regulate work
performed by any homeowner on his or her own residence, provided that such work
does not cause an unreasonable disturbance of the peace and quiet in any
residential neighborhood.
(Ord. 2005-O-23, passed 10-18-05) Penalty, see §
150.99
§ 150.007 WATER WALLS.
   Notwithstanding any code provision set forth in this chapter, any wall of
any structure constructed after the adoption of this section in April of 2008
in which plumbing pipes are located shall meet the following minimum
provisions:
   (A)   Any wall which contains any plumbing lines, stacks, branches of
risers, any one of which is at least one and one-half inch minimum diameter in
size, shall be constructed of not less than two-inch by six-inch framing
members.
   (B)   Any measures necessary to protect such plumbing from freezing shall be
the joint responsibility of the architect, engineer and general contractor.
   (C)   Drilling and notching shall comply with the requirements of the
International Building Code, 2006 and the International Residential Code, 2006.
(Ord. 2008-O-8, passed 4-1-08)
§ 150.008 SUPPLEMENTAL ENFORCEMENT POWERS.
    In addition to all other powers granted to the Building Official and any
and all Building Inspectors in this code, or in the uniform codes adopted by
this code, the Community Development Director shall have the following non-
cumulative powers:
   (A)   To charge a double permit fee for work commenced without a required
building permit;
   (B)   To require and charge the contractor and/or owner for any additional
inspections necessary to ensure the safety and code compliance of work
commenced without a required building permit;
   (C)   To require any re-work of non-code-compliant work commenced prior to
obtaining a required building permit;
   (D)   To issue citations for work or practices that violate any of the
provisions of this section, and to have the same served upon the contractor
and/or owner either in person, by any Building Inspector, by any village police
officer or by one of the village's Community Service Officers.
(Ord. 2011-O-2, passed 1-18-11)
§ 150.009 FINAL INSPECTION REQUIRED.  
   In all circumstances where a building permit has been issued, it is the
joint and several duty of the owner and any contractor obtaining a permit to
obtain a final inspection of the work encompassed within the permit, and to
comply with all conditions necessary to pass that final inspection. In
addition, the following conditions shall, in all cases, apply:
   (A)   This requirement applies in all instances, including those where no
certificate of occupancy is required by the applicable building codes set forth
in this chapter or adopted hereunder.
   (B)   The final inspection must be ordered and completed promptly at the
completion of the work encompassed within the permit, and in any event, prior
to the expiration of the building permit.
   (C)   The Community Development Director and/or any Building Official, at
his or her sound discretion, shall not issue any building permits to any person
who demonstrates a pattern of refusing or habitually failing to secure final
inspections on a timely basis.
(Ord. 2011-O-2, passed 1-18-11)
SWIMMING POOLS
§ 150.010 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PRIVATE POOL. A swimming pool or wading pool at a private residence intended
only for the use of the individual owner, the owner's family and friends. This
includes portable or temporary-type pools or plastic, rubberized cloth, or
similar materials installed either above or below ground elevation.
   PUBLIC POOL. All swimming pools and wading pools other than private
residence installations. This includes municipal, park district, association,
club, camp, and school pools, as well as those at motels and hotels.
   SWIMMING POOL or WADING POOL. An artificial pool of water and auxiliary
structures including dressing and locker rooms, toilets, showers, and other
areas and enclosures that are intended for the use of persons using the pool.
('79 Code, § 1606(1))
§ 150.011 PUBLIC POOLS TO COMPLY WITH STATE REGULATIONS.
   Public pools, their equipment and operation, shall comply with the state
department of public health minimum sanitary requirements for swimming pools
and bathing places.
('79 Code, § 1606(2)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.012 CONSTRUCTION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person or organization shall proceed to construct a swimming pool or make
major alterations at an existing pool without first having obtained a permit
therefor, issued and signed by the Building Inspector or the Inspector’s
authorized representative upon approved application. No permit is required for
erection of a portable pool if the capacity of such pool is 1,000 gallons or
less.
('79 Code, § 1606(3)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.013 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   Application for a permit required by §
150.012 shall be in writing in the form prescribed by the village. Such
application shall contain such information and drawings as shall be required by
the village for a proper understanding of the proposed work. Each application
for permit for the construction of a public pool shall be accompanied by an
approval permit for the construction issued by the County Health Department and
reviewed by Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and North Shore Sanitation
District. Applications for permits shall be accompanied by plans and
specifications in duplicate and in sufficient detail shall show the following:
   (A)   Plot plan elevation with dimensions drawn to scale.
   (B)   Pool dimensions, depth, and volume in gallons.
   (C)   Type and size of filter systems, filtration and backwash capacity.
   (D)   Pool piping layout with all pipe sized, and valves shown and types of
materials to be used.
   (E)   The rated capacity and head of filtration and backwash flow of the
pool pump in gallons per minute with the size and type of motor.
   (F)   Location and type of waste disposal system.
('79 Code, § 1606(4))
§ 150.014 TESTS.
   All pool piping and the installation and construction of the pool piping
system shall be in accordance with the approved plans. The entire pool piping
system shall be tested with a water test of 100 PSI and proved tight before
covering or concealing.
('79 Code, § 1606(5))
§ 150.015 SAFETY DEVICES.
   (A)   Every person owning land on which there is situated a swimming pool
which contains 18 inches or more of water in depth at any point, shall erect
and maintain thereon an adequate enclosure either surrounding the property or
pool area, sufficient to make such a body of water inaccessible to small
children. Such enclosure, including gates thereon, must extend at least 4 feet
above the underlying ground and all gates must be self-latching with latches
placed at least 4 feet above the underlying ground or otherwise made
inaccessible from the outside to small children.
   (B)   A natural barrier or other protective device may be used so long as
the degree of protection afforded by the substituted devices or structures is
not less than the protection afforded by the enclosure, gate, and latch
described in division (A).
('79 Code, § 1606(6)) (Am. Ord. 2003-O-7, passed 4-15-03) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.016 OVERHEAD ELECTRICAL CONDUCTORS.
   No overhead electrical conductors shall be installed within 15 feet of any
swimming pool. All metal fences, enclosures, or railings near or adjacent to a
swimming pool to which bathers have access, which may become electrically alive
as a result of contact with broken overhead conductors, or from any other
cause, shall be effectively grounded.
('79 Code, § 1606(7)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.017 EQUIPMENT INSTALLATION.
   Pumps, filters, and other mechanical and electrical equipment for public and
semi-public swimming pools shall be in such manner as to be accessible only to
authorized persons and not to bathers. Construction and drainage shall be such
as to avoid the entrance and accumulation of water in the vicinity of
electrical equipment.
('79 Code, § 1606(8)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.018 DRAINAGE FROM POOL.
   Drain outlet connections from a pool shall not be connected into village
storm sewers. Pool waste water discharge shall be made into the village
sanitary sewer if available.
('79 Code, § 1606(9)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.019 OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   All private residential swimming pools shall be maintained in a clean
and sanitary condition, and all equipment shall be maintained in a satisfactory
operating condition during periods the pool is in use.
   (B)   No private residential swimming pool shall be used, kept, maintained,
or operated in the village if such use, keeping, maintaining, or operating
shall be the occasion of any nuisance or shall be dangerous to life or
detrimental to health.
   (C)   Chlorine disinfectant in the form of sodium or calcium hypochlorite,
or chlorine gas or bromine or an acceptable substitute, shall be applied daily
as frequently as needed to maintain a definite residual throughout the pool
volume while the pool is in use.
('79 Code, § 1606(10)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.020 RIGHT OF VILLAGE TO INSPECT AND TEST.
   The representatives of the village shall have the right and authority to
inspect any pool or to check the operation thereof during reasonable daylight
hours.
('79 Code, § 1606(11))
§ 150.021 AUTHORITY OF VILLAGE TO CLOSE.
   If a representative of the village shall find, after inspection, that the
operation of the pool does not meet the sanitary and safety requirements of
this subchapter, the representative shall direct that the pool be closed until
the sanitary and safety requirements are met.
('79 Code, § 1606(12))
§ 150.022 FEES.
   The fee for a permit for the erection of a swimming pool shall be determined
in accordance with Ord. 1978-O-6, passed 4-4-78, as amended from time to time.
('79 Code, § 1606(13)) (Ord. 1983-O-25, passed 9-1-82)
ENCROACHMENTS
§ 150.035 COUNTY-VILLAGE AGREEMENT.
   (A)   Whereas the county, under the terms of a State-County Agreement, has
entered into an additional Agreement with the village as part of said
Agreement, the village has agreed to enact regulations relative to the removal
of encroachments within certain rights-of-way for certain improvements, in
accordance with the following definitions:
      (1)   CONSTRUCTION EASEMENT AREA. That area lying between the project
right-of-way limits and the roadway right-of-way limits. The village will
permit the state and county to enter within this area to perform all necessary
construction operations in connection with this improvement.
      (2)   ENCROACHMENT. Any building, fence, sign, or any other structure or
object of any kind (with the exception of utilities, public road signs, and
municipally-owned parking meters) which is placed, located, or maintained in,
on, under, or over any portion of the roadway right-of-way.
      (3)   PERMISSIBLE ENCROACHMENT. Existing awnings, marquees, advertising
signs, and similar overhanging structures supported from buildings immediately
adjacent to the roadway right-of- way at locations where there is continuous
sidewalk extending to and through the frontage of the building line, and which
do not impair the free and safe flow of traffic on the highway, may be
permitted, upon the approval of the State Department of Public Works and
Buildings, to remain under a permit issued by the State Department of Public
Works and Buildings.
      (4)   ROADWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY. Those areas existing or acquired by
dedication or by fee simple for highway purposes; also the areas acquired by
temporary easement during the time the easement is in effect.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to erect or
cause to be erected, or to retain or cause to be retained any encroachment
above defined within the limits of the project right-of-way or roadway right-
of-way where no project right-of-way lines have been established.
   (C)   Project right-of-way lines will hereafter be established, pursuant to
the agreement entered into by and between the village and Lake County on 6-20-
72.
   (D)   The village hereby agrees that it will cause to be removed all
encroachments less permanent in nature, such as overhanging structures
supported by poles or similar structures, moveable signs, or advertising
displays which are encroachments within the roadway right-of-way.
   (E)   This section is intended to and shall be in addition to all other
ordinances, rules, and regulations concerning encroachments and shall not be
construed as repealing or rescinding any other ordinances or part of any
ordinance unless in direct conflict therewith.
('79 Code, § 1607(1) - (4)) Penalty, see §
150.999
SHEDS AND ACCESSORY STRUCTURES
§ 150.040 SHEDS AND ACCESSORY STRUCTURE CONSTRUCTION.
   (A)   Floors regulated. Sheds and other accessory structures, other than
garages and other buildings designed to house or store motor vehicles, shall be
soundly constructed upon four-inch-thick concrete pads cushioned on a compacted
gravel base of not less than four inches thick, unless the floor of a shed
shall be an integrated structural component of a pre-fabricated shed, in which
case the floor shall be constructed of structural plastic, structural steel or
fiberglass so that it cannot absorb and retain gasoline or other flammable
materials and thereby increase the risk of fire or explosion. No shed or other
accessory structure shall be constructed or maintained with a dirt or gravel
floor.
   (B)   Cargo containers prohibited. No metal box or shipping container,
including but not limited to, seagoing cargo containers, railroad-compatible
shipping containers, truck-mountable unitized steel containers, intermodal
shipping containers or other similar device, may be used or maintained as a
shed or other accessory building in any zoning district. Any cargo container
being used as a shed at the time of the adoption of amendatory Ordinance No.
2011-O-4 on March 1, 2011, shall be removed from the premises where it is
located by September 1, 2011.
(Ord. 2002-O-35, passed 9-3-02; Am. Ord. 2011-O-4, passed 3-1-11) Penalty, see
§
150.999
DETACHED GARAGES
§ 150.45 DETACHED GARAGES.
   (A)   Detached garages and other buildings designed to house or store motor
vehicles shall be soundly constructed upon reinforced concrete pads cushioned
on a compacted gravel base with footings as set forth hereinbelow. No garage or
other accessory structure shall be constructed or maintained with a dirt or
gravel floor. The specific requirements of the concrete base shall be as
follows:
      (1)   The top of the slab shall sit not less than six inches above the
high point in the site grade;
      (2)   The base of the footings shall be not less than 18 inches below
grade on all sides;
      (3)   The footings shall be a minimum of 12 inches across at the bottom,
resting on undisturbed soil;
      (4)   All base plates shall be connected with 1/2-inch diameter anchor
bolts set in the place prior to the pour, not less than seven inches in length
and not more than six feet on center, and there shall be at least one such
anchor bolt on each side of any door and one at each side of each corner;
      (5)   The concrete footing reinforcement shall consist of one #5 rebar or
two #4 rebars set in a continuous loop around the garage footing, with all ends
overlapping not less than two feet and tied securely;
      (6)   The slab shall consist of a minimum of six inch by six inch welded
wire mesh with six-inch overlaps tied at any joints (fiber mesh concrete alone
is not permitted);
      (7)   The slab shall be poured with a minimum of four inches of concrete
set on a minimum four inches of compacted gravel base;
      (8)   There shall be a minimum two inches of pitch from the rear to the
overhead door opening(s);
      (9)   Floor drains may be permitted if otherwise allowed under § 890.520
of the Illinois Plumbing Code;
      (10)   All organic soils shall be removed from under the slab and
footings prior to the forming and pouring.
   (B)   No so-called temporary garage shall be permitted to be constructed or
maintained in the village. Temporary garages include but are not limited to
plastic sheeting stretched over pipe or poles, light duty aluminum structures
without strong frames, and the like. Many impermissible temporary garages are
commonly sold as “instant garages” or “instant carports.” Nothing herein shall
regulate any use of a close-fitting car cover made of plastic, cloth, or other
material that is designed and used to cover only one motor vehicle.
   (C)   All detached garages constructed or substantially rebuilt after March
15, 2005, shall be solidly built of frame, face brick, or masonry construction
and except for brick or masonry structures shall be faced or sided with
permanent siding designed to withstand weather and provide a sightly aspect to
the structure. Roofs shall be constructed with hurricane clips and trusses or
other approved joist structures so as to provide sufficient structural
integrity to the unit as to ensure stability during storm events. All roofs
shall have a tarpaper base covered with asphalt shingles, cedar shake, slate,
or other approved weatherproof covering.
   (D)   All detached garages constructed or substantially rebuilt after March
15, 2005, shall have the following electrical components and specifications:
      (1)   Installed underground electrical service providing a minimum of 110
volts and at least two 20 ampere circuits;
      (2)   At least two wall-mounted duplex receptacles protected by ground
fault circuit interrupters;
      (3)   At least one overhead light fixture operated by a wall-mounted
switch;
      (4)   At least one overhead duplex receptacle for powering an overhead
garage door opener.
   (E)   For penalty, see §
150.999.
(Ord. 2005-O-5, passed 4-19-05)
RELOCATION OF BUILDINGS
§ 150.050 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to relocate a building which requires the utilization
of any public street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way within the village
without first having secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits
shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall state the name of the applicant, a
description of the building sought to be relocated, the present location of
said building, the exact location where said building is to be relocated, the
date on which the work pertaining to said relocation is to be commenced, the
date on which all work connected with said relocation is to be finalized, and
the person or firm who is to do the actual relocation or moving work. No such
permit shall be issued except on order of the Board of Trustees.
('79 Code, § 1608(1)) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.051 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   No permit shall be issued if the building sought to be moved or relocated
does not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances of the village.
Upon receipt of an application for a permit, the Village Clerk shall refer such
application to the proper officer for making an investigation or inspection and
said officer shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within five
days after receiving the application or a copy thereof.
('79 Code, § 1608(2))
§ 150.052 BOND REQUIRED.
   Each applicant shall file a bond, with surety to be approved by the Board of
Trustees, conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss or damage resulting
from the work undertaken or the manner of doing the same. Said bond shall be in
an amount of not less than $5,000.
('79 Code, § 1608(3))
§ 150.053 PERMIT FEE.
   The permit fee for relocating a single-family dwelling as defined by the
village zoning code (Chapter 154) shall be $200. Permit fees for other
buildings shall be determined by the Board of Trustees.
('79 Code, § 1608(4))
§ 150.054 NOTIFICATION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   The village Police Department shall be notified by the applicant concerning
the route to be traveled in moving and relocating said building, and the
proposed time schedule. Said route and proposed time schedule shall meet with
the approval of the Police Department of the village.
('79 Code, § 1608(5))
STREET ROADWAY CONSTRUCTION FOR NEW HOMES
§ 150.064 REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   When a person constructs one or more homes in a single block of a
previously platted subdivision, he or she shall improve the street roadway in
accordance with the requirements given herein and shall connect the street
roadway to a primary street as defined in §
152.005, the connection being in accordance with the requirements given herein.
   (B)   The roadway cross section shall be as shown in §1 of the Appendix
which follows this chapter. All materials and construction procedures shall be
in accordance with the Standard Specifications of Road and Bridge Construction,
State of Illinois, Department of Transportation, adopted July 1, 1976, or the
latest revision thereof.
   (C)   General plans for roadway improvements shall be submitted with the
application for a building permit. Building permits shall not be issued until
roadway improvements are complete or a sum of money equal to 125% of the
estimated cost of the street is put into escrow.
   (D)   The line and grade as well as drainage provisions of the proposed
roadway shall be subject to the review of the Village Engineer and the Public
Works Superintendent.
   (E)   When roadway construction is completed, an inspection by the
Superintendent of Public Works and the Engineer shall be requested. The
inspection shall be performed between 20 and 35 days after the date of request.
The purpose of this time lapse is to allow some exposure to weather and
traffic.
      (1)   Any defects noted during the inspection shall be remedied within 30
days after written notice by the Superintendent of Public Works or the Village
Engineer. When the corrective work has been performed to the satisfaction of
the Superintendent of Public Works and the Engineer, the Village Board of
Trustees may grant tentative approval. At this time monies escrowed as security
against road construction will be released. The developer will be required at
the same time to post a corporate surety bond in the amount of 10% of the cost
of roadway construction to guarantee maintenance of the roadway for a period of
one year from the date of tentative acceptance. Cash or a suitable bank letter
of credit may be substituted for the surety bond.
      (2)   When the aforesaid year has lapsed, the Superintendent of Public
Works and the Engineer shall perform a final inspection. Any remaining defects
shall be remedied within 15 days of final inspection. When this corrective work
has been performed, the Village Board shall grant final acceptance and at that
time the surety bond shall be released. Where unusual conditions so warrant,
the Village Board may alter the terms set forth in this section.
   (F)   Where it is intended the sanitary and/or storm sewers and/or water
mains be constructed as part of the complete street improvement, subgrade and
ditches shall be cut in prior to sewer and water main construction.
('79 Code, § 1609(1)) (Ord. 1979-O-16, passed 4-17-79) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.065 APPLICATION OF SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS.
   Nothing contained herein shall be construed so as to circumvent the
requirements of Chapter 152 Subdivision Regulations.
('79 Code, § 1609(2)) (Ord. 1979-O-16, passed 4-17-89)
SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION FOR NEW HOMES
§ 150.085 REQUIREMENTS.
   This section only applies to areas with concrete curbs and gutters.
   (A)   When a person constructs one or more homes in a single block of a
previously platted subdivision, he or she shall construct a concrete sidewalk
across the entire length of that portion of the lot or parcel of real estate on
which the residence or building to be constructed fronts, except that the
person constructing a dwelling on a corner lot shall also be required to
construct a sidewalk the entire length of the lot from the point where the
sidewalk ends at the front of the lot to the rear lot line.
   (B)   General plans for sidewalk construction shall be submitted with the
application for a building permit.
   (C)   Sidewalks constructed shall have a width of no less than five feet and
shall have a minimum thickness of five inches laid on a one-inch sand cushion
in all areas other than driveways. The property edge of the walk is to be
located 12 inches toward the street from the property line and the grade of the
walk shall be subject to the review of the Village Engineer and Public Works
Superintendent. The owner of the property is responsible for any surveys that
may be necessary to locate lot corner markers and for locating the line of the
sidewalk from such lot corner markers. In driveway areas, the thickness shall
be increased to a minimum thickness of seven inches laid on a one-inch sand
cushion.
      (1)   The sidewalk shall have a broom finish and shall be edged on both
sides. Traverse joints shall be struck at five-foot intervals and at every 50-
feet interval, a one-half inch expansion joint shall be placed. Likewise, one-
half inch expansion joint material shall be placed between adjacent structures
which shall include curb, gutter, old driveways, building foundations, old
sidewalk, traffic signals, light poles, and any other man-made structure.
      (2)   The sidewalk shall be cured with a state acceptable curing
compound. After the concrete has cured, all forms shall be removed, the area
disturbed shall be backfilled with black dirt graded to a net cross section
acceptable to the Building Commissioner, and seeded, to leave the area in a
neat and clean condition.
      (3)   Where practical, handicapped ramps should be constructed at all
intersections.
      (4)   All work shall be done in accordance with the applicable portions
of the State Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and
Bridge Construction adopted on October 1, 1983, and any subsequent revisions
made thereto.
   (D)   When sidewalk construction is complete, an inspection by the Building
Inspector shall be performed. Any defects shall be corrected by the owner
before an occupancy certificate is issued.
   (E)   The owner will be required to post a corporate surety bond in the
amount of 25% of the cost of the sidewalk construction to guarantee maintenance
of the sidewalk for a period of one year from date of acceptance. Cash or a
suitable bank letter of credit may be substituted for the surety bond. When the
aforesaid year has elapsed, the Building Inspector shall perform a final
inspection. Any defects shall be remedied within 15 days from the date on which
the owner is notified by the Building Inspector of the defects. After the
defects, if any, are corrected, the surety bond shall be released.
   (F)   Where unusual conditions so warrant, the Village Board of Trustees may
alter the terms set forth in this section.
('79 Code, § 1611(a) -(f)) (Ord. 1985-O-16, passed 8-6-85; Am. Ord. 1987-O-29,
passed 9-1-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.086 EXEMPTIONS.
   R-5 (Rural Subdivisions) shall be deemed exempt from the requirements of §
150.085.
('79 Code, § 1611(g)) (Ord. 1985-O-16, passed 8-6-85; Am. Ord. 1987-O-29,
passed 9-1-87)
SATELLITE ANTENNAS
§ 150.095 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DISH. That part of a satellite signal receiving antenna characteristically
shaped like a saucer or dish.
   DISH-TYPE SATELLITE SIGNAL-RECEIVING ANTENNAS, EARTH-STATIONS, or GROUND
STATIONS. One, or a combination of two or more of the following:
   (A)   A signal-receiving device (antenna, dish antenna, or dish-type
antenna), the purpose of which is to receive communication or other signals
from satellites in earth orbit and other extra-terrestrial sources.
   (B)   A low-noise amplifier (LNA) which is situated at the focal point of
the receiving component and the purpose of which is to magnify, store,
transfer, or transmit electronic or light signals.
   (C)   A coaxial cable, the purpose of which is to carry or transmit said
signals to a receiver.
   GROUNDING ROD. A metal pole permanently positioned in the earth to serve as
an electrical conductor through which electrical current may safely pass and
dissipate.
   RECEIVER. A television set or radio receiver.
('79 Code, § 1612(1) - (4)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.096 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, partnership, corporation, trust, or other legal entity
shall construct an earth station without a permit, nor shall construction
commence before a permit is issued by the Building Inspector.
('79 Code, § 1612(5)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.097 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE.
   (A)   The owner, or occupant with written permission from the owner, of any
lot, premises, or parcel of land within the village who desires to construct an
earth station on said lot, premises, or land parcel must first obtain a permit
to do so from the Building Commissioner.
   (B)   The Building Commissioner shall issue such permit, provided the
applicant submits a written application, along with a plot plan of the lot,
premises, or land parcel attached showing the exact location and dimensions of
the proposed earth station; a description of the kind of earth station
proposed; and the exact locations and dimensions of all buildings or
structures, showing the elevations of the proposed earth station upon
completion. Each application shall specify among other things the name and
address of the owner of the real estate and the applicant, the name of who
prepared the construction plans and specifications, and the person to be
permitted to construct the proposed earth station.
   (C)   The applicant shall present documentation of the possession of any
license or permit required by any federal, state, or local agency pertaining to
the ownership, construction, or operation of an earth station.
   (D)   The applicant shall submit with each application the sum of $50 which
represents the permit fee. The permit fee shall cover the costs of reviewing
the construction plans and specifications, inspecting the final construction,
and processing the application.
('79 Code, § 1612(6)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.098 GROUND-MOUNTED EARTH STATIONS.
   (A)   No earth station shall be constructed in any front yard, but, shall be
constructed to the rear or side of the residence or main structure.
   (B)   No earth station, including its concrete base slab or other
substructure, shall be constructed less than eight feet from any property line
or easement.
   (C)   No earth station shall be constructed without appropriate landscaping,
a fence, or other shield in order that said earth station can be reasonably
concealed from view; the manner of concealment to be approved by the Building
Commissioner.
   (D)   No earth station shall be linked, physically or electronically, to a
receiver which is not located on the same lot, premises, or parcel of land as
is the earth station.
   (E)   An earth station shall not exceed a great height of 12 feet.
   (F)   All structural supports shall be of galvanized metal.
   (G)   Wiring between an earth station and a receiver shall be placed at
least four inches beneath the surface of the ground within rigid conduit.
   (H)   Such earth station shall be designed to withstand a wind force of 75
miles per hour without the use of supporting guy wires.
   (I)   Any driving motor shall be limited to 110 volt maximum power design
and be encased in protective guards.
   (J)   An earth station must be bonded to a grounding rod.
   (K)   Only one earth station on a lot.
   (1)   Earth stations can only be used for non-commercial use.
('79 Code, § 1612(7)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.099 ROOF-MOUNTED EARTH STATIONS.
   (A)   Earth stations shall be mounted directly upon the roof of a primary or
accessory structure, as defined in this chapter and shall not be mounted upon
appurtenances such as chimneys, towers, trees, poles, or spires.
   (B)   An earth station shall not exceed a height of more than three feet
above the roof upon which it is mounted.
   (C)   An earth station dish shall not exceed three feet in diameter.
   (D)   An earth station shall be designed to withstand a wind force of 85
miles per hour without the use of supporting guy wires.
   (E)   Any driving motor shall be limited to 110 volt maximum power design
and be encased in protective guards.
   (F)   An earth station must be bonded to a grounding rod.
('79 Code, § 1612(8)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.100 APPEALS.
   Appeals from decisions of the Building Commissioner concerning dish-type
satellite antennas shall be made to the Board of Zoning Appeals.
('79 Code, § 1612(9)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87)
ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS
§ 150.110 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR. Any person engaged in the business of installing or
altering by contract, equipment and electricity supplied for light, heat, or
power not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of
sounds and signals, and not including apparatus, conductors, and other
equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers,
which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission for use in
their operation as public utilities; but the term ELECTRICAL CONTRACTOR does
not include employees employed by such contractor to supervise such work.
('79 Code, § 1613(1)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.111 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to alter, repair,
or install any electrical equipment in the city without first complying with
this subchapter.
('79 Code, § 1613(2)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.112 REGISTRATION OF CONTRACTORS.
   Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contracting
shall apply for registration to the Electrical Inspector stating the name and
the place of business of the applicant and the name of the representative of
the applicant who will act as supervisor of the work to be done under the
registration. Such application shall be accompanied by satisfactory affidavit
that the applicant or the applicant's representative has had at least five
years practical experience installing and altering electrical equipment.
('79 Code, § 1613(3)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.113 EXAMINATION PREREQUISITE TO REGISTRATION.
   Before a certificate of registration shall be issued, the applicant or the
applicant's representative shall, following reasonable advance notice, present
himself for examination before the Electrical Inspector at a time and place set
by him. Said Inspector shall examine such applicant as to the applicant's
practical knowledge of the installation and alteration of electrical equipment
and knowledge of the rules and regulations for the installation of electrical
wiring devices and equipment as set forth in this chapter and in the latest
standards issued by the National Board of Fire Underwriters as recommended by
the National Fire Protection Association and approved by the American Standards
Association. Such examination shall be in whole or in part in writing and shall
be of a practical character as determined by the Electrical Inspector but
sufficiently strict to thoroughly test the experience and qualifications of the
applicant.
('79 Code, § 1613(4)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.114 ENTITLE TO CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   Any person who shall have filed proper application, and later shall have
satisfactorily passed the examination required under §
150.113, shall be entitled to receive a certificate of registration to do
electrical work and to engage in the business of electrical work and to engage
in the business of electrical contracting in the Village.
('79 Code, § 1613(5)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.115 USE OF INVALID CERTIFICATE.
   (A)   No person granted a certificate of registration under the provisions
of this chapter shall install or repair electrical equipment for electric
light, heat, or power purposes after the expiration of such certificate of
registration or after such certificate shall have been revoked as herein
provided unless the said certificate of registration has been renewed and the
fee paid as provided herein.
   (B)   Certificates of registration issued by the Electrical Inspector shall
not be loaned, rented, assigned, or transferred. Each and every certificate of
registration may, after hearing, be suspended or revoked by the Board of
Trustees upon the recommendation of the Electrical Inspector upon failure or
refusal of the electrical contractor to comply with the rules and requirements
of the Electrical Inspector, or the provisions of this chapter.
('79 Code, § 1613(6)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.116 REGISTRATION FEE.
   The annual fee for registering as an electrical contractor shall be $25;
provided that an application made after the expiration of the first six months
of the register year shall be issued upon the payment of a fee of $12.50. The
register year shall correspond with the license year.
('79 Code, § 1613(7)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87)
§ 150.117 OUT-OF-TOWN CONTRACTORS.
   (A)   Any electrical contractor who is registered as such in any other city
or village in the state shall not be required to pay a fee for being registered
in this village; but every person doing business in this village as an
electrical contractor shall secure a certificate of registration before
commencing of altering, repairing, or installing any electrical work.
   (B)   Such certificate shall be issued without charge to electrical
contractors registered as such under the ordinances of another city or village
in this state.
('79 Code, § 1613(8)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.118 OBEDIENCE TO REGULATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person registered under the provisions of this
subchapter to install any electrical appliances, wiring, or fixtures without
strict compliance with the ordinances relating to such fixtures. It shall be
unlawful for any such person to do any such work without having obtained such
permits as may be required.
('79 Code, § 1613(9)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87) Penalty, see §
150.999
§ 150.119 ELECTRICAL COMMISSION.
   (A)   The Electrical Commission shall be appointed by the President with the
advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees.
   (B)   The Electrical Commission shall:
      (1)   Review the test administered by the Electrical Inspector.
      (2)   Rewrite or alter the test as needed.
      (3)   Set reasonable rules and regulations on the issuance of permits by
the Electrical Inspector.
      (4)   Set reasonable fees to be paid for inspection by the Electrical
Inspector of all electrical equipment installed or altered within the
municipality.
      (5)   Recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the
installation, alteration, and use of electrical equipment within the
municipality.
      (6)   Any person or contractor denied a permit or certificate of
registration has the right to a hearing before the Electrical Commission which
shall have the power to override the Electrical Inspector.
   (C)   The Electrical Commission shall consist of the following six members:
      (1)   The Electrical Inspector shall be a member and ex officio Chairman
of the Commission.
      (2) A registered professional engineer.
      (3) An electrical contractor.
      (4) A journeyman electrician.
      (5) A representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the Fire
Underwriters. If no such representative resides in the municipality then the
chief of the Fire Department shall take the representative's place.
      (6) A representative of an electrical supply company.
   If there is no person residing in the municipality who is qualified or
willing to serve under any one of these descriptions, the President with the
advice and consent of the Village Board may appoint some other person to fill
that position.
('79 Code, § 1613(10)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87)
UNIFORM ELECTRICAL CODE
§ 150.130 [RESERVED].
§ 150.131 REGULATIONS OF ELECTRICAL UTILITY ADOPTED.
   The rules and regulations regarding the installation, alteration, and use of
electrical equipment as last adopted by the electricity supply company
supplying the village as last published, and filed with the Illinois Commerce
Commission and as approved by the Village Electrical Commission are hereby
adopted.
(Ord. 1989-O-24, passed 7-18-89)
§ 151.132 FILING; INCORPORATION OF CODE AND REGULATIONS.
   A copy of the code and rules and regulations adopted by this subchapter are
on file in the office of the Chief Electrical Inspector and the provisions of
this code and those rules and regulations are hereby made a part of this code.
(Ord. 1989-O-24, passed 7-18-89)
CELL TOWERS
§ 150.150 CELL TOWER PREFERRED PLACEMENT.
   In order to ensure the maximum retention of value of existing and planned
housing, from and after the effective date of this amendatory ordinance, any
and all persons, companies or corporations wishing to site a cellular telephone
tower within the village shall be required to place it first, upon property
zoned “MP,” and if no such property is available or if no available sites are
technologically feasible to install such a tower, the tower shall be installed
on property owned by a school district. If, and only if, no site meeting the
foregoing is available or technologically feasible, the tower may be installed,
in order of preference, upon property zoned Industrial, upon property zoned B-
3, upon property zoned B-2 or upon property B-1. The Zoning Administrator shall
receive and review all such permit applications and approve or deny them based
on the foregoing criteria. The decision of the Zoning Administrator on all such
applications may be appealed to the Village Board.
(Ord. 2002-O-6, passed 2-19-02)
§ 150.151 RESIDENTIAL PLACEMENT OF CELL TOWER REGULATIONS.
   Only where the person, company or corporation wishing to site a tower can
prove to the Planning and Zoning Board and the Village Board by clear and
convincing evidence that no other location is possible, available or
technologically feasible may the tower be sited in any residential
neighborhood. Any such request to site a tower in a residential area shall be
filed with the Zoning Administrator and public notice shall be given by the
applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested, to all owners of record
of property located within 500 feet of the boundaries of the proposed site.
Such mailed notice shall be given not less than 30 days nor more than 45 days
prior to the hearing. Notice of the hearing and application shall also be
published in a newspaper of general circulation within the village on three
consecutive weeks not less than 14 days prior to the hearing, nor more than 45
days prior thereto. The initial hearing shall be conducted before the Planning
and Zoning Board, who shall take testimony from the applicant and all
interested persons. At the conclusion of the testimony, the Board shall
thereupon take a vote and make a recommendation to the Village Board to approve
or deny the permit based on the evidence presented. The Village Board shall
consider the application within 14 days thereafter, and shall act without
taking further evidence or conducting any further examination of any persons
under oath. Where the Planning and Zoning Board has recommended against the
proposed siting, a three-fifths majority of the Village Board shall be required
to approve the same.
(Ord. 2002-O-6, passed 2-19-02)
§ 150.152 CELL TOWER SITING APPLICATION FEES.
   Any application for the siting of a cellular telephone tower shall be
accompanied by the following fees:
   For any tower proposed for MP zoned property      $100
   For any tower proposed for school district property      +$200
   For any tower proposed in I zoned property         $500
   For any tower proposed in any B zoned district      $10,000
   For any tower proposed in any R zoned district      $20,000
(Ord. 2002-O-6, passed 2-19-02)
BUILDING PLAN STANDARDS
§ 150.160 BUILDING PLAN STANDARDS.
   All plans submitted to the Building Department relative to any existing
permit or permit application shall be:
   (A)   Submitted in triplicate; two paper copies and one electronic copy;
   (B)   In the form of blueprints, bluelines or other readily legible
reproduction;
   (C)   Of a size sufficient to legibly show all details necessary for review;
   (D)   Not larger than 24 inches × 36 inches;
   (E)   On white opaque paper of not less than 20 # weight;
   (F)   Prepared by an Illinois Licensed Design Professional;
   (G)   Accompanied by all required fees and deposits.
   Exception: The Building Official is authorized to waive the submission of
construction documents and other data not required to be prepared by an
Illinois Licensed Design Professional if it is found that the nature of the
work applied for is such that reviewing of construction documents is not
necessary to obtain compliance with the code.
(Ord. 2002-O-25, passed 7-2-02; Am. Ord. 2018-O-15, passed 10-16-18)
§ 150.161 REJECTION BY BUILDING DEPARTMENT.
   Any plan which, in the discretion of the Building Department, fails to meet
the standards established in §
150.160 shall be rejected and the applicant advised to resubmit plans
conforming to these standards.
(Ord. 2002-O-25, passed 7-2-02; Am. Ord. 2018-O-15, passed 10-16-18)
§ 150.162 BUILDING DEPARTMENT REVIEW.
   The village Building Department’s plan reviewers shall review all plans
properly submitted in accordance with the then current building codes and
amendments adopted by the village, where appropriate, and in the event the
reviewers determine that the plans submitted fail to meet the standards called
for in these codes, the plan reviewers shall have the discretion to reject the
plans.
(Ord. 2002-O-25, passed 7-2-02; Am. Ord. 2018-O-15, passed 10-16-18)
§ 150.163 RESUBMISSION OF PLANS.
   Any applicant submitting plans that have been rejected previously shall bear
the full expense of any additional plan review, and shall submit an appropriate
deposit at the time the plans are resubmitted.
(Ord. 2002-O-25, passed 7-2-02; Am. Ord. 2018-O-15, passed 10-16-18)
§ 150.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no other
penalty exists shall be fined not more than $500 for each offense, and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day which a violation
continues or exists.
   (B)   Any person, firm, or corporate violating any provision of §§
150.010 through
150.022 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25 nor more than $500 for
such offense, and each day on which the violation continues shall be considered
a separate offense.
('79 Code, § 1606(14))
   (C)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating §
150.035 shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $500 for each offense,
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and every day during
which a violation continues or exists.
('79 Code, § 1607(5))
   (D)   Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provisions of §§
150.050 through
150.054 shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $200 for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or is continued.
('79 Code, § 1608(6))
   (E)   All persons, firms, or corporations violating any of the provisions of
§
150.064, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof
shall be fined in an amount not less than $25 nor more than $200. Each day such
violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate
offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
('79 Code, § 1609(3)) (Ord. 1979-O-16, passed 4-17-79)
   (F)   All persons, firms, or corporations violating any of the provisions of
§
150.085 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof
shall be fined in an amount not less than $25 nor more than $200. Each day such
violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate
offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
('79 Code, § 1611(3)) (Ord. 1987-O-12, passed - -87)
   (G)   All persons, firms, or corporations violating any of the provisions of
§§
150.095 through
150.100 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof
shall be fined in an amount not less than $25 nor more than $200. Each day such
violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate
offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
('79 Code, § 1612(10)) (Ord. 1987-O-15, passed 4-7-87)
   (H)   Any willful failure or refusal to comply with §§
150.110 through
150.119 constitutes a petty offense punishable upon conviction by a fine of not
less than $25 nor more than $50 for each offense.
   (I)   Nothing in this section or chapter may be construed to impose any fine
or penalty, nor to impose regulations of any kind, nor to stand for the
proposition that the village has the power to enforce regulations against
licensed plumbers or plumbing contractors, since state law grants exclusive
powers in these areas to the Illinois Department of Public Health. Accordingly,
all alleged violations of the Illinois Plumbing Code will be referred to the
Illinois Department of Public Health, consistent with the requirements of the
Plumbing Licensing Law (ILCS Ch. 225, Act 320).
('79 Code, § 1613(11)) (Ord. 1987-O-14, passed 4-7-87; Am. Ord. 2015-O-19,
passed 8-18-15)
