GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 151.001 TITLE.
   The provisions contained within the following sections of this chapter shall
be known as the "Housing Code of the Village of Winthrop Harbor, Lake County,
Illinois" and may be cited as such and will be referred to herein as "this
code".
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.002 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to provide safeguards to life or limb, public
health, safety, and welfare of occupants of buildings or structures used in
whole or in part for human habitation by providing minimum standards regulating
building maintenance, area, light and ventilation, sanitation, and fire safety.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.003 SCOPE.
   (A)   Provisions and regulations contained in this chapter shall apply to
buildings and structures, or portions thereof, used for residential occupancies
or human habitation, and all accessory buildings and structures thereto,
located within the corporate limits of the village, and shall include
dwellings, multi- family dwellings, apartments, and buildings and structures
used as hotels, motels, tourist homes, rooming and boarding houses, rest and
nursing homes, dormitories, club houses and any other facility where space is
provided for living or sleeping of three or more persons not related to the
owner or operator, and such buildings of residential or dwelling occupancy may
be referred to herein as the building, structure, or premises.
   (B)   Owner occupied single-family dwellings and buildings of two-family
dwellings shall be exempt from provisions of this chapter when a valid and
current certificate of occupancy has been issued and is effective on the
building or structure and all additions or appurtenances thereto, except;
complaint and determination of the maintenance of a hazard or nuisance in
violation of provisions of this chapter shall constitute cause to invoke
provisions of this chapter on owner occupied single-family dwellings or
buildings of two-family dwellings.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.004 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   (A)   This chapter shall become effective January 19, 1965.
   (B)   No provision of this chapter shall be held to deprive any governmental
authority, or department thereof having jurisdiction, of any power or authority
it held on January 19, 1965 or of any remedy then existing for the enforcement
of its orders, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal
rights as provided by law.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.005 CONFLICT OF ORDINANCES.
   In event a provision of this chapter is in conflict with a provision of the
zoning, building, fire, safety or health ordinances as applicable to the
health, safety, and welfare of occupants, the more restrictive provisions shall
apply.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.006 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ACCESSORY STRUCTURE. A building which use is incidental to that of the main
building and which is located upon the same lot.
   ACCESSORY USE. An occupancy use incidental to the principal use of a
building as defined or limited by provisions of the zoning chapter.
   ADDITION. An extension or increase in floor area or height of a building or
structure.
   ALTERATIONS. A change or rearrangement in the structural parts or exit
facilities of a building or structure, or an enlargement by extending the
exterior walls or by increasing the height, or by moving from one location or
position to another.
   APARTMENT. One or more rooms comprising a dwelling unit or serving as the
home or residence of an individual, or a family or household.
   APARTMENT BUILDING. A building or structure containing more than two
dwelling units or apartments.
   APPROVED. The approval of the Building Official or other authority having
jurisdiction.
   APPURTENANT STRUCTURE. A device or structure attached to the exterior or
erected on the roof of a building.
   ATTIC. The space between the ceiling joists of the top habitable story and
the roof rafters.
   BALCONY, EXTERIOR. An appurtenance to a structure supported on the
structural members of the building extending beyond the main walls of the
building more than four feet above grade.
   BASEMENT. That portion of a building partly underground, and having more
than one-half of its clear height above the average grade of the adjoining
ground.
   BUILDING. A structure enclosed within exterior walls built, erected, and
framed of component structural parts and designed for the housing, shelter,
enclosure, and support of individuals, animals, or property of any kind.
   BUILDING CODE. The regulations and amendments thereto regulating building
construction within the village, and includes the plumbing code, electrical
code, heating code, and amendments thereto.
   BUILDING LINE. The line or limits established by law beyond which the
building or structure shall not extend.
   BUILDING OFFICIAL. The officer or other designated authority charged with
enforcement of this chapter.
   CELLAR. That portion of a building wholly or partly underground and having
one-half or more
of its clear height below the average grade of the adjoining ground.
   CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY. The certificate issued by the building official
which permits the use of a building or structure in accordance with approved
plans and specifications and which certified compliance with provisions of law
for the use and occupancy of the building in its several parts together with
any special stipulations or conditions of the building permit.
   CHANGE OF USE. An alteration by change of use or occupancy of a building
heretofore existing to a new use group which imposes other special provisions
of law governing building construction, equipment, or exits.
   CORRIDOR. An enclosed passageway leading to a means of legal egress.
   DORMITORY. A building arranged for lodging individuals and having common
toilet and bathroom facilities.
   DUPLEX. A building containing two dwelling units located on a single level
and completely separated by a party wall or located on separate floors with
complete separation.
   DWELLING, ONE-FAMILY. A building containing one dwelling unit.
   DWELLING, TWO-FAMILY. A building containing two dwelling units completely
separated by a party wall or floor and ceiling and containing separate toilet,
bathing, and cooking facilities.
   DWELLING UNIT. One or more rooms arranged for use of one or more individuals
living together as a family, with cooking, living, sanitary, and sleeping
facilities.
   ELECTRICAL CODE. The regulations and amendments thereto regulating the
installations of electrical equipment, appliances, wiring, and power in
buildings.
   ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR. The official or other designated authority charged
with the enforcement of provisions of the electrical code.
   ELECTRICAL SERVICE EQUIPMENT. The equipment located at a point of entrance
of supply conductors to a building which constitutes the main control of supply
and cut-off of electricity and including circuit breakers, switches, fuses,
wiring, and electrical accessories.
   EXIT. A continuous and unobstructed means of egress to a public way, and
shall include intervening doorways, corridors, ramps, stairways, smokeproof
towers, horizontal exits, exterior courts, and yards.
   EXTERMINATION. The process of ridding the premises or building of insects or
rodents.
   FAMILY. One or more persons related by blood or marriage, or not more than
three persons not related by blood or marriage, living together as a single
housekeeping unit.
   FIRE CHIEF. The official or other designated authority charged with
enforcement of fire prevention and safety regulations and ordinances.
   FLOOR AREA. The area included within surrounding walls of a building or
portion thereof exclusive of vent shafts and courts.
   GARBAGE. The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking, and consumption of food.
   GUEST. Any person hiring or occupying a room for living or sleeping
purposes.
   HABITABLE ROOM. A room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used
for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes.
   HEALTH OFFICER. The official or other designated authority charged with
enforcement of health regulations and ordinances.
   HEATING INSPECTOR. The official or other designated authority charged with
enforcement or ordinances regulating the installation and operation of heating
equipment in building.
   HOTEL. Any building containing six or more rooms and intended or designed to
be used, rented, or hired out to be occupied by guests for sleeping purposes.
   INFESTATION. The presence, within or around a dwelling or dwelling unit of
insects, rodents, or other pests.
   LOT. A portion or parcel of land considered as a unit.
   LOT LINE. The line dividing one lot from another, or from the street or
other public space.
   MIXED OCCUPANCY USES. The use of a building structure or premises thereof by
more than one distinct occupancy classification.
   MULTIPLE DWELLING. Any building containing more than two dwelling units.
   OCCUPANCY. The purpose for which a building is used or intended to be used,
and a change of occupancy is not intended to include change of tenants or
proprietors.
   OCCUPANT. Any person living, sleeping, cooking, or eating in, or having
actual possession of a dwelling or rooming unit.
   OPERATOR. Any person who has charge, care, or control of a building or part
thereof in which dwelling or rooming units are let.
   OWNER. Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others, shall have
legal title to any dwelling or dwelling unit, with or without accompanying
actual possession thereof; or, shall have charge, care, or control of any
dwelling or dwelling unit as owner, as agent of the owner, or as executor,
administrator, trustee, or guardian of the estate of the owner.
   PLUMBING. Includes, but shall not be limited to, gas pipes, gas-burning
equipment, water pipes, garbage disposal units, waste pipes, water closets,
sinks, installed dishwashers, lavatories, bathtubs, shower baths, installed
clothes-washing machines, catch basins, drains, vents and similar fixtures,
septic tanks and water wells, and all connections to water, sewer, and gas
lines.
   PLUMBING INSPECTOR. The official or other designated authority charged with
enforcement of ordinances regulating plumbing.
   ROOMING HOUSE. Any dwelling, or portion thereof, containing one or more
rooming units in which space is let by the owner or operator to three or more
persons not related by blood or marriage to the owner or operator.
   ROOMING UNIT. Any room or enclosure or group of rooms forming a single
habitable unit used or intended to be used for living or sleeping.
   RUBBISH. Combustible or non-combustible waste materials and shall include
ashes and discarded papers, wood, metals, glass, or tree limbs among others.
   SUPPLIED. Paid for, furnished, or provided by or under control of the owner
or operator.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
   ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 151.015 ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   The Building Official is hereby authorized and directed to administer
and enforce all provisions and regulations contained in this chapter within the
corporate limits of the village, and for such purposes shall have the powers of
a police officer.
   (B)   Where jurisdiction exists or is established by provisions of this
chapter, the Fire Chief, Health Officer, or other designated official as
defined herein shall enforce all provisions of this chapter as applicable
jointly with the Building Official.
('79 Code, § 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.016 INTERPRETATIONS, RULINGS, AND ORDERS.
   Interpretation of provisions of this chapter and rulings or orders under its
provisions shall be made and issued by the Building Official. Any person
affected may appeal such interpretation, ruling, or order as provided herein.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.017 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Building Official is hereby authorized to make and adopt such rules and
regulations subject to approval of the Village Board of Trustees as are deemed
necessary for proper enforcement of this chapter.
('79 Code, § 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.018 BUILDINGS OF MIXED OCCUPANCY USES.
   Buildings or structures of mixed occupancy uses containing dwelling units
shall for purposes of administration of this chapter be classified as multi-
family dwellings.
('79 Code, § 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.019 CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
   No building or structure of dwelling occupancy shall be occupied unless a
current and valid certificate of occupancy is effective as provided by the
building code, and in all buildings or structures other than one- and two-
family dwellings the certificate of occupancy shall be retained at all times
upon the premises.
('79 Code, § 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.020 CONSTRUCTION.
   All construction of buildings or structures and additions, alterations, and
repairs thereto and the installation of equipment and appliances therein
required for conformance to the provisions of this chapter shall conform to
provisions of the building code and other applicable ordinances and regulations
of the village, and all required permits and fees shall be obtained and paid.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.021 ISSUANCE OF BUILDING PERMITS.
   The Building Official, Plumbing Inspector, Electrical Inspector, or Heating
Inspector shall not issue a permit for the erection, construction, or
alteration of any building or installation of appliances or equipment therein,
which is used or intended to be used for a dwelling unit, unless the building
or installations therein are designed to conform to provisions of this chapter
and provisions of the zoning chapter, building code, and other applicable
ordinances.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.022 INSPECTION.
   (A)   The Building Official shall inspect all buildings or dwelling
occupancy, except one- or two-family dwelling units, and the premises thereof,
not less than once each year.
   (B)   The Building Official or other designated official as provided by this
chapter, may for purposes of this chapter enter, inspect, examine, and survey
at all reasonable times such buildings, structures, and premises subject to
provisions of this chapter.
   (C)   The owner or occupant of buildings, structures, and premises or
portions thereof, subject to provisions of this chapter, or the person in
charge thereof, shall give the Building Official free access to all portions of
the building, structure, or premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of
inspection, examination, or survey.
   (D)   Upon reasonable assumption that the building, structure, or premises
constitute an immediate hazard or emergency to life, safety, or health of the
occupants or community the Building Official is hereby granted authority to
enter said building, structure, or premises at any and all times for purposes
of inspection, examination, and survey.
   (E)   Each occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall give the owner
thereof, or the owner's agent or employee, access to all portions of the
dwelling or dwelling unit, or its premises at all reasonable times for purposes
of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect
compliance with provisions of this chapter or with any rule, regulation, or
order issued pursuant to provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.023 BUILDING VIOLATIONS.
   Upon determination that a building, structure, or premises is in violation
of this chapter or of rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, the
Building Official shall issue a written notice of violation, said notice to
include the following:
   (A)   Detailed specification of violations;
   (B)   Date by which the violations as set forth in division (A) must be
corrected; and
   (C)   Date of issuance of notice and time within which a request for an
appeals hearing may be filed.
('79 Code, § 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.024 NOTICE OF VIOLATION.
   Notice of violation shall be served in the following manner:
   (A)   By serving copies thereof upon the owner and occupant of the building,
structure, or premises personally, or by sending copies of notice by certified
mail to the said owner and occupant. A lessee shall be considered to be an
occupant for purposes of this section.
   (B)   Where, upon diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of the owner
or owners of any such building, structure, or premises is not ascertainable,
notice mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real estate was last
assessed is sufficient notice under this section.
   (C)   Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act required to
affect compliance with provisions of this chapter.
   (D)   Contain a brief outline of remedial action to effect compliance with
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.025 CONDEMNED AND PLACARDED PROPERTY; NOTICE.
   (A)   When the Building Official or other enforcement official as designated
herein determines that a building, structure, or premises are so damaged,
decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, or vermin-infested that it creates a serious
and immediate hazard to the health or safety of the occupants or public or
community, the Building Official shall condemn and placard said dwelling,
dwelling unit, or structure and issue an emergency order as set forth in §
151.026.
   (B)   Prior notice under this section shall not be required. Within 24 hours
after such dwelling or structure is placarded, a copy of the emergency order
shall be served in the manner set forth in §
151.024 and the owner or occupant shall be entitled to a hearing before the
Appeals Board not later than three days after the date on which the owner or
occupant serves the Building Official with a written request for same.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.026 EMERGENCY ORDERS.
   When the Building Official finds an emergency exists which requires
immediate corrective action to safety and public health, the Building Official
may without notice or hearing issued an order reciting the facts which
constitute the emergency and requiring such action be taken as the Building
Official deems necessary to meet the emergency; the order shall be effective
upon service, and the person to whom the order is directed shall comply
immediately.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.027 VACATING OF PREMISES.
   (A)   The occupants of any dwelling or dwelling unit condemned and placarded
as dangerous or unfit for human habitation shall vacate the dwelling or
dwelling unit within a reasonable time as ordered by the Building Official.
   (B)   When in the judgment of the Building Official an emergency exists
which constitutes an immediate hazard to occupants, the Building Official may
order the immediate vacating of the premises, and any person failing to comply
with the order shall be held in violation of this chapter.
   (C)   No dwelling or dwelling unit which has been condemned as dangerous or
unfit for human habitation shall be used for human habitation until corrective
measures to elimination of the basis of the condemnation action have been
completed and written approval of the Building Official obtained, and the
placard removed from the premises by the Building Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.028 REMOVAL OF CONDEMNATION PLACARD.
   No person shall deface or remove the placard from any dwelling or dwelling
unit condemned as dangerous or unfit for human habitation except, upon written
approval of the Building Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.029 VACANT STRUCTURES.
   Any dwelling or dwelling unit vacated by order of the Building Official and
vacant for more than 20 days shall have its doors and windows effectively
locked and boarded to prevent entry.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.030 DEMOLITION OF STRUCTURES.
   The Building Official may certify any dwelling or dwelling unit which has
been condemned and placarded to the Building and Zoning Committee of the Board
of Trustees to be demolished in accordance with provisions of the Building Code
for unsafe buildings.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.031 APPEALS.
   (A)   Any person affected by a notice of violation, interpretation, ruling,
or order issued under provisions of this chapter may file a written request for
a hearing before the Board of Appeals under procedures of the Board of Appeals,
and said request shall include a brief statement of the basis for appeal
action.
   (B)   If no request for a hearing before the Board of Appeals is filed
within 15 days of date of notice of violation, the notice of violation shall
constitute a final determination that a violation exists and a final order to
corrective action described in the notice.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
OWNER AND OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITIES
§ 151.040 BURDEN OF RESPONSIBILITY; COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS REQUIRED.
   (A)   The responsibility for maintaining buildings or structures of dwelling
occupancy, appurtenances and accessory structures, and premises and lands
thereto, in a clean, safe, sanitary, and healthful condition and repair at all
times to conform to provisions of this chapter shall be shared jointly by the
owner and occupants as defined herein and as provided in this section, except,
for purposes of administration and enforcement of this chapter, the owner shall
be held responsible and liable for any violations thereof and penalties
assessed under provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   No person shall occupy as owner, or let to another for occupancy any
dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or
eating therein, which does not comply with provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.041 PUBLIC AREAS.
   Every owner of a dwelling containing two or more dwelling units shall
maintain in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the
dwelling and premises thereof.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.042 OCCUPANT'S RESPONSIBILITY.
   Every occupancy of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall keep in a clean and
sanitary condition that part of the dwelling, dwelling unit, and premises
thereof which the occupant occupies and controls.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.043 RUBBISH AND GARBAGE DISPOSAL.
   (A)   Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all
rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the rubbish disposal
facilities or rubbish containers.
   (B)   Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all
garbage and any other organic waste which might provide food for rodents, in a
clean and sanitary manner, by placing it in garbage disposal facilities or
garbage containers.
   (C)   The owner shall supply such garbage facilities or containers for all
dwelling units in a dwelling containing two or more dwelling units and shall
provide for removal of same. In all other cases the occupant shall supply such
facilities or containers and removal.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.044 RODENT AND INSECT CONTROL.
   (A)   Every occupant of a dwelling containing a single dwelling unit shall
exterminate any insect, rodent, or other pests therein or on the premises; and
every occupant of a dwelling unit in a building containing two or more dwelling
units shall be responsible for such extermination wherever the occupant's
dwelling unit is the only one infested.
   (B)   When infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a
dwelling in a rodent-proof or reasonably insect-proof condition, extermination
and prevention of further infestation shall be the responsibility of the owner.
   (C)   Termite extermination shall be the sole responsibility of the owner.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.045 PLUMBING.
   Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall keep all plumbing fixtures therein
in a clean and sanitary condition and shall exercise reasonable care in the
proper use and operation thereof.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.046 EQUIPMENT AND APPLIANCES.
   Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall maintain reasonable care in the
operation and maintenance of such heating equipment, electrical fixtures,
appliances, and other equipment or appliances supplied by the owner.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.047 WEED CONTROL.
   Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall be responsible for weed control on
all portions of the premises the occupant controls and the owner shall be
responsible for all other portions of the premises.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.048 SNOW REMOVAL.
   Snow shall be removed from all areas of the premises used by the public and
the occupant shall be responsible for portions of the premises the occupant
controls and the owner shall be responsible for all other portions of the
premises.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
STRUCTURAL REQUIREMENTS AND MAINTENANCE
§ 151.060 COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS REQUIRED.
   (A)   No dwelling unit or building of dwelling occupancy shall hereafter be
constructed, created, altered, or reconstructed which does not comply with
provisions of this chapter, and no dwelling unit shall be altered in its space,
area, use, or arrangement in a manner which shall decrease its compliance with
provisions of this section and this chapter.
   (B)   All structural alterations or additions to existing buildings shall
comply with provisions of the building code as applies to new construction.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.061 PLUMBING; ELECTRIC WIRING; HEATING; EQUIPMENT.
   All plumbing, electric wiring, heating equipment, and other facilities,
utilities, and appliances or equipment which is required under provisions of
this chapter shall be constructed and installed in conformance with applicable
ordinances and to function safely and effectively, and shall be maintained in
satisfactory working condition.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.062 FOUNDATION; FLOORS; ROOF.
   Every foundation, floor, wall ceiling, and roof shall be reasonably
weathertight, watertight, and rodent-proof; shall be capable of affording
privacy; and shall be kept in good repair.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.063 WINDOWS AND DOORS.
   Every window, exterior door, and basement hatchway shall be reasonably
weathertight, watertight, rodent-proof, and insect-proof, and shall be kept in
sound working condition and good repair.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.064 SCREENS.
   (A)   Every basement or cellar window which is openable shall be supplied
with a heavy wire screen or hardware cloth of not less than four mesh per inch
fitted tightly and securely fastened to
the frame, or such other material providing equivalent protection against entry
of rodents.
   (B)   From April 15th to November 15th of each year every window and every
door of a dwelling unit opening directly to the exterior or other openings used
for ventilation and opening directly to the exterior of the building shall be
supplied with a screen of not less than 16 mesh per inch and every such door
shall be equipped with a spring or self-closing device maintained in good
working condition.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.065 STAIRS AND PORCHES.
   Every inside and outside stair, every porch, and every appurtenance thereto
shall be constructed to be safe to use, and shall be kept in sound condition
and good repair to support any load that normal use may place thereon.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.066 BATHROOMS AND WATER CLOSET COMPARTMENTS.
   Every water closet compartment floor surface and bathroom floor surface
shall be constructed as required by the building code and maintained so as to
be reasonably impervious to water and so as to permit such floor to be easily
kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.067 STORAGE.
   (A)   Storage of combustible materials under stairways or in halls or
corridors, or an accumulation of rubbish upon the premises shall not be
permitted.
   (B)   Storage of explosives or inflammable liquids on the premises shall not
be permitted.
   (C)   Paints, lacquers, or finishes shall not be stored in quantity in
excess of current maintenance requirements and shall be in sealed containers
and stored in an enclosed cabinet or area.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.068 DISRUPTION OF UTILITY SERVICES.
   Services, facilities, equipment, or utilities required under provisions of
this chapter shall not be removed from, shut off, or discontinued from any
occupied dwelling unit, except:
   (A)   For such temporary interruption as may be necessary while repair or
alterations are in process.
   (B)   During temporary emergency when discontinuance of service is ordered
by an authorized official.
   (C)   When service is discontinued for cause by a public utility or
municipal service, and the Building Official notified.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
MEANS OF EGRESS
§ 151.080 UNOBSTRUCTED MEANS OF EGRESS.
   Required means of egress to the exterior from each dwelling unit shall be
unobstructed and shall lead directly to the exterior at ground level and upon a
safe and open space leading directly to the street or yard or shall open upon a
hall, corridor, or public area of the building as provided herein, with direct
access to the exterior of the building at ground level.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.081 REQUIRED MEANS OF EGRESS.
   (A)   Every building of single-family dwelling occupancy shall have not less
than one means of egress to the exterior, except such buildings of more than
600 square feet of floor area and more than two stories in height shall have
not less than two means of egress to the exterior, each accessible to all areas
and portions of the building.
   (B)   Every building of two or more dwelling units located above or below
the ground floor shall have not less than two means of egress to the exterior
and each shall be directly accessible to all areas and portions of the
building.
   (C)   Windows shall not be considered as required means of egress.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.082 HALLS OR CORRIDORS.
   Halls and corridors of buildings of multi-family occupancy above or below
the ground floor serving as means of egress shall lead directly to a stairway
leading to a means of egress to the exterior at ground level and such halls or
corridors shall contain no dead ends extending more than ten feet beyond a
stairway leading to the ground floor.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.083 REQUIRED WIDTHS.
   Required widths of halls, corridors, stairs, and doors serving as a required
means of egress shall be not less than 30 inches in clear widths and the
required widths shall be calculated from the occupant capacities of all areas
of the building as provided by the building code.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.084 OUTSIDE BALCONIES AND STAIRS.
   Outside balconies or stairs of required widths may be used for required
means of egress subject to approval of the Building Official except such
balconies shall have no dead ends beyond a stairway leading to the ground of
more than ten feet.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.085 PASSAGE THROUGH OTHER UNITS.
   Required means of egress from a dwelling unit shall be had without passing
through any portion of another dwelling unit.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
AREA, SPACE, AND USE
§ 151.090 COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS; COMPUTATION.
   Minimum floor area, sizes, and ceiling heights of dwelling units shall not
be less than provided in this subchapter, and floor areas shall be calculated
to include habitable rooms, bathrooms, water-closet compartments, pantries,
foyers, communicating corridors and closets, except the floor area of any
portion of a room with a ceiling height of less than five feet shall not be
calculated in computing floor areas.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.091 FLOOR AREAS.
   No dwelling unit shall contain less than 1,000 square feet of floor area,
except efficiency-type dwelling units of motel, hotel, or multi-family
structures shall contain not less than 300 square feet of floor area per unit
and an additional 100 square feet of floor area per unit for each occupant over
two.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.092 CEILING HEIGHTS.
   A habitable room shall have a ceiling height of not less than seven feet six
inches, except, where there is a sloping ceiling not more than one-third of the
computed floor area shall have a ceiling height of less than seven feet.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.093 ROOM WIDTHS.
   A habitable room, except the kitchen, shall not be less than seven feet in
width in at least 90% of the area of the room.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.094 ACCESS TO ROOMS.
   No dwelling or dwelling unit containing two or more sleeping rooms shall
have such room arrangements that access to a bathroom or water closet
compartment intended for use by occupants of more than one sleeping room can be
had only by passing through another sleeping room; nor shall room arrangements
be such that access to a sleeping room can be had only by passing through
another sleeping room or through a bathroom or water closet compartment; nor
shall a water closet compartment open directly into kitchens or rooms for the
preparation of food.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.095 CELLAR AREA.
   Cellar space shall not be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit, except,
cellar space may be used as a recreation room or workroom when it complies with
provisions of §
151.096(A) and has adequate lighting, ventilation, and means of egress and is
approved by the Building Officer.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.096 BASEMENT AREA.
   No basement space shall be used as a habitable room or dwelling unit unless
approved by the Building Official subject to the following provisions:
   (A)   The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and
surface runoff water and are insulated against dampness.
   (B)   The total of window area in each room is equal to at least minimum
window area sizes as required in §
151.106 of this chapter.
   (C)   The required minimum window area is located entirely above the grade
of the ground adjoining the window area.
   (D)   The total of openable window area in each room is equal to at least
the minimum as required under §
151.106 of this chapter, except where there is supplied some other device
affording adequate ventilation and approved by the Building Official.
   (E)   The room or unit, and access thereto, are protected and separated from
any adjacent heating, incinerating or other hazardous facilities. Basement
space may, however, be used as a recreation room or workroom where it complies
with requirements in this section, and has adequate lighting, ventilation, and
means of egress as approved by the Building Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
LIGHT AND VENTILATION
§ 151.105 MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS.
   Every habitable room shall have not less than one window or skylight facing
upon a street, yard,
or other open space as defined by the zoning ordinance and any alcove opening
off a habitable room may be included as part of the room in calculating
required window area if 80% of the common wall area provides an unobstructed
opening to the alcove.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.106 REQUIRED WINDOW AREA.
   (A)   The minimum total window area of any habitable room shall be not less
than 10% of the floor area of the room measured in areas of clear glass and not
less than 50% of required window area shall be easily opened for ventilation.
   (B)   Every bathroom and water closet compartment shall comply with the
light and ventilation provisions of this subchapter.
   (C)   Whenever a window of a room faces a wall or other portion of any
abutting structure which is located less than three feet from the window and
extends to a level above that of the ceiling of the room, the window shall not
be counted in calculating window area or openable area.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.107 MECHANICAL VENTILATION AND LIGHTING.
   Artificial lighting and mechanical ventilation of a capacity conforming to
provisions of the building code may be substituted for window areas subject to
approval of the Building Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.108 HALLS AND STAIRWAY LIGHTING.
   Every public hall and stairway in a multiple dwelling containing five or
more dwelling units shall be adequately lighted at all times. Every public hall
and stairway in a multiple dwelling containing not more than four dwelling
units shall have conveniently located switches controlling an adequate lighting
system which may be turned on when needed.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
PLUMBING, WATER, AND SANITATION FACILITIES
§ 151.120 COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS REQUIRED.
   (A)   Each dwelling unit shall contain plumbing, water, and sanitation
equipment and facilities conforming to the provisions of this section and to
provisions of the building and plumbing codes.
   (B)   All plumbing shall be properly installed and maintained in good
sanitary working condition, free from defects, leaks, and obstructions.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.121 SEWER AND WATER.
   (A)   Every building or structure of dwelling occupancy and each dwelling
unit therein shall be connected to a sewer and water system.
   (B)   A public storm/sanitary sewer and/or water system shall be deemed
available when a public storm/sanitary sewer and/or water system is in a place
within any street, alley, right-of-way, or easement that adjoins or abuts the
premises on which the building or structure of a dwelling, business
establishment or other building used for human occupancy, employment,
recreation or business is now located or will be located, or when the
improvement to be served is located within a reasonable distance of a public
sewer and/or water system to which a connection is practical and is permitted
by the controlling authority for the sewer or water system. A reasonable
distance for the purposes of this provision shall be deemed to be not greater
than 400 feet (excluding the crossing of any street, alley, right-of-way or
easement) from such public sewer or water system. All costs of such connections
shall be paid by the owner and such connections shall comply with standards
established by the village and all ordinances and regulations thereof.
   (C)   Whenever it shall be required to extend any currently in place storm
or sanitary sewer or water main of the current village system the course
(direction) of said extension shall be determined by the Superintendent of
Public Works and submitted to the Board of Trustees for final acceptance and
approval, thereby providing the means towards an efficient, comprehensive
system.
   (D)   Where public sewer and/or water systems are not available substitute
systems may be used subject to required standards and approval of the Building
Official and County Health Department.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65; Am. Ord. 1989-O-34, passed 8-15-89)
§ 151.122 KITCHEN SINK.
   Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink properly connected to the
water and sewer system.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.123 BATHROOM.
   Every dwelling unit shall contain, within a room or rooms that afford
privacy, a flush water closet, a lavatory basin, and a bathtub or shower, and
all such equipment shall be properly connected to the water and sewer system.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.124 HOT WATER SYSTEM.
   (A)   Every dwelling unit shall have water-heating facilities capable of
heating water to such a temperature at all times as to permit an adequate
supply of water to be drawn at all required taps at a temperature of not less
than 120° F. and all required kitchen sinks, lavatories, bathtubs and showers,
and laundry tubs shall be connected to such water-heating facilities.
   (B)   Buildings and structures of more than a single dwelling unit may have
a central water-heating system.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
HEATING EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES
§ 151.130 HEATING FACILITIES REQUIRED.
   (A)   Every building or structure of dwelling occupancy shall have heating
facilities maintained in safe and good workable condition and capable of
adequately and safely heating all habitable areas of every dwelling unit
therein, including halls and public rooms to a temperature of not less than 70°
F., at a height of three feet above the floor levels when the outdoor
temperature is at -10° F.
   (B)   A central heating system, space heaters, or individual heating system
for each dwelling unit may be used, subject to approval of the Building
Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.131 PORTABLE HEATERS.
   Portable heating equipment burning solid, liquid, or gaseous fuels and
employing a flame for combustion shall not be permitted.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.132 VENTS, CHIMNEYS, AND SMOKE PIPES.
   (A)   Every heating system burning solid, liquid, or gaseous fuels shall be
properly vented to a chimney or gas vent leading to the outdoor space.
   (B)   Every smoke pipe, chimney, or vent shall be adequately supported,
shall be reasonably clean, and shall be maintained in a condition so that there
will be no leakage or back-up of noxious gases.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.133 CENTRAL HEATING SYSTEMS.
   When a building of dwelling occupancy or a dwelling unit is heated by
central heating unit:
   (A)   Every heat duct steam pipe or hot water pipe shall be free of leaks
and shall function so that adequate heat is delivered to every area of the
building.
   (B)   Every seal between sections of hot air furnaces shall be maintained in
good repair.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.134 SPACE HEATERS.
   When dwelling units are heated by space heaters:
   (A)   Every smoke pipe or vent pipe shall be equipped with guards of metal
or other nonflammable material at the point where the pipe or vent goes through
walls, ceilings, or partitions.
   (B)   Required and sufficient clearance shall be allowed from all
combustible materials and structural elements.
   (C)   Every coal burning space heater shall have a fire-resistant panel
beneath it.
   (D)   Space heaters located in confined areas shall be equipped with air
intake vents of sufficient capacity to support combustion.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.135 SAFETY VALVES.
   Steam and hot water heating systems shall be equipped with approved safety
valves.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.136 HOT WATER HEATERS.
   Hot water heating facilities shall be installed as required by this chapter
and the building and plumbing codes and shall be maintained in a safe and good
working condition at all times and shall be equipped with an approved type
pressure valve.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.137 INCINERATORS.
   Incinerators when installed in buildings of dwelling occupancy or in
dwelling units shall be subject to approval of the Building Official and shall
be installed as provided herein for solid fuel heaters, shall be vented to a
chimney or approved type vent, and shall be located with adequate and safe
clearances to combustible materials or structural elements.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
ELECTRIC WIRING AND FACILITIES
§ 151.145 COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS; CONNECTION REQUIRED.
   (A)   All electrical wiring and equipment shall be installed and maintained
as provided by this chapter and by provisions of the building and electrical
codes.
   (B)   Every building or structure of dwelling occupancy located within 300
feet of an electric utility line shall be connected to such utility service.
   (C)   Buildings or structures inaccessible to an electric utility line or
service may use substitute systems for lighting and power subject to approval
of the Building Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.146 MAINTENANCE.
   Electrical systems shall be maintained in a safe and good working condition
and:
   (A)   All exposed electrical wire shall have insulation which is in good
condition.
   (B)   Every fixture and outlet shall function properly and shall be securely
fastened in place.
   (C)   Every switch plate and outlet plate shall be securely fastened in
place.
   (D)   Short circuits or breaks shall not exist in any electric line.
   (E)   No obvious shock hazard shall exist.
   (F)   No temporary wiring shall be used.
   (G)   Extension cords shall run directly from portable electric fixtures to
convenience outlets and shall not be placed underneath floor covering material
or extend through doorways, transoms, or other similar apertures through
structural elements.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.147 APPLIANCES.
   Electrical appliances shall be installed and maintained as provided by the
provisions of this chapter and by provisions of the building and electrical
codes and in conformance with recommendations and specifications of the
manufacturer.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.148 CONVENIENCE OUTLETS.
   Every dwelling or dwelling unit shall be provided with electric convenience
outlets or ceiling fixtures that meet requirements of the building and
electrical codes as to number, location, and installation.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.149 OVERLOADS.
   Electrical circuits shall not be overloaded as a result of connecting
appliances which operate at high wattages to outlets supplied with wire of
inadequate size.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
GAS FACILITIES
§ 151.160 CONNECTIONS WITH GAS LINES.
   All gas-burning furnaces, hot water heaters, appliances, and equipment shall
be connected to a gas line with solid metal piping and where required shall be
vented to a chimney or approved type gas vent.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.161 GAS PIPING.
   Every gas pipe shall be sound and tightly put together without leaks and
shall not be corroded or obstructed as to reduce gas pressure or volume.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.162 GAS PRESSURE.
   Gas pressure shall be adequate to permit proper flow of gas from all open
gas valves at all times.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.163 LP OR BOTTLED GAS.
   Storage facilities, tanks, or containers for LP or bottled gases shall be
located outside the building or structure and shall be equipped with an
approved type relief valve, shall be maintained in good condition free of rust
or corrosion at all times, and all connections thereto shall be free of leaks.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
ROOMING HOUSES
§ 151.170 APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Provisions of this chapter applying to maintenance, area, light,
ventilation, sanitation, and means of egress shall apply to rooming houses and
other occupancies specified in this subchapter in addition to provisions of
this subchapter.
   (B)   Provisions of this subchapter shall apply to rooming houses, hotels,
motels, tourist homes, and rest or nursing homes and shall apply to club
houses, dormitories, or any other facility in which space is provided for
living and sleeping to three or more persons not related to the owner or
operator.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.171 OPERATOR'S RESPONSIBILITY.
   The operator of a rooming house and other occupancies specified by this
subchapter shall be responsible for maintenance of the premises, buildings,
structures, and grounds thereto to the standards provided by this chapter and
this subchapter.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.172 ROOMING HOUSES; HOTELS; MOTELS.
   For purposes of administering this chapter provisions applying to rooming
houses as defined herein shall apply to hotels, motels, or other occupancies
where space for living or eating is rented or let for hire to a transient
clientele.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.173 ROOMING HOUSE PERMIT.
   (A)   No person shall operate a rooming house without first obtaining a
valid rooming house permit issued by the Building Official upon application in
the name of the operator and for the specific rooming house and the permit
shall be prominently displayed within the rooming house at all times.
   (B)   A rooming house permit shall not be transferrable and shall be
surrendered by the permit holder to the Building Official within 24 hours of a
transfer of interest or control of a rooming house.
   (C)   A rooming house permit expires one year after the date upon which it
was issued and it shall be the responsibility of the operator to apply for
renewal.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65) Penalty, see §
151.999
§ 151.174 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
   Application for a rooming house permit shall be filed with the Building
Official in such form as prescribed and shall be approved by the Zoning
Officer, Fire Chief, and Health Officer for endorsement that the building,
structure, and premises conform to ordinances, rules, and regulations enforced
by said officers.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.175 PERMIT FEE.
   The annual application fee for a rooming house permit shall be $100, which
shall be paid upon submission of any application to the village. All fees
received under this section shall be non-refundable.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65; Am. Ord. 1988-O-11, passed 3-15-88)
§ 151.176 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   A rooming house permit may be revoked upon notice to the operator by the
Building Official upon violation of this chapter or any rule or regulation
adopted pursuant to this chapter or upon evidence of immoral conduct of the
operator or occupants of the rooming house.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.177 APPEAL OF REJECTION OR REVOCATION.
   A rooming house operator may appeal a rejection of a rooming house permit
application or a revocation order of the Building Official to the Board of
Appeals subject to procedures of the Board of Appeals.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.178 MEANS OF EGRESS.
   Every rooming unit shall have not less than one unobstructed means of egress
to the exterior of the building at ground level without passage through another
rooming unit and rooming units located above or below the ground floor shall
have not less than two means of egress, and all required means of egress shall
be as provided in §§
151.080 through
151.085 of this chapter.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.179 FLOOR AREA.
   Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one persons shall contain not
less than 100 square feet of floor area and not less than 80 square feet for
each occupant and shall be not less in any dimension than provided in §§
151.090 through
151.096, and areas shall be computed as provided in §§
151.090 through
151.096.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.180 LIGHT AND VENTILATION.
   Every room occupied for sleeping purposes shall be provided with light and
ventilation as provided in §§
151.105 through
151.108.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.181 PLUMBING, WATER, AND SANITATION FACILITIES.
   (A)   Every rooming house shall be equipped with not less than one flush
water closet, one lavatory basin, and one bathtub or shower properly connected
to an approved water and sewer system and in good working condition for each
six occupants or fraction thereof, including members of the operators family,
and each lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be supplied with hot and
cold water at all times.
   (B)   Flush urinals may be substituted for not less than one-half the
required number of water closets in rooming houses of male occupancy only.
   (C)   All water closets, lavatory, and bath facilities shall be located to
afford privacy, shall be separate from habitable rooms, shall be readily
accessible to all occupants sharing the facilities from a common hall or
passageway without passing through any sleeping room or going outside the
building, and shall not be more than one story removed from the rooming unit of
any occupant intended to share the facility and no such facility located in a
basement or cellar shall be included in computing the required number, except
by approval of the Building Official.
   (D)   All such facilities shall be located in a room or rooms conforming to
requirements of §
151.066 and §§
151.120 through
151.124.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.182 HEATING.
   Every rooming unit and every rooming house shall be provided with heating
equipment as provided in §§
151.130 through
151.137 of this chapter.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.183 LIGHTING.
   (A)   Every rooming unit shall contain not less than two separate floor or
wall-type electric convenience outlets, or one such convenience outlet and one
ceiling type electric light fixture.
   (B)   Every public hall, stairway, and foyer of a rooming house shall be
provided with sufficient lighting fixtures to supply illumination of not less
than one foot-candle on every portion of such areas at all times of the day and
night.
   (C)   All electrical wiring, fixtures, and equipment shall be installed and
maintained as provided in §§
151.145 through
151.149.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.184 COOKING EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   Cooking facilities where permitted in rooming house units shall
include such equipment as required for kitchens in §§
151.040 through
151.048 and §§
151.120 through
151.124 of this chapter.
   (B)   Cooking equipment shall be so constructed and installed that it will
function safely and effectively and shall be maintained in sound working
condition.
   (C)   The use of portable cooking equipment employing flame and cooking
equipment using gasoline or kerosene as fuel shall not be permitted in rooming
units or rooming houses.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.185 BEDDING AND TOWELS.
   Bedding, bed linen, and towels supplied by the operator shall be maintained
in a clean and sanitary manner and clean bed linen and towels shall be supplied
not less than once each week and upon letting of any rooming unit to any
occupant.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
§ 151.186 RUBBISH AND GARBAGE DISPOSAL.
   Every rooming unit shall have adequate rubbish and garbage disposal
facilities and garbage containers of a type and in a location approved by the
Building Official.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
AESTHETIC STANDARDS
§ 151.200 ANTI-MONOTONY STANDARDS.
   The following standards shall apply to all construction of new single-family
detached dwellings in the village for which permits are granted after the
effective date of this section:
   (A)   Abutting lots. No single-family detached dwelling shall be erected on
any lot abutting, or directly across the street from, a lot with a single-
family detached dwelling of the same exterior design or appearance, or with
identical front elevations.
   (B)   Spacing. Not more than two single-family detached dwellings of the
same exterior design or appearance, or with identical front elevations, shall
be erected on the same block and on the same side of the street.
   (C)   Criteria. The village shall apply the criteria from divisions (C)(1)
through (C)(3) to determine whether the exterior design and appearance and
front elevations of two single-family detached dwellings are the same or,
instead, are sufficiently dissimilar:
      (1)   Roof lines. To be considered dissimilar, the roof lines of two
single-family detached dwellings as seen from the front of the dwelling shall
be changed in at least one of the following ways:
         (a)   Changing a gable roof to hip roof or changing a hip roof to a
gable roof.
         (b)   Providing an intersecting gable roof on the main roof, provided
that the height of the intersecting roof is at least 50% of the height of the
main roof.
         (c)   Providing an intersecting hip roof on the main hip roof,
provided that the height of the intersecting hip roof is at least 50% of the
height of the main roof.
      (2)   Windows. To be considered dissimilar, the windows of two single-
family detached dwellings shall be changed in at least one of the following
ways:
         (a)   Changing from single windows to a multiple-window arrangement
(ganged units) or changing from a multiple-window arrangement to single
windows.
         (b)   Providing a bay or bow window in the area of the predominant
window.
      (3)   Construction materials. To be considered dissimilar, the
construction materials of two single- family detached dwellings shall be
changed in at least one of the following ways, provided that when materials are
changed, the change must occur throughout the front facade of elevation for a
minimum of one story in height.
         (a)   Changing the siding from horizontal to vertical or vertical to
horizontal.
         (b)   Changing the facing material (wood, brick, stone, stucco/
staccato board and trim).
   (D)   Administration. The provisions of this section shall be administered
by the Building Official. To aid the Building Official and applicants in their
interpretation of the provisions of this section, the Building Official may
prepare illustrative drawings and written descriptions of the manner in which
the provisions have been or will be administered.
   (E)   Appeals. If a building permit is denied to an applicant by reason of
this section, then that applicant may appeal that decision to the Board of
Trustees, whose decision shall be final. On such appeal, the Board of Trustees
may:
      (1)   Order the permit to be issued;
      (2)   Order the permit to be issued if modifications are made in the
design of the building to bring it into conformity with the provisions of this
section; or
      (3)   Deny the appeal.
(Ord. 2000-O-16, passed 10-17-00)
§ 151.999 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates a provision of this chapter shall be subject to a
fine of not less than $25 or more than $500 for each violation and each day's
failure to comply with such provisions shall constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. 1965-O-2, passed 1-19-65)
